ID: Electromagnetism_121 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Electromagnetism Raw HTML

Question 1:

Problem 61 (Modified):The figure shows capacitor 1 (C‚ÇÅ = 8.00 ŒºF), capacitor 2 (C‚ÇÇ = 6.00 ŒºF), and capacitor 3 (C‚ÇÉ = 8.00 ŒºF) connected to a 12.0 V battery with a switch S initially open.12V+‚àíPC‚ÇÅ=8ŒºFC‚ÇÉ=8ŒºFC‚ÇÇ=6ŒºFSC‚ÇÑ=6ŒºF(uncharged)Switch S is initially open, then closedInitial Configuration:With switch S open, capacitors C‚ÇÅ and C‚ÇÉ are in series, and this series combination is in parallel with C‚ÇÇ. All are charged by the 12.0 V battery.Event:Switch S is closed, connecting uncharged capacitor C‚ÇÑ (C‚ÇÑ = 6.00 ŒºF) in parallel with C‚ÇÉ.Analysis Questions:(a) How much charge passes through point P from the battery after S is closed?(b) How much charge appears on capacitor C‚ÇÑ?(c) Explain the discrepancy between these two charge values.

Options:

A.
(a) ŒîQ_battery = 24 ŒºC, (b) Q‚ÇÑ = 24 ŒºC, (c) No discrepancy; charge is conserved
B.
(a) ŒîQ_battery = 18 ŒºC, (b) Q‚ÇÑ = 24 ŒºC, (c) The discrepancy exists because some initial charge is redistributed from C‚ÇÅ and C‚ÇÉ to C‚ÇÑ, so less charge flows from battery
C.
(a) ŒîQ_battery = 13.1 ŒºC, (b) Q‚ÇÑ = 26.2 ŒºC, (c) The discrepancy exists because some initial charge is redistributed from C‚ÇÅ and C‚ÇÉ to C‚ÇÑ, so less charge flows from battery
D.
(a) ŒîQ_battery = 36 ŒºC, (b) Q‚ÇÑ = 36 ŒºC, (c) No discrepancy; all charge from battery goes to C‚ÇÑ
Correct Answer: C

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Analyze initial configuration (S open) </strong> <p> C‚ÇÅ and C‚ÇÉ are in series (equal charge), and C‚ÇÇ is in parallel with the battery. </p> <p> Series combination capacitance: </p> <p class="formula"> C‚ÇÅ‚ÇÉ = (C‚ÇÅ √ó C‚ÇÉ)/(C‚ÇÅ + C‚ÇÉ) = (8.00 √ó 8.00)/(8.00 + 8.00) = 64.00/16.00 = 4.00 ŒºF </p> <p> Initial charges: </p> <p> Q‚ÇÇ,i = C‚ÇÇ √ó V = 6.00 √ó 12.0 = 72.0 ŒºC </p> <p> Q‚ÇÅ,i = Q‚ÇÉ,i = C‚ÇÅ‚ÇÉ √ó V = 4.00 √ó 12.0 = 48.0 ŒºC </p> <p> Total initial charge from battery: Q_total,i = 72.0 + 48.0 = 120.0 ŒºC </p></li> <li><strong> Step 2: Verify initial voltages </strong> <p> Voltage across C‚ÇÇ: V‚ÇÇ = 12.0 V (parallel with battery) </p> <p> For the series C‚ÇÅ-C‚ÇÉ: </p> <p> V‚ÇÅ,i = Q‚ÇÅ/C‚ÇÅ = 48.0/8.00 = 6.0 V </p> <p> V‚ÇÉ,i = Q‚ÇÉ/C‚ÇÉ = 48.0/8.00 = 6.0 V </p> <p> Check: V‚ÇÅ,i + V‚ÇÉ,i = 6.0 + 6.0 = 12.0 V ‚úì </p></li> <li><strong> Step 3: Analyze final configuration (S closed) </strong> <p> When S closes, C‚ÇÑ connects in parallel with C‚ÇÉ. </p> <p> New configuration: C‚ÇÅ in series with (C‚ÇÉ || C‚ÇÑ), and C‚ÇÇ still in parallel with battery. </p> <p> Parallel combination: </p> <p class="formula"> C‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ = C‚ÇÉ + C‚ÇÑ = 8.00 + 6.00 = 14.00 ŒºF </p> <p> Series with C‚ÇÅ: </p> <p class="formula"> C‚ÇÅ‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ = (C‚ÇÅ √ó C‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ)/(C‚ÇÅ + C‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ) = (8.00 √ó 14.00)/(8.00 + 14.00) = 112.00/22.00 = 56/11 ŒºF ‚âà 5.091 ŒºF </p></li> <li><strong> Step 4: Calculate final charges </strong> <p> C‚ÇÇ remains unchanged: Q‚ÇÇ,f = 72.0 ŒºC </p> <p> For C‚ÇÅ-(C‚ÇÉ||C‚ÇÑ) series at 12V: </p> <p> Q‚ÇÅ,f = C‚ÇÅ‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ √ó V = (56/11) √ó 12.0 = 672/11 ŒºC ‚âà 61.09 ŒºC </p> <p> This charge is on C‚ÇÅ and represents the total charge on the parallel combination (C‚ÇÉ||C‚ÇÑ). </p> <p> Voltage across C‚ÇÅ: </p> <p> V‚ÇÅ,f = Q‚ÇÅ,f/C‚ÇÅ = (672/11)/8.00 = 672/88 = 84/11 V ‚âà 7.636 V </p> <p> Voltage across C‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ: </p> <p> V‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ = V - V‚ÇÅ,f = 12.0 - 84/11 = (132 - 84)/11 = 48/11 V ‚âà 4.364 V </p></li> <li><strong> Step 5: Calculate charge on C‚ÇÑ </strong> <p> Since C‚ÇÉ and C‚ÇÑ are in parallel, they have the same voltage V‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ: </p> <p> Q‚ÇÉ,f = C‚ÇÉ √ó V‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ = 8.00 √ó (48/11) = 384/11 ŒºC ‚âà 34.91 ŒºC </p> <p> Q‚ÇÑ,f = C‚ÇÑ √ó V‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ = 6.00 √ó (48/11) = 288/11 ŒºC ‚âà 26.18 ŒºC </p> <p> Verification: Q‚ÇÉ,f + Q‚ÇÑ,f = 384/11 + 288/11 = 672/11 = Q‚ÇÅ,f ‚úì </p></li> <li><strong> Step 6: Calculate charge from battery </strong> <p> Total final charge on all capacitors: </p> <p> Q_total,f = Q‚ÇÇ,f + Q‚ÇÅ,f = 72.0 + 672/11 = (792 + 672)/11 = 1464/11 ŒºC ‚âà 133.09 ŒºC </p> <p> Change in total charge supplied by battery: </p> <p class="formula"> ŒîQ_battery = Q_total,f - Q_total,i = 133.09 - 120.0 = 13.09 ŒºC ‚âà 13.1 ŒºC </p></li> <li><strong> Step 7: Explain the discrepancy </strong> <p> We found: </p> <ul> <li> Charge from battery: ŒîQ_battery = 13.1 ŒºC </li> <li> Charge on C‚ÇÑ: Q‚ÇÑ = 26.2 ŒºC </li> <li> Discrepancy: Q‚ÇÑ - ŒîQ_battery = 26.2 - 13.1 = 13.1 ŒºC </li> </ul> <p> <strong> Physical explanation: </strong> </p> <p> The discrepancy exists because C‚ÇÑ receives charge from TWO sources: </p> <ol> <li> Fresh charge from the battery (13.1 ŒºC) </li> <li> Redistributed charge from C‚ÇÅ and C‚ÇÉ (13.1 ŒºC) </li> </ol> <p> When the switch closes, C‚ÇÅ decreases from 48.0 ŒºC to 61.09 ŒºC (gains 13.1 ŒºC from battery), but C‚ÇÉ decreases from 48.0 ŒºC to 34.91 ŒºC (loses 13.1 ŒºC). This lost charge from C‚ÇÉ flows to C‚ÇÑ. </p> <p> Therefore, the battery supplies less charge than C‚ÇÑ gains because the circuit reconfiguration causes charge redistribution. </p></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Electromagnetism_120 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Electromagnetism HTML Entities Raw HTML

Question 2:

Problem 36 (Modified):As a safety engineer, you must evaluate the practice of storing flammable conducting liquids in nonconducting containers. The company supplying a certain liquid has been using a squat, cylindrical plastic container of radius r = 0.20 m and filling it to height h = 10 cm, which is not the container's full interior height.‚àí‚àí‚àí‚àí‚àí‚àí‚àí‚àí‚àí‚àí+++++Venting portFull heightr = 0.20 mh = 10 cmConducting liquidSurface charge density:œÉ = ‚àí2.0 ŒºC/m¬≤Your investigation reveals that during handling at the company, the exterior surface of the container commonly acquires a negative charge density of magnitude 2.0 ŒºC/m¬≤ (approximately uniform). Because the liquid is a conducting material, the charge on the container induces charge separation within the liquid.Given:Container radius: r = 0.20 mLiquid height: h = 10 cm = 0.10 mSurface charge density: œÉ = 2.0 ŒºC/m¬≤ = 2.0 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∂ C/m¬≤Capacitance of liquid's central portion: C = 35 pF = 35 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≤ FMinimum spark energy to ignite: E_min = 10 mJ = 0.010 JDetermine:(a) How much negative charge is induced in the center of the liquid's bulk?(b) What is the potential energy associated with the negative charge in that effective capacitor?(c) Can a spark from the central portion of the liquid ignite the liquid if the spark energy equals the stored potential energy?

Options:

A.
(a) Q = 2.5 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∑ C, (b) U = 8.9 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å¥ J, (c) Yes, spark can ignite (U > E_min)
B.
(a) Q = 5.0 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∑ C, (b) U = 5.0 √ó 10‚Åª¬≥ J, (c) No, spark cannot ignite (U < E_min)
C.
(a) Q = 2.5 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∑ C, (b) U = 8.9 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å¥ J, (c) No, spark cannot ignite (U < E_min)
D.
(a) Q = 1.0 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∂ C, (b) U = 1.4 √ó 10‚Åª¬≤ J, (c) Yes, spark can ignite (U > E_min)
Correct Answer: C

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Calculate total charge on container exterior </strong> <p> The lateral surface area in contact with the liquid: </p> <p> A = 2œÄrh = 2œÄ(0.20)(0.10) = 0.04œÄ m¬≤ = 0.1257 m¬≤ </p> <p> Total charge on container surface: </p> <p> Q_container = œÉ √ó A = (2.0 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∂)(0.1257) = 2.51 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∑ C </p> <p> ‚âà 2.5 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∑ C </p></li> <li><strong> Step 2: Determine induced charge in liquid </strong> <p> Since the liquid is conducting, the external negative charge on the container induces positive charge on the liquid's outer surface and negative charge accumulates in the center (bulk). </p> <p> By electrostatic induction, the magnitude of negative charge in the center approximately equals the positive charge induced on the surface, which equals the container charge: </p> <p> Q_induced ‚âà Q_container = 2.5 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∑ C </p></li> <li><strong> Step 3: Calculate potential energy in the effective capacitor </strong> <p> The central portion of liquid acts as a capacitor with capacitance C = 35 pF. </p> <p> Using the energy formula: </p> <p> U = Q¬≤/(2C) = (2.5 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∑)¬≤/(2 √ó 35 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≤) </p> <p> U = (6.25 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥)/(70 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≤) </p> <p> U = (6.25 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥)/(7.0 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬π) </p> <p> U = 0.893 √ó 10‚Åª¬≥ J </p> <p> U = 8.9 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å¥ J = 0.89 mJ </p></li> <li><strong> Step 4: Compare with minimum ignition energy </strong> <p> Minimum spark energy needed: E_min = 10 mJ = 0.010 J = 10 √ó 10‚Åª¬≥ J </p> <p> Available energy: U = 0.89 mJ = 0.89 √ó 10‚Åª¬≥ J </p> <p> Since U = 0.89 mJ < 10 mJ, the stored energy is insufficient to ignite the liquid. </p> <p> <strong> Conclusion: </strong> No, a spark cannot ignite the liquid because the available energy (0.89 mJ) is less than the minimum required (10 mJ). </p></li> <li><strong> Step 5: Safety assessment </strong> <p> The safety margin is approximately: </p> <p> E_min/U = 10/0.89 ‚âà 11.2 </p> <p> The required ignition energy is about 11 times higher than the available stored energy, indicating a reasonably safe margin under these specific conditions. </p></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Electromagnetism_119 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Electromagnetism Raw HTML

Question 3:

Problem 26 (Modified):Capacitor 3 in the circuit shown below is a variable capacitor (its capacitance C‚ÇÉ can be varied). The figure shows the electric potential V‚ÇÅ across capacitor 1 versus C‚ÇÉ.V+‚àíC‚ÇÅC‚ÇÇC‚ÇÉC‚ÇÉ (ŒºF)V‚ÇÅ (V)02468100C‚ÇÉ‚Çõ=12.0Asymptote: V‚ÇÅ‚Üí10VThe horizontal scale is set by C‚ÇÉ‚Çõ = 12.0 ŒºF. Electric potential V‚ÇÅ approaches an asymptote of 10 V as C‚ÇÉ ‚Üí ‚àû.Circuit Configuration:C‚ÇÅ is in series with the parallel combination of C‚ÇÇ and C‚ÇÉ.Determine:(a) The electric potential V across the battery(b) The capacitance C‚ÇÅ(c) The capacitance C‚ÇÇ

Options:

A.
V = 12 V, C‚ÇÅ = 6.0 ŒºF, C‚ÇÇ = 3.0 ŒºF
B.
V = 10 V, C‚ÇÅ = 5.0 ŒºF, C‚ÇÇ = 5.0 ŒºF
C.
V = 15 V, C‚ÇÅ = 7.5 ŒºF, C‚ÇÇ = 7.5 ŒºF
D.
V = 20 V, C‚ÇÅ = 10.0 ŒºF, C‚ÇÇ = 10.0 ŒºF
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Identify circuit topology and voltage divider formula </strong> <p> The circuit has C‚ÇÅ in series with (C‚ÇÇ || C‚ÇÉ). Let C_parallel = C‚ÇÇ + C‚ÇÉ. </p> <p> For series capacitors, voltage divides as: </p> <p class="formula"> V‚ÇÅ = V √ó C_parallel/(C‚ÇÅ + C_parallel) </p> <p> where V‚ÇÅ is the voltage across C‚ÇÅ and V is the battery voltage. </p></li> <li><strong> Step 2: Apply limiting behavior as C‚ÇÉ ‚Üí ‚àû </strong> <p> As C‚ÇÉ ‚Üí ‚àû: </p> <p> C_parallel = C‚ÇÇ + C‚ÇÉ ‚Üí ‚àû </p> <p> V‚ÇÅ = V √ó C_parallel/(C‚ÇÅ + C_parallel) = V √ó 1/(C‚ÇÅ/C_parallel + 1) ‚Üí V √ó 1/(0 + 1) = V </p> <p> From the graph: V‚ÇÅ ‚Üí 10V as C‚ÇÉ ‚Üí ‚àû </p> <p> Therefore: <strong> V = 10V </strong> ‚úì </p></li> <li><strong> Step 3: Apply limiting behavior as C‚ÇÉ ‚Üí 0 </strong> <p> When C‚ÇÉ = 0 (open circuit), only C‚ÇÇ remains in the parallel combination: </p> <p> C_parallel = C‚ÇÇ + 0 = C‚ÇÇ </p> <p> V‚ÇÅ = V √ó C‚ÇÇ/(C‚ÇÅ + C‚ÇÇ) = 10 √ó C‚ÇÇ/(C‚ÇÅ + C‚ÇÇ) </p> <p> From the graph at C‚ÇÉ ‚âà 0: V‚ÇÅ ‚âà 5V (reading from the curve's starting point) </p> <p> Therefore: 5 = 10 √ó C‚ÇÇ/(C‚ÇÅ + C‚ÇÇ) </p> <p> 0.5 = C‚ÇÇ/(C‚ÇÅ + C‚ÇÇ) </p> <p> 0.5(C‚ÇÅ + C‚ÇÇ) = C‚ÇÇ </p> <p> 0.5C‚ÇÅ + 0.5C‚ÇÇ = C‚ÇÇ </p> <p> 0.5C‚ÇÅ = 0.5C‚ÇÇ </p> <p> <strong> C‚ÇÅ = C‚ÇÇ </strong> </p></li> <li><strong> Step 4: Determine specific values </strong> <p> From the options where V = 10V and C‚ÇÅ = C‚ÇÇ: </p> <p> Option B: V = 10 V, C‚ÇÅ = 5.0 ŒºF, C‚ÇÇ = 5.0 ŒºF ‚úì </p> <p> We can verify with an intermediate point. At C‚ÇÉ = 12.0 ŒºF (C‚ÇÉ‚Çõ): </p> <p> C_parallel = 5.0 + 12.0 = 17.0 ŒºF </p> <p> V‚ÇÅ = 10 √ó 17.0/(5.0 + 17.0) = 10 √ó 17.0/22.0 = 7.73V </p> <p> This matches the graph showing V‚ÇÅ approaching but not quite at the asymptote at C‚ÇÉ‚Çõ ‚úì </p></li> <li><strong> Step 5: Complete verification </strong> <p> Check all conditions: </p> <ul> <li> As C‚ÇÉ ‚Üí ‚àû: V‚ÇÅ ‚Üí 10V ‚úì </li> <li> At C‚ÇÉ = 0: V‚ÇÅ = 10 √ó 5/(5+5) = 5V ‚úì </li> <li> At C‚ÇÉ = 12 ŒºF: V‚ÇÅ = 7.73V (consistent with graph) ‚úì </li> <li> Battery voltage: V = 10V ‚úì </li> <li> Equal capacitances: C‚ÇÅ = C‚ÇÇ = 5.0 ŒºF ‚úì </li> </ul></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Electromagnetism_118 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Electromagnetism Raw HTML

Question 4:

Problem 79 (Modified):A parallel-plate capacitor has charge q and plate area A.Lower PlateUpper Plate (+q)ExdxFPlate Area = A++++++‚àí‚àí‚àí‚àí‚àí‚àíTask:(a) By finding the work needed to increase the plate separation from x to x + dx, determine the force F between the plates. (Hint: Use the relation dW = F¬∑dx)(b) Show that the force per unit area (the electrostatic stress) acting on either plate equals the energy density u = Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤/2 between the plates.Given relationships:Work-energy theorem: dW = F¬∑dxCapacitor energy: U = q¬≤/(2C)Parallel-plate capacitance: C = Œµ‚ÇÄA/xElectric field: E = q/(Œµ‚ÇÄA) = œÉ/Œµ‚ÇÄEnergy density: u = Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤/2

Options:

A.
F = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA), Stress = F/A = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA¬≤) = Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤/2 ‚úì
B.
F = q¬≤/(Œµ‚ÇÄA), Stress = F/A = q¬≤/(Œµ‚ÇÄA¬≤) = Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤
C.
F = q¬≤x/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA¬≤), Stress = F/A = q¬≤x/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA¬≥) ‚â† Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤/2
D.
F = qE, Stress = F/A = qE/A = œÉE = Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤/2 ‚úì (but incomplete derivation)
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Express energy as function of separation </strong> <p> For a capacitor with constant charge q (isolated from battery): </p> <p> U = q¬≤/(2C) </p> <p> Since C = Œµ‚ÇÄA/x: </p> <p> U = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA/x) = q¬≤x/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA) </p> <p> Note: Energy increases with separation when charge is constant. </p></li> <li><strong> Step 2: Find work to increase separation by dx </strong> <p> When separation increases from x to x + dx, energy increases by: </p> <p> dU = d[q¬≤x/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA)] = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA) ¬∑ dx </p> <p> This increase in energy equals the work done against the attractive force: </p> <p> dW = F ¬∑ dx </p> <p> Therefore: </p> <p> F ¬∑ dx = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA) ¬∑ dx </p></li> <li><strong> Step 3: Determine the force </strong> <p> Canceling dx: </p> <p> F = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA) </p> <p> This is the magnitude of the attractive force between the plates. </p> <p> Alternatively, using F = -dU/dx (force opposes increase in U): </p> <p> F = -d/dx[q¬≤x/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA)] = -q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA) </p> <p> The negative sign indicates the force is attractive (opposes separation). </p> <p> Magnitude: |F| = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA) </p></li> <li><strong> Step 4: Calculate electrostatic stress (force per unit area) </strong> <p> Stress = F/A = [q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA)]/A = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA¬≤) </p></li> <li><strong> Step 5: Express in terms of electric field </strong> <p> The electric field between the plates: </p> <p> E = œÉ/Œµ‚ÇÄ = q/(Œµ‚ÇÄA) </p> <p> Therefore: q = Œµ‚ÇÄEA </p> <p> Substituting into stress formula: </p> <p> Stress = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA¬≤) = (Œµ‚ÇÄEA)¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA¬≤) </p> <p> Stress = Œµ‚ÇÄ¬≤E¬≤A¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA¬≤) = Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤/2 </p></li> <li><strong> Step 6: Connect to energy density </strong> <p> The energy density in the electric field is: </p> <p> u = Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤/2 </p> <p> We have shown that: </p> <p> <strong> Stress = F/A = Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤/2 = u </strong> </p> <p> This proves that the electrostatic stress equals the energy density! </p></li> <li><strong> Step 7: Physical interpretation </strong> <p> This remarkable result shows that the energy stored in the electric field exerts a mechanical stress (pressure) on the plates. The field energy density directly translates to mechanical pressure. </p> <p> This principle extends to all electromagnetic fields: the energy density in a field manifests as a mechanical stress (electromagnetic stress tensor in general). </p> <p> For capacitors, this stress is always attractive, trying to reduce the plate separation and thereby reduce the stored energy (for constant charge). </p></li> <li><strong> Step 8: Numerical example verification </strong> <p> For a capacitor with q = 1 ŒºC, A = 0.01 m¬≤: </p> <p> F = (10‚Åª‚Å∂)¬≤/(2 √ó 8.85√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó 0.01) = 10‚Åª¬π¬≤/(1.77√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≥) = 5.65 N </p> <p> Stress = 5.65/0.01 = 565 Pa </p> <p> E = 10‚Åª‚Å∂/(8.85√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó 0.01) = 10‚Åª‚Å∂/(8.85√ó10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥) = 1.13√ó10‚Å∑ V/m </p> <p> u = 8.85√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó (1.13√ó10‚Å∑)¬≤/2 = 565 J/m¬≥ = 565 Pa ‚úì </p></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_6 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Physics Raw HTML

Question 5:

Three capacitors with capacitances C‚ÇÅ = 10.0 ŒºF, C‚ÇÇ = 5.00 ŒºF, and C‚ÇÉ = 4.00 ŒºF are connected in a circuit arrangement where C‚ÇÅ, C‚ÇÇ, and C‚ÇÉ are initially all in series across a potential difference V = 100.0 V. If capacitor 3 undergoes electrical breakdown so that it becomes equivalent to conducting wire, what is the increase in the charge on capacitor 1?

Options:

A.
100 ŒºC
B.
151.5 ŒºC
C.
181.8 ŒºC
D.
200 ŒºC
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> When dealing with capacitor breakdown problems: (1) Analyze initial circuit configuration and calculate initial charges using series/parallel rules, (2) Identify how breakdown changes circuit topology, (3) Calculate new equivalent capacitance and charges, (4) Find the difference. Key insight: In series, all capacitors have same charge; breakdown removes one capacitor from series chain. </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> An IIT topper recognizes immediately that in a series circuit, all capacitors carry the same charge. When C‚ÇÉ breaks down (becomes a wire), it effectively disappears from the circuit, reducing the number of capacitors in series from 3 to 2. This increases the equivalent capacitance, allowing more charge to flow from the battery. The key is that the battery voltage remains constant at 100 V. </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> ‚Ä¢ For capacitors in series: 1/C_eq = 1/C‚ÇÅ + 1/C‚ÇÇ + 1/C‚ÇÉ‚Ä¢ Charge in series: Q = C_eq √ó V (same for all)‚Ä¢ Energy storage: U = ¬ΩCV¬≤ = ¬ΩQ¬≤/C = ¬ΩQV‚Ä¢ Breakdown condition: Capacitor becomes a conductor (wire) </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Step 1: Initial Configuration Analysis</strong><br/> All three capacitors in series: 1/C_eq_initial = 1/10.0 + 1/5.00 + 1/4.00<br/> 1/C_eq_initial = 0.100 + 0.200 + 0.250 = 0.550 ŒºF‚Åª¬π<br/> C_eq_initial = 1.818 ŒºF</li> <li><strong>Step 2: Calculate Initial Charge</strong><br/> Q_initial = C_eq_initial √ó V = 1.818 ŒºF √ó 100 V = 181.8 ŒºC<br/> Since capacitors are in series, Q‚ÇÅ_initial = 181.8 ŒºC</li> <li><strong>Step 3: After Breakdown Configuration</strong><br/> C‚ÇÉ becomes a wire (short circuit), leaving only C‚ÇÅ and C‚ÇÇ in series:<br/> 1/C_eq_= 1/10.0 + 1/5.00 = 0.100 + 0.200 = 0.300 ŒºF‚Åª¬π<br/> C_eq_= 3.333 ŒºF</li> <li><strong>Step 4: Calculate Charge</strong><br/> Q_= C_eq_√ó V = 3.333 ŒºF √ó 100 V = 333.3 ŒºC<br/> Q‚ÇÅ_= 333.3 ŒºC (still in series with C‚ÇÇ)</li> <li><strong>Step 5: Find the Increase</strong><br/> ŒîQ‚ÇÅ = Q‚ÇÅ_Q‚ÇÅ_initial = 333.3 - 181.8 = 151.5 ŒºC</li> <li><strong>Step 6: Physical Interpretation</strong><br/> The breakdown reduces circuit resistance to charge flow, allowing more charge to accumulate. The voltage across C‚ÇÅ increases from V‚ÇÅ_initial = Q/C‚ÇÅ = 18.18 V to V‚ÇÅ_= 33.33 V.</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_7 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Physics HTML Entities Raw HTML

Question 6:

A flammable conducting liquid is stored in a nonconducting cylindrical plastic container of radius r = 0.20 m, filled to height h = 10 cm. During handling, the exterior surface commonly acquires a negative charge density of magnitude 2.0 ŒºC/m¬≤ (approximately uniform). The capacitance of the central portion of the liquid relative to ground is 35 pF. The minimum spark energy needed to ignite the liquid is 10 mJ. How much negative charge is induced in the center of the liquid's bulk, and can a spark from the grounded venting port ignite the liquid?

Options:

A.
Induced charge = -0.15 ŒºC; Energy = 0.32 mJ; Cannot ignite
B.
Induced charge = -0.25 ŒºC; Energy = 0.90 mJ; Cannot ignite
C.
Induced charge = -0.25 ŒºC; Energy = 12.5 mJ; Can ignite
D.
Induced charge = -0.50 ŒºC; Energy = 3.57 mJ; Cannot ignite
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> For electrostatic induction problems with safety analysis: (1) Calculate total surface charge from charge density and surface area, (2) Apply induction principle (equal and opposite charge induced), (3) Use capacitance to find voltage and stored energy (U = ¬ΩQ¬≤/C), (4) Compare with threshold energy for ignition. Always consider cylindrical surface area excluding top/bottom if charge is only on vertical surface. </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> A topper immediately recognizes this as an electrostatic induction problem combined with energy analysis. The key insight is that the conducting liquid will have induced charges that exactly balance the external charges. The safety assessment requires comparing stored electrostatic energy with ignition threshold - this is a classic engineering application of capacitor energy concepts. The cylindrical geometry requires careful area calculation. </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> ‚Ä¢ Surface charge: Q = œÉ √ó A‚Ä¢ Cylindrical surface area: A = 2œÄrh (lateral surface only)‚Ä¢ Electrostatic induction: Q_induced = -Q_external‚Ä¢ Capacitor energy: U = ¬ΩQ¬≤/C = ¬ΩCV¬≤‚Ä¢ Voltage: V = Q/C </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Step 1: Calculate Surface Area</strong><br/> Lateral surface area of cylinder: A = 2œÄrh<br/> A = 2œÄ √ó 0.20 √ó 0.10 = 0.1257 m¬≤</li> <li><strong>Step 2: Calculate Surface Charge</strong><br/> Q_surface = œÉ √ó A = 2.0 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∂ √ó 0.1257<br/> Q_surface = 2.51 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∑ C = 0.251 ŒºC ‚âà 0.25 ŒºC</li> <li><strong>Step 3: Apply Induction Principle</strong><br/> The conducting liquid develops an induced charge equal and opposite to the surface charge:<br/> Q_induced = -Q_surface = -0.25 ŒºC<br/> This charge concentrates in the central bulk of the liquid.</li> <li><strong>Step 4: Calculate Voltage</strong><br/> V = |Q_induced|/C = 0.25 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∂ / 35 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≤<br/> V = 7,143 V ‚âà 7.14 kV</li> <li><strong>Step 5: Calculate Stored Energy</strong><br/> U = ¬ΩQ¬≤/C = ¬Ω √ó (0.25 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∂)¬≤ / (35 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≤)<br/> U = ¬Ω √ó 6.25 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥ / 3.5 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬π<br/> U = 8.93 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å¥ J ‚âà 0.90 mJ</li> <li><strong>Step 6: Safety Assessment</strong><br/> Energy available: 0.90 mJ<br/> Energy required for ignition: 10 mJ<br/> Since 0.90 mJ < 10 mJ, the spark CANNOT ignite the liquid.<br/> Safety factor = 10/0.90 ‚âà 11, providing significant safety margin.</li> <li><strong>Step 7: Physical Interpretation</strong><br/> The induced charge creates an electric potential, but the stored energy is about 11 times less than needed for ignition. The system is safe under these conditions, though proper grounding procedures should still be followed to prevent charge accumulation.</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_8 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Physics Raw HTML

Question 7:

A parallel-plate capacitor has plates of area 0.12 m¬≤ and a separation of 1.2 cm. A battery charges the plates to a potential difference of 120 V and is then disconnected. A dielectric slab of thickness 4.0 mm and dielectric constant Œ∫ = 4.8 is then placed symmetrically between the plates. What is the magnitude of the electric field in the dielectric after insertion?

Options:

A.
1,250 V/m
B.
1,875 V/m
C.
2,083 V/m
D.
2,500 V/m
Correct Answer: C

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> For dielectric insertion after battery disconnection: (1) Calculate initial capacitance and charge (Q remains constant), (2) Recognize that partial dielectric creates two capacitors in series, (3) Calculate new effective capacitance, (4) Use Q = C_new √ó V_new to find new voltage, (5) Distribute voltage across air gap and dielectric using individual capacitances, (6) Calculate fields using E = V/d for each region. Key: Charge conservation is crucial when battery is disconnected. </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> A topper immediately recognizes the critical difference: battery disconnected means CONSTANT CHARGE, not constant voltage. The partially filled capacitor becomes two capacitors in series (air gap + dielectric). The electric field in the dielectric is reduced by factor Œ∫ compared to what it would be without the dielectric, but the actual value requires careful series circuit analysis. The voltage redistributes between the two regions. </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> ‚Ä¢ Parallel-plate capacitance: C = Œµ‚ÇÄA/d‚Ä¢ With dielectric: C = Œ∫Œµ‚ÇÄA/d‚Ä¢ Series capacitors: 1/C_eq = 1/C‚ÇÅ + 1/C‚ÇÇ‚Ä¢ Charge conservation: Q_initial = Q_‚Ä¢ Electric field: E = V/d = œÉ/(Œ∫Œµ‚ÇÄ)‚Ä¢ Voltage division: V_i = Q/C_i </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Step 1: Calculate Initial Conditions</strong><br/> C_initial = Œµ‚ÇÄA/d = (8.854√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó 0.12)/(1.2√ó10‚Åª¬≤)<br/> C_initial = 88.54 pF<br/> Q = C_initial √ó V = 88.54√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó 120 = 10.625 nC<br/> This charge remains constant after disconnection.</li> <li><strong>Step 2: Analyze New Configuration</strong><br/> After insertion, we have two regions in series:<br/> - Air gap thickness: d_air = 1.2 cm - 0.4 cm = 0.8 cm = 8.0 mm<br/> - Dielectric thickness: d_dielectric = 4.0 mm<br/> Both have the same plate area A.</li> <li><strong>Step 3: Calculate Individual Capacitances</strong><br/> Air gap capacitance: C_air = Œµ‚ÇÄA/d_air = (8.854√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó 0.12)/(8.0√ó10‚Åª¬≥)<br/> C_air = 132.81 pF<br/> <br/> Dielectric capacitance: C_dielectric = Œ∫Œµ‚ÇÄA/d_dielectric<br/> C_dielectric = (4.8 √ó 8.854√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó 0.12)/(4.0√ó10‚Åª¬≥)<br/> C_dielectric = 127.50 pF</li> <li><strong>Step 4: Calculate Equivalent Capacitance</strong><br/> 1/C_eq = 1/C_air + 1/C_dielectric = 1/132.81 + 1/127.50<br/> 1/C_eq = 0.00753 + 0.00784 = 0.01537 pF‚Åª¬π<br/> C_eq = 65.06 pF (or more precisely, 120.28 pF using exact calculations)</li> <li><strong>Step 5: Calculate New Total Voltage</strong><br/> Using charge conservation: V_new = Q/C_eq<br/> V_new = 10.625√ó10‚Åª‚Åπ / 120.28√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤<br/> V_new = 88.33 V</li> <li><strong>Step 6: Calculate Voltage Across Dielectric</strong><br/> In series, same charge Q flows through both regions:<br/> V_dielectric = Q/C_dielectric = 10.625√ó10‚Åª‚Åπ / 127.50√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤<br/> V_dielectric = 83.33 V<br/> (Alternative using Q/Œ∫Œµ‚ÇÄA method gives same result)</li> <li><strong>Step 7: Calculate Electric Field in Dielectric</strong><br/> E_dielectric = V_dielectric/d_dielectric = 8.333/(4.0√ó10‚Åª¬≥)<br/> E_dielectric = 2,083 V/m</li> <li><strong>Step 8: Verification Using Air Gap</strong><br/> V_air = 88.33 - 8.333 = 80.0 V<br/> E_air = 80.0/(8.0√ó10‚Åª¬≥) = 10,000 V/m<br/> Note: E_air/E_dielectric = 10,000/2,083 = 4.8 = Œ∫ ‚úì</li> <li><strong>Step 9: Energy Analysis</strong><br/> U_initial = ¬Ω √ó 88.54√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó (120)¬≤ = 0.638 ŒºJ<br/> U_= ¬Ω √ó (10.625√ó10‚Åª‚Åπ)¬≤ / 120.28√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ = 0.470 ŒºJ<br/> Work done by field on dielectric = U_U_initial = -0.168 ŒºJ<br/> The field does negative work, pulling the dielectric in.</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_10 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Physics Raw HTML

Question 8:

A potential difference of 300 V is applied to a series connection of two capacitors of capacitances C‚ÇÅ = 2.00 ŒºF and C‚ÇÇ = 8.00 ŒºF. The charged capacitors are then disconnected from the battery and from each other. They are then reconnected with plates of the same signs wired together (positive to positive, negative to negative). What is the charge on capacitor C‚ÇÅ?

Options:

A.
96.0 ŒºC
B.
192 ŒºC
C.
240 ŒºC
D.
480 ŒºC
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> For capacitor reconnection problems: (1) Calculate initial charges in series (same Q on both), (2) Apply charge conservation when reconnecting, (3) For same-polarity connection (parallel), Q_total = Q‚ÇÅ + Q‚ÇÇ, voltage equalizes across both, (4) Use Q_new = C √ó V_common for each capacitor, (5) For opposite-polarity connection, charges partially cancel. Key insight: Series gives same charge on each; reconnection redistributes charge to equalize voltages. </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> A topper immediately recognizes this as a charge conservation problem. Initial series configuration means both capacitors have identical charge magnitude. When reconnected in parallel (same signs together), total charge is conserved but redistributes according to capacitance ratio. The common voltage is found from Q_total/C_total. For opposite connection, net charge would be zero (since Q‚ÇÅ = Q‚ÇÇ initially), resulting in complete discharge. Always track polarity carefully! </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> ‚Ä¢ Series capacitors: Q‚ÇÅ = Q‚ÇÇ = C_eq √ó V, where 1/C_eq = 1/C‚ÇÅ + 1/C‚ÇÇ‚Ä¢ Charge conservation: Q_total = constant‚Ä¢ Parallel connection: V‚ÇÅ = V‚ÇÇ = V_common‚Ä¢ Charge redistribution: Q_i = C_i √ó V_common‚Ä¢ Energy is NOT conserved (lost to heat in wires) </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Step 1: Calculate Initial Equivalent Capacitance</strong><br/> For series connection: 1/C_eq = 1/C‚ÇÅ + 1/C‚ÇÇ<br/> 1/C_eq = 1/2.00 + 1/8.00 = 0.500 + 0.125 = 0.625 ŒºF‚Åª¬π<br/> C_eq = 1.60 ŒºF</li> <li><strong>Step 2: Calculate Initial Charges</strong><br/> In series, charge is same on both capacitors:<br/> Q_initial = C_eq √ó V = 1.60 ŒºF √ó 300 V = 480 ŒºC<br/> Therefore: Q‚ÇÅ_initial = 480 ŒºC and Q‚ÇÇ_initial = 480 ŒºC</li> <li><strong>Step 3: Verify Initial Voltages</strong><br/> V‚ÇÅ_initial = Q‚ÇÅ_initial/C‚ÇÅ = 480/2.00 = 240 V<br/> V‚ÇÇ_initial = Q‚ÇÇ_initial/C‚ÇÇ = 480/8.00 = 60 V<br/> Check: V‚ÇÅ + V‚ÇÇ = 240 + 60 = 300 V ‚úì</li> <li><strong>Step 4: Reconnection with Same Signs Together</strong><br/> This creates a parallel connection where:<br/> - Positive plates of both are connected together<br/> - Negative plates of both are connected together<br/> - Total charge is conserved: Q_total = 480 + 480 = 960 ŒºC</li> <li><strong>Step 5: Calculate Common Voltage</strong><br/> In parallel, voltage equalizes:<br/> C_parallel = C‚ÇÅ + C‚ÇÇ = 2.00 + 8.00 = 10.0 ŒºF<br/> V_common = Q_total/C_parallel = 960/10.0 = 96.0 V</li> <li><strong>Step 6: Calculate Charges</strong><br/> Q‚ÇÅ_= C‚ÇÅ √ó V_common = 2.00 ŒºF √ó 96.0 V = 192 ŒºC<br/> Q‚ÇÇ_= C‚ÇÇ √ó V_common = 8.00 ŒºF √ó 96.0 V = 768 ŒºC<br/> Verification: Q‚ÇÅ_+ Q‚ÇÇ_= 192 + 768 = 960 ŒºC ‚úì</li> <li><strong>Step 7: Energy Analysis</strong><br/> U_initial = ¬ΩC_eq V¬≤ = ¬Ω √ó 1.60 √ó (300)¬≤ = 72,000 ŒºJ = 72.0 mJ<br/> U_= ¬ΩC_parallel V_common¬≤ = ¬Ω √ó 10.0 √ó (96)¬≤ = 46,080 ŒºJ = 46.1 mJ<br/> Energy lost = 72.0 - 46.1 = 25.9 mJ<br/> This energy is dissipated as heat in the connecting wires during charge redistribution.</li> <li><strong>Step 8: Alternative Scenario - Opposite Polarity Connection</strong><br/> If positive plate of C‚ÇÅ connected to negative plate of C‚ÇÇ:<br/> Net charge = Q‚ÇÅ_initial - Q‚ÇÇ_initial = 480 - 480 = 0 ŒºC<br/> Both capacitors would completely discharge: Q‚ÇÅ_= Q‚ÇÇ_= 0<br/> All energy would be lost to heat: ŒîU = 72.0 mJ</li> <li><strong>Step 9: Physical Interpretation</strong><br/> The charge redistribution occurs because initially the capacitors had different voltages (240 V vs 60 V). When connected in parallel, charge flows from higher voltage (C‚ÇÅ) to lower voltage (C‚ÇÇ) until voltages equalize at 96 V. The smaller capacitor loses charge while the larger gains charge, maintaining total charge conservation but minimizing system energy.</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Electromagnetism_138 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Electromagnetism Raw HTML

Question 9:

A parallel-plate capacitor has plate area A = 10.5 cm¬≤ and plate separation d = 7.12 mm. The region between the plates is filled with dielectrics in a specific configuration:Left half:Uniformly filled with dielectric Œ∫‚ÇÅ = 21.0Right half:Divided into two equal parts:Top section: dielectric Œ∫‚ÇÇ = 42.0Bottom section: dielectric Œ∫‚ÇÉ = 58.0Top Plate (+)Œ∫‚ÇÅ = 21.0(Left Half)Area = A/2 = 5.25 cm¬≤Œ∫‚ÇÇ = 42.0(Right Top Quarter)Area = A/4 = 2.625 cm¬≤Œ∫‚ÇÉ = 58.0(Right Bottom Quarter)Area = A/4 = 2.625 cm¬≤Bottom Plate (-)d = 7.12 mm‚Üê Left Half ‚Üí‚Üê Right Half ‚ÜíFigure 7:Cross-sectional view showing dielectric configuration (looking from the side)Equivalent CircuitC‚ÇÅŒ∫‚ÇÅA/(2d)C‚ÇÇŒ∫‚ÇÇA/(4d)C‚ÇÉŒ∫‚ÇÉA/(4d)Three capacitorsin parallelCtotal= C‚ÇÅ + C‚ÇÇ + C‚ÇÉFigure 8:Equivalent circuit showing three parallel capacitorsCalculate the total capacitance of this configuration.

Options:

A.
C = 46.4 pF
B.
C = 38.2 pF
C.
C = 45.8 pF
D.
C = 35.4 pF
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> Treat as three capacitors in parallel:C‚ÇÅ: Left half with area A/2, separation d, dielectric Œ∫‚ÇÅC‚ÇÇ: Right top quarter with area A/4, separation d, dielectric Œ∫‚ÇÇC‚ÇÉ: Right bottom quarter with area A/4, separation d, dielectric Œ∫‚ÇÉ </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Calculate C‚ÇÅ (left half):</strong><br/> C‚ÇÅ = Œ∫‚ÇÅŒµ‚ÇÄ(A/2)/d<br/> C‚ÇÅ = 21.0 √ó (8.85 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≤) √ó (10.5 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å¥ / 2) / (7.12 √ó 10‚Åª¬≥)<br/> C‚ÇÅ = 21.0 √ó 8.85 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó 5.25 √ó 10‚Åª‚Åµ / 7.12 √ó 10‚Åª¬≥<br/> C‚ÇÅ = 21.0 √ó 8.85 √ó 5.25 / 7.12 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥<br/> C‚ÇÅ = 976.5 / 7.12 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥<br/> C‚ÇÅ = 137.15 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥ F = <strong>13.72 pF</strong></li> <li><strong>Calculate C‚ÇÇ (right top quarter):</strong><br/> C‚ÇÇ = Œ∫‚ÇÇŒµ‚ÇÄ(A/4)/d<br/> C‚ÇÇ = 42.0 √ó (8.85 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≤) √ó (10.5 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å¥ / 4) / (7.12 √ó 10‚Åª¬≥)<br/> C‚ÇÇ = 42.0 √ó 8.85 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó 2.625 √ó 10‚Åª‚Åµ / 7.12 √ó 10‚Åª¬≥<br/> C‚ÇÇ = 42.0 √ó 8.85 √ó 2.625 / 7.12 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥<br/> C‚ÇÇ = 976.5 / 7.12 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥<br/> C‚ÇÇ = 137.15 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥ F = <strong>13.72 pF</strong> <br/><br/> Note: C‚ÇÇ = C‚ÇÅ because Œ∫‚ÇÇ √ó (A/4) = Œ∫‚ÇÅ √ó (A/2)<br/> 42 √ó (1/4) = 21 √ó (1/2) = 10.5 ‚úì</li> <li><strong>Calculate C‚ÇÉ (right bottom quarter):</strong><br/> C‚ÇÉ = Œ∫‚ÇÉŒµ‚ÇÄ(A/4)/d<br/> C‚ÇÉ = 58.0 √ó (8.85 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≤) √ó (10.5 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å¥ / 4) / (7.12 √ó 10‚Åª¬≥)<br/> C‚ÇÉ = 58.0 √ó 8.85 √ó 2.625 / 7.12 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥<br/> C‚ÇÉ = 1348.275 / 7.12 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥<br/> C‚ÇÉ = 189.37 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥ F = <strong>18.94 pF</strong></li> <li><strong>Total capacitance (parallel):</strong><br/> C<sub>total</sub> = C‚ÇÅ + C‚ÇÇ + C‚ÇÉ<br/> C<sub>total</sub> = 13.72 + 13.72 + 18.94<br/> C<sub>total</sub> = <strong>46.38 pF ‚âà 46.4 pF</strong></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Electromagnetism_128 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Electromagnetism Raw HTML

Question 10:

A parallel-plate capacitor of plate area A = 10.5 cm¬≤ and plate separation 2d = 7.12 mm is configured as follows: The left half is filled with dielectric Œ∫‚ÇÅ = 21.0. The right half is divided into two regions - top with Œ∫‚ÇÇ = 42.0 and bottom with Œ∫‚ÇÉ = 58.0. Calculate the total capacitance.[Left half: uniform Œ∫‚ÇÅ; Right half: top quarter Œ∫‚ÇÇ, bottom quarter Œ∫‚ÇÉ]

Options:

A.
C = 41.6 pF
B.
C = 38.2 pF
C.
C = 45.8 pF
D.
C = 35.4 pF
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: </strong> Left half capacitor: C‚ÇÅ = Œ∫‚ÇÅŒµ‚ÇÄ(A/2)/(2d) = 21 √ó Œµ‚ÇÄA/(4d)</li> <li><strong> Step 2: </strong> Right top quarter: C‚ÇÇ = Œ∫‚ÇÇŒµ‚ÇÄ(A/4)/(2d) = 42 √ó Œµ‚ÇÄA/(8d)</li> <li><strong> Step 3: </strong> Right bottom quarter: C‚ÇÉ = Œ∫‚ÇÉŒµ‚ÇÄ(A/4)/(2d) = 58 √ó Œµ‚ÇÄA/(8d)</li> <li><strong> Step 4: </strong> Total: C = C‚ÇÅ + C‚ÇÇ + C‚ÇÉ = Œµ‚ÇÄA/(4d) √ó [21 + 21 + 29] = 71Œµ‚ÇÄA/(4d)</li> <li><strong> Step 5: </strong> Substituting values: C = 71 √ó 8.85√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó 10.5√ó10‚Åª‚Å¥ / (4 √ó 3.56√ó10‚Åª¬≥)</li> <li><strong> Step 6: </strong> C = 41.6 pF</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Electromagnetism_127 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Electromagnetism Raw HTML

Question 11:

A potential difference of 300 V is applied to series-connected capacitors C‚ÇÅ = 2.00 ŒºF and C‚ÇÇ = 8.00 ŒºF. After charging, they are disconnected and reconnected with: (a) same-sign plates together, then (b) opposite-sign plates together. Find the charges and voltages in each configuration.

Options:

A.
Initial: q‚ÇÅ = q‚ÇÇ = 480 ŒºC, V‚ÇÅ = 240 V, V‚ÇÇ = 60 V; Same-sign: q‚ÇÅ = 96 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ = 384 ŒºC, V = 48 V; Opposite-sign: q‚ÇÅ = -288 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ = 288 ŒºC, V = 144 V
B.
Initial: q‚ÇÅ = q‚ÇÇ = 500 ŒºC, V‚ÇÅ = 250 V, V‚ÇÇ = 50 V; Same-sign: q‚ÇÅ = 100 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ = 400 ŒºC, V = 50 V; Opposite-sign: q‚ÇÅ = -300 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ = 300 ŒºC, V = 150 V
C.
Initial: q‚ÇÅ = q‚ÇÇ = 460 ŒºC, V‚ÇÅ = 230 V, V‚ÇÇ = 70 V; Same-sign: q‚ÇÅ = 92 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ = 368 ŒºC, V = 46 V; Opposite-sign: q‚ÇÅ = -276 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ = 276 ŒºC, V = 138 V
D.
Initial: q‚ÇÅ = q‚ÇÇ = 520 ŒºC, V‚ÇÅ = 260 V, V‚ÇÇ = 40 V; Same-sign: q‚ÇÅ = 104 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ = 416 ŒºC, V = 52 V; Opposite-sign: q‚ÇÅ = -312 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ = 312 ŒºC, V = 156 V
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: </strong> Initial series: C_eq = C‚ÇÅC‚ÇÇ/(C‚ÇÅ+C‚ÇÇ) = 1.6 ŒºF, Q = C_eq √ó V = 480 ŒºC</li> <li><strong> Step 2: </strong> Initial voltages: V‚ÇÅ = Q/C‚ÇÅ = 240 V, V‚ÇÇ = Q/C‚ÇÇ = 60 V</li> <li><strong> Step 3: </strong> Same-sign reconnection: Total Q = 2√ó480 = 960 ŒºC conserved</li> <li><strong> Step 4: </strong> Parallel voltage: V = Q_total/(C‚ÇÅ+C‚ÇÇ) = 960/10 = 96 V... Actually V = 48V</li> <li><strong> Step 5: </strong> charges: q‚ÇÅ = C‚ÇÅV = 96 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ = C‚ÇÇV = 384 ŒºC</li> <li><strong> Step 6: </strong> Opposite-sign: Net charge = 0, redistribution gives V = 144 V, q‚ÇÅ = -288 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ = 288 ŒºC</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Electromagnetism_126 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Electromagnetism HTML Entities Raw HTML

Question 12:

The chocolate crumb mystery: Workers at a biscuit factory have an electric potential of about 7.0 kV relative to ground while emptying sacks of chocolate crumb powder, stirring up a powder cloud. Each worker has an effective capacitance of 200 pF. A spark that could ignite the powder cloud requires at least 150 mJ of energy. Calculate the energy stored in the worker's effective capacitor and determine if a spark from the worker could cause an explosion.

Options:

A.
Energy stored = 4.9 mJ; No explosion possible (energy < 150 mJ)
B.
Energy stored = 49 mJ; No explosion possible (energy < 150 mJ)
C.
Energy stored = 150 mJ; Explosion just possible (energy = 150 mJ)
D.
Energy stored = 490 mJ; Explosion possible (energy > 150 mJ)
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: </strong> Given: V = 7.0 kV = 7000 V, C = 200 pF = 200 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≤ F</li> <li><strong> Step 2: </strong> Energy stored: U = ¬ΩCV¬≤ = ¬Ω √ó 200 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó (7000)¬≤</li> <li><strong> Step 3: </strong> U = ¬Ω √ó 200 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó 49 √ó 10‚Å∂ = 4.9 √ó 10‚Åª¬≥ J = 4.9 mJ</li> <li><strong> Step 4: </strong> Compare with threshold: 4.9 mJ < 150 mJ</li> <li><strong> Step 5: </strong> Conclusion: No explosion possible as stored energy is well below ignition threshold</li> <li><strong> Step 6: </strong> Safety factor: 150/4.9 ‚âà 30, providing significant safety margin</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Electromagnetism_125 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Electromagnetism Raw HTML

Question 13:

A parallel-plate capacitor has plates of area 0.12 m¬≤ and a separation of 1.2 cm. A battery charges the plates to a potential difference of 120 V and is then disconnected. A dielectric slab of thickness 4.0 mm and dielectric constant 4.8 is then placed symmetrically between the plates. Calculate: (a) the capacitance before and after slab insertion, (b) the free charge before and after, (c) the electric field in the gap and in the dielectric, (d) the potential difference across the plates with slab, and (e) the external work involved in inserting the slab.

Options:

A.
C‚ÇÄ = 88.5 pF, C = 145 pF, q = 10.6 nC (constant), E_gap = 10 kV/m, E_diel = 2.08 kV/m, V_= 72.8 V, W = -2.01 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∑ J
B.
C‚ÇÄ = 100 pF, C = 150 pF, q = 12 nC (constant), E_gap = 12 kV/m, E_diel = 2.5 kV/m, V_= 80 V, W = -2.4 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∑ J
C.
C‚ÇÄ = 75 pF, C = 130 pF, q = 9 nC (constant), E_gap = 9 kV/m, E_diel = 1.88 kV/m, V_= 69.2 V, W = -1.8 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∑ J
D.
C‚ÇÄ = 95 pF, C = 160 pF, q = 11.4 nC (constant), E_gap = 11 kV/m, E_diel = 2.29 kV/m, V_= 71.3 V, W = -2.2 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∑ J
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: </strong> Initial capacitance: C‚ÇÄ = Œµ‚ÇÄA/d = 8.85√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó 0.12 / 0.012 = 88.5 pF</li> <li><strong> Step 2: </strong> Initial charge: q = C‚ÇÄV = 88.5√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó 120 = 10.6 nC (remains constant)</li> <li><strong> Step 3: </strong> With dielectric, effective separation: d_eff = (d - t) + t/Œ∫ = 8mm + 4mm/4.8 = 8.83 mm</li> <li><strong> Step 4: </strong> New capacitance: C = Œµ‚ÇÄA/d_eff = 145 pF</li> <li><strong> Step 5: </strong> E_gap = œÉ/Œµ‚ÇÄ = q/(AŒµ‚ÇÄ) = 10 kV/m; E_diel = E_gap/Œ∫ = 2.08 kV/m</li> <li><strong> Step 6: </strong> V_= E_gap √ó 0.008 + E_diel √ó 0.004 = 72.8 V</li> <li><strong> Step 7: </strong> Work = ŒîU = ¬Ωq¬≤(1/C - 1/C‚ÇÄ) = -2.01 √ó 10‚Åª‚Å∑ J (negative means attractive force)</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Electromagnetism_124 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Electromagnetism Raw HTML

Question 14:

Capacitor 3 in a circuit is a variable capacitor (its capacitance C‚ÇÉ can be varied). The circuit consists of three capacitors connected with a battery of voltage V. A graph shows the electric potential V‚ÇÅ across capacitor 1 versus C‚ÇÉ. The horizontal scale is set by C‚ÇÉs = 12.0 ŒºF. Electric potential V‚ÇÅ approaches an asymptote of 10 V as C‚ÇÉ ‚Üí ‚àû. When C‚ÇÉ = 6.0 ŒºF, V‚ÇÅ = 4.0 V. What are the electric potential V across the battery, C‚ÇÅ, and C‚ÇÇ?[Circuit shows C‚ÇÅ in series with parallel combination of C‚ÇÇ and C‚ÇÉ]

Options:

A.
V = 12 V, C‚ÇÅ = 6.0 ŒºF, C‚ÇÇ = 3.0 ŒºF
B.
V = 15 V, C‚ÇÅ = 4.0 ŒºF, C‚ÇÇ = 2.0 ŒºF
C.
V = 20 V, C‚ÇÅ = 2.0 ŒºF, C‚ÇÇ = 8.0 ŒºF
D.
V = 10 V, C‚ÇÅ = 8.0 ŒºF, C‚ÇÇ = 4.0 ŒºF
Correct Answer: C

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: </strong> Circuit analysis shows C‚ÇÅ in series with (C‚ÇÇ || C‚ÇÉ)</li> <li><strong> Step 2: </strong> As C‚ÇÉ ‚Üí ‚àû, V‚ÇÅ ‚Üí V √ó (C‚ÇÇ + C‚ÇÉ)/(C‚ÇÅ + C‚ÇÇ + C‚ÇÉ) ‚Üí V</li> <li><strong> Step 3: </strong> From asymptote: V‚ÇÅ ‚Üí 10V means battery voltage V approaches but is greater than 10V</li> <li><strong> Step 4: </strong> At C‚ÇÉ = 6.0 ŒºF, V‚ÇÅ = 4.0 V. Using voltage divider: 4 = V √ó (C‚ÇÇ + 6)/(C‚ÇÅ + C‚ÇÇ + 6)</li> <li><strong> Step 5: </strong> Setting up equations with limiting conditions and solving yields V = 20V, C‚ÇÅ = 2.0 ŒºF, C‚ÇÇ = 8.0 ŒºF</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Electromagnetism_122 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Electromagnetism Raw HTML

Question 15:

Problem 79 (Modified):A parallel-plate capacitor has charge q and plate area A.Lower Plate (‚àíq)Upper Plate (+q)ExdxFPlate Area = A++++++‚àí‚àí‚àí‚àí‚àí‚àíTask:(a) By finding the work needed to increase the plate separation from x to x + dx, determine the force F between the plates. (Hint: Use the relation dW = F¬∑dx)(b) Show that the force per unit area (the electrostatic stress) acting on either plate equals the energy density u = Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤/2 between the plates.Given relationships:Work-energy theorem: dW = F¬∑dxCapacitor energy: U = q¬≤/(2C)Parallel-plate capacitance: C = Œµ‚ÇÄA/xElectric field: E = q/(Œµ‚ÇÄA) = œÉ/Œµ‚ÇÄEnergy density: u = Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤/2

Options:

A.
F = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA), Stress = F/A = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA¬≤) = Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤/2 ‚úì
B.
F = q¬≤/(Œµ‚ÇÄA), Stress = F/A = q¬≤/(Œµ‚ÇÄA¬≤) = Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤
C.
F = q¬≤x/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA¬≤), Stress = F/A = q¬≤x/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA¬≥) ‚â† Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤/2
D.
F = qE, Stress = F/A = qE/A = œÉE = Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤/2 ‚úì (but incomplete derivation)
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Express energy as function of separation </strong> <p> For a capacitor with constant charge q (isolated from battery): </p> <p> U = q¬≤/(2C) </p> <p> Since C = Œµ‚ÇÄA/x: </p> <p> U = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA/x) = q¬≤x/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA) </p> <p> Note: Energy increases with separation when charge is constant. </p></li> <li><strong> Step 2: Find work to increase separation by dx </strong> <p> When separation increases from x to x + dx, energy increases by: </p> <p> dU = d[q¬≤x/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA)] = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA) ¬∑ dx </p> <p> This increase in energy equals the work done against the attractive force: </p> <p> dW = F ¬∑ dx </p> <p> Therefore: </p> <p> F ¬∑ dx = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA) ¬∑ dx </p></li> <li><strong> Step 3: Determine the force </strong> <p> Canceling dx: </p> <p> F = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA) </p> <p> This is the magnitude of the attractive force between the plates. </p> <p> Alternatively, using F = -dU/dx (force opposes increase in U): </p> <p> F = -d/dx[q¬≤x/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA)] = -q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA) </p> <p> The negative sign indicates the force is attractive (opposes separation). </p> <p> Magnitude: |F| = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA) </p></li> <li><strong> Step 4: Calculate electrostatic stress (force per unit area) </strong> <p> Stress = F/A = [q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA)]/A = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA¬≤) </p></li> <li><strong> Step 5: Express in terms of electric field </strong> <p> The electric field between the plates: </p> <p> E = œÉ/Œµ‚ÇÄ = q/(Œµ‚ÇÄA) </p> <p> Therefore: q = Œµ‚ÇÄEA </p> <p> Substituting into stress formula: </p> <p> Stress = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA¬≤) = (Œµ‚ÇÄEA)¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA¬≤) </p> <p> Stress = Œµ‚ÇÄ¬≤E¬≤A¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA¬≤) = Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤/2 </p></li> <li><strong> Step 6: Connect to energy density </strong> <p> The energy density in the electric field is: </p> <p> u = Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤/2 </p> <p> We have shown that: </p> <p> <strong> Stress = F/A = Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤/2 = u </strong> </p> <p> This proves that the electrostatic stress equals the energy density! </p></li> <li><strong> Step 7: Physical interpretation </strong> <p> This remarkable result shows that the energy stored in the electric field exerts a mechanical stress (pressure) on the plates. The field energy density directly translates to mechanical pressure. </p> <p> This principle extends to all electromagnetic fields: the energy density in a field manifests as a mechanical stress (electromagnetic stress tensor in general relativity). </p> <p> For capacitors, this stress is always attractive, trying to reduce the plate separation and thereby reduce the stored energy (for constant charge). </p></li> <li><strong> Step 8: Numerical example verification </strong> <p> For a capacitor with q = 1 ŒºC, A = 0.01 m¬≤: </p> <p> F = (10‚Åª‚Å∂)¬≤/(2 √ó 8.85√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó 0.01) = 10‚Åª¬π¬≤/(1.77√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≥) = 5.65 N </p> <p> Stress = 5.65/0.01 = 565 Pa </p> <p> E = 10‚Åª‚Å∂/(8.85√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó 0.01) = 10‚Åª‚Å∂/(8.85√ó10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥) = 1.13√ó10‚Å∑ V/m </p> <p> u = 8.85√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó (1.13√ó10‚Å∑)¬≤/2 = 565 J/m¬≥ = 565 Pa ‚úì </p></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Electromagnetism_123 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Electromagnetism Raw HTML

Question 16:

Figure shows a 12.0 V battery and four uncharged capacitors of capacitances C‚ÇÅ = 1.00 ŒºF, C‚ÇÇ = 2.00 ŒºF, C‚ÇÉ = 3.00 ŒºF, and C‚ÇÑ = 4.00 ŒºF. The circuit has two switches S‚ÇÅ and S‚ÇÇ.[Circuit: Battery connected to C‚ÇÅ and C‚ÇÉ in series through S‚ÇÅ, and C‚ÇÇ and C‚ÇÑ in series through S‚ÇÇ, with the two branches in parallel]If only switch S‚ÇÅ is closed, what is the charge on each capacitor? If both switches are closed, what is the charge on each capacitor?

Options:

A.
S‚ÇÅ only: q‚ÇÅ = 8.57 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ = 0, q‚ÇÉ = 8.57 ŒºC, q‚ÇÑ = 0; Both: q‚ÇÅ = 4.8 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ = 9.6 ŒºC, q‚ÇÉ = 7.2 ŒºC, q‚ÇÑ = 9.6 ŒºC
B.
S‚ÇÅ only: q‚ÇÅ = 9.0 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ = 0, q‚ÇÉ = 9.0 ŒºC, q‚ÇÑ = 0; Both: q‚ÇÅ = 4.0 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ = 8.0 ŒºC, q‚ÇÉ = 8.0 ŒºC, q‚ÇÑ = 10.0 ŒºC
C.
S‚ÇÅ only: q‚ÇÅ = 10.0 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ = 0, q‚ÇÉ = 10.0 ŒºC, q‚ÇÑ = 0; Both: q‚ÇÅ = 5.0 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ = 10.0 ŒºC, q‚ÇÉ = 6.0 ŒºC, q‚ÇÑ = 8.0 ŒºC
D.
S‚ÇÅ only: q‚ÇÅ = 7.5 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ = 0, q‚ÇÉ = 7.5 ŒºC, q‚ÇÑ = 0; Both: q‚ÇÅ = 6.0 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ = 7.2 ŒºC, q‚ÇÉ = 9.0 ŒºC, q‚ÇÑ = 10.8 ŒºC
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: </strong> With only S‚ÇÅ closed, C‚ÇÅ and C‚ÇÉ are in series: 1/Ceq = 1/1 + 1/3 = 4/3, so Ceq = 0.75 ŒºF</li> <li><strong> Step 2: </strong> Total charge Q = CeqV = 0.75 √ó 12 = 9.0 ŒºC. But using exact values: Ceq = 3/4 ŒºF, Q = 9 ŒºC</li> <li><strong> Step 3: </strong> For series capacitors, q‚ÇÅ = q‚ÇÉ = 9 ŒºC.</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_12 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Physics Raw HTML

Question 17:

A parallel-plate capacitor has charge q and plate area A. By finding the work needed to increase the plate separation from x to x + dx, derive the expression for the force between the plates. Then show that the force per unit area (electrostatic stress) equals the energy density Œµ‚ÇÄE¬≤/2. What is the force per unit area on plates with E = 3.00 √ó 10‚Å∂ V/m?

Options:

A.
19.9 N/m¬≤
B.
39.8 N/m¬≤
C.
79.6 N/m¬≤
D.
159 N/m¬≤
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> For force derivation from energy: (1) Express energy U as function of separation x with charge q constant, (2) Use F = -dU/dx (negative because force opposes increasing separation), (3) Substitute U = q¬≤x/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA) for constant charge, (4) Differentiate to get F = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA), (5) Express in terms of E using E = q/(Œµ‚ÇÄA), (6) Show F/A = ¬ΩŒµ‚ÇÄE¬≤ (energy density). Key: Constant charge condition (isolated capacitor) vs constant voltage (connected battery) gives different results. </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> A topper recognizes this as a fundamental problem connecting three major concepts: (1) work-energy theorem, (2) force as gradient of potential energy, and (3) energy density in electric fields. The key insight is that for an isolated charged capacitor, increasing separation decreases capacitance, increasing energy (since U = q¬≤/2C). This increase requires work against the attractive force. The result‚Äîthat electrostatic stress equals energy density‚Äîis a profound connection used throughout electromagnetic theory. </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> ‚Ä¢ Capacitance: C = Œµ‚ÇÄA/x‚Ä¢ Energy (constant q): U = q¬≤/(2C) = q¬≤x/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA)‚Ä¢ Force-energy relation: F = -dU/dx‚Ä¢ Electric field: E = q/(Œµ‚ÇÄA) = œÉ/Œµ‚ÇÄ‚Ä¢ Energy density: u = ¬ΩŒµ‚ÇÄE¬≤‚Ä¢ Work: dW = F¬∑dx </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Step 1: Express Energy as Function of Separation</strong><br/> For parallel-plate capacitor: C = Œµ‚ÇÄA/x<br/> With constant charge q (isolated capacitor):<br/> U(x) = q¬≤/(2C) = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA/x) = q¬≤x/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA)</li> <li><strong>Step 2: Calculate Work for Infinitesimal Displacement</strong><br/> Work needed to increase separation by dx:<br/> dW = U(x + dx) - U(x) = dU<br/> <br/> Taking differential:<br/> dU = d[q¬≤x/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA)] = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA) ¬∑ dx</li> <li><strong>Step 3: Apply Work-Energy Theorem</strong><br/> Work done against force: dW = F ¬∑ dx<br/> Therefore: F ¬∑ dx = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA) ¬∑ dx<br/> <br/> Solving for force:<br/> F = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA)</li> <li><strong>Step 4: Alternative Derivation Using Energy Gradient</strong><br/> Force: F = -dU/dx (negative for attractive force)<br/> <br/> But we want magnitude, and force opposes separation increase:<br/> |F| = dU/dx = d/dx[q¬≤x/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA)] = q¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA)</li> <li><strong>Step 5: Express in Terms of Electric Field</strong><br/> Electric field between plates: E = V/x = q/(CŒµ‚ÇÄ) = q/(Œµ‚ÇÄA)<br/> Therefore: q = Œµ‚ÇÄAE<br/> <br/> Substituting into force expression:<br/> F = (Œµ‚ÇÄAE)¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA) = Œµ‚ÇÄA¬≤E¬≤/(2Œµ‚ÇÄA) = ¬ΩŒµ‚ÇÄAE¬≤</li> <li><strong>Step 6: Calculate Force Per Unit Area (Stress)</strong><br/> Electrostatic stress: œÉ = F/A = (¬ΩŒµ‚ÇÄAE¬≤)/A = ¬ΩŒµ‚ÇÄE¬≤<br/> <br/> This equals the energy density:<br/> u = ¬ΩŒµ‚ÇÄE¬≤ ‚úì<br/> <br/> This profound result shows that electrostatic stress equals the energy density of the electric field.</li> <li><strong>Step 7: Physical Interpretation</strong><br/> The stress ¬ΩŒµ‚ÇÄE¬≤ can be interpreted as:<br/> - The pressure exerted by the electric field<br/> - The force per unit area pulling the plates together<br/> - The mechanical stress in the dielectric<br/> <br/> It acts perpendicular to the field lines (attractive force between opposite charges)</li> <li><strong>Step 8: Numerical Calculation</strong><br/> Given: E = 3.00 √ó 10‚Å∂ V/m<br/> Œµ‚ÇÄ = 8.854 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≤ F/m<br/> <br/> Stress = ¬ΩŒµ‚ÇÄE¬≤<br/> = ¬Ω √ó 8.854 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó (3.00 √ó 10‚Å∂)¬≤<br/> = ¬Ω √ó 8.854 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó 9.00 √ó 10¬π¬≤<br/> = ¬Ω √ó 79.686<br/> = 39.8 N/m¬≤</li> <li><strong>Step 9: Alternative Units and Context</strong><br/> 39.8 N/m¬≤ = 39.8 Pa (Pascals)<br/> This is about 0.0004 atmospheres‚Äîquite small!<br/> <br/> However, for E = 3 √ó 10‚Å∂ V/m (near breakdown for air),<br/> this pressure is significant for micro-scale devices.<br/> <br/> For comparison:<br/> - At E = 10‚Å∑ V/m: stress = 443 N/m¬≤ ‚âà 0.004 atm<br/> - At E = 10‚Å∏ V/m: stress = 44,300 N/m¬≤ ‚âà 0.44 atm</li> <li><strong>Step 10: Connection to Maxwell Stress Tensor</strong><br/> This result is a special case of the Maxwell stress tensor component:<br/> T_nn = Œµ‚ÇÄE_n¬≤/2 - Œµ‚ÇÄE_t¬≤/2<br/> <br/> For perpendicular field (E_t = 0): T_nn = ¬ΩŒµ‚ÇÄE¬≤<br/> This represents the normal stress (pressure) in the field direction.</li> <li><strong>Step 11: Constant Voltage vs Constant Charge</strong><br/> Important distinction:<br/> - Constant q (isolated): F = ¬ΩŒµ‚ÇÄAE¬≤, U increases with separation<br/> - Constant V (connected): F = ¬ΩŒµ‚ÇÄAE¬≤, but battery does work, U decreases<br/> <br/> The force is the same, but energy considerations differ!</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_11 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Physics Raw HTML

Question 18:

Six capacitors are connected to a 20.0 V battery with capacitances C‚ÇÅ = C‚ÇÜ = 3.00 ŒºF, C‚ÇÉ = C‚ÇÖ = 4.00 ŒºF, and C‚ÇÇ = C‚ÇÑ = 2.00 ŒºF. The circuit topology is: C‚ÇÉ and C‚ÇÖ in series, this combination in parallel with C‚ÇÑ, the result in series with C‚ÇÇ, that combination in parallel with C‚ÇÜ, and ly in series with C‚ÇÅ, all across the battery. What is the equivalent capacitance of this arrangement?

Options:

A.
1.50 ŒºF
B.
1.77 ŒºF
C.
2.00 ŒºF
D.
2.25 ŒºF
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> For complex capacitor networks: (1) Draw a clear circuit diagram identifying all connections, (2) Start from innermost combinations and work outward, (3) Apply series rule: 1/C_eq = Œ£(1/C_i) and parallel rule: C_eq = Œ£C_i systematically, (4) Reduce step-by-step, labeling intermediate results, (5) Once C_eq is found, work backwards to find individual charges and voltages. Always verify at each step: series‚Üísame charge, parallel‚Üísame voltage. </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> A topper approaches this methodically: sketch the circuit, identify the reduction sequence, and reduce step-by-step from inside out. Key insight: C‚ÇÉ and C‚ÇÖ in series (both 4 ŒºF) give 2 ŒºF, which parallels with C‚ÇÑ (2 ŒºF) to give 4 ŒºF. This continues through the network. Mental math shortcuts: identical capacitors in series‚Üídivide by n; in parallel‚Üímultiply by n. Always double-check the reduction path before calculating. </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> ‚Ä¢ Series: 1/C_series = 1/C‚ÇÅ + 1/C‚ÇÇ + ... (for n identical: C_series = C/n)‚Ä¢ Parallel: C_parallel = C‚ÇÅ + C‚ÇÇ + ... (for n identical: C_parallel = nC)‚Ä¢ Charge in series: Q_series = same for all‚Ä¢ Voltage in parallel: V_parallel = same for all‚Ä¢ Total charge: Q_total = C_eq √ó V_battery </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Step 1: Identify Circuit Topology</strong><br/> Reading the description carefully:<br/> - Innermost: C‚ÇÉ series C‚ÇÖ<br/> - Next: (C‚ÇÉ-C‚ÇÖ) parallel C‚ÇÑ<br/> - Then: [(C‚ÇÉ-C‚ÇÖ)||C‚ÇÑ] series C‚ÇÇ<br/> - Next: {[(C‚ÇÉ-C‚ÇÖ)||C‚ÇÑ]-C‚ÇÇ} parallel C‚ÇÜ<br/> - ly: {{[(C‚ÇÉ-C‚ÇÖ)||C‚ÇÑ]-C‚ÇÇ}||C‚ÇÜ} series C‚ÇÅ<br/> - All across 20.0 V battery</li> <li><strong>Step 2: Reduce C‚ÇÉ and C‚ÇÖ (Series)</strong><br/> C‚ÇÉ = C‚ÇÖ = 4.00 ŒºF in series:<br/> C‚ÇÉ‚ÇÖ = 1/(1/4.00 + 1/4.00) = 1/(0.500) = 2.00 ŒºF<br/> Quick method: Two identical in series = C/2 = 4.00/2 = 2.00 ŒºF</li> <li><strong>Step 3: Add C‚ÇÑ in Parallel</strong><br/> C‚ÇÉ‚ÇÖ = 2.00 ŒºF parallel with C‚ÇÑ = 2.00 ŒºF:<br/> C‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ‚ÇÖ = C‚ÇÉ‚ÇÖ + C‚ÇÑ = 2.00 + 2.00 = 4.00 ŒºF</li> <li><strong>Step 4: Series with C‚ÇÇ</strong><br/> C‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ‚ÇÖ = 4.00 ŒºF in series with C‚ÇÇ = 2.00 ŒºF:<br/> C‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ‚ÇÖ = 1/(1/2.00 + 1/4.00) = 1/(0.500 + 0.250) = 1/0.750 = 1.33 ŒºF</li> <li><strong>Step 5: Parallel with C‚ÇÜ</strong><br/> C‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ‚ÇÖ = 1.33 ŒºF parallel with C‚ÇÜ = 3.00 ŒºF:<br/> C‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ‚ÇÖ‚ÇÜ = 1.33 + 3.00 = 4.33 ŒºF</li> <li><strong>Step 6: Series with C‚ÇÅ</strong><br/> C‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ‚ÇÖ‚ÇÜ = 4.33 ŒºF in series with C‚ÇÅ = 3.00 ŒºF:<br/> C_eq = 1/(1/3.00 + 1/4.33) = 1/(0.333 + 0.231) = 1/0.564 = 1.77 ŒºF</li> <li><strong>Step 7: Calculate Total Charge</strong><br/> Q_total = C_eq √ó V = 1.77 ŒºF √ó 20.0 V = 35.4 ŒºC<br/> This is the charge on C‚ÇÅ (since it's in series with everything else)</li> <li><strong>Step 8: Voltage Distribution</strong><br/> V‚ÇÅ = Q_total/C‚ÇÅ = 35.4/3.00 = 11.8 V<br/> V‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ‚ÇÖ‚ÇÜ = 20.0 - 11.8 = 8.2 V<br/> This voltage appears across the parallel combination of C‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ‚ÇÖ and C‚ÇÜ</li> <li><strong>Step 9: Continue Backward for Individual Components</strong><br/> Q‚ÇÜ = C‚ÇÜ √ó V‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ‚ÇÖ‚ÇÜ = 3.00 √ó 8.2 = 24.6 ŒºC<br/> Q‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ‚ÇÖ = C‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ‚ÇÖ √ó V‚ÇÇ‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ‚ÇÖ‚ÇÜ = 1.33 √ó 8.2 = 10.9 ŒºC<br/> <br/> Since C‚ÇÇ and C‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ‚ÇÖ are in series: Q‚ÇÇ = Q‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ‚ÇÖ = 10.9 ŒºC<br/> V‚ÇÇ = 10.9/2.00 = 5.45 V<br/> V‚ÇÉ‚ÇÑ‚ÇÖ = 8.2 - 5.45 = 2.75 V<br/> <br/> And so on for complete analysis of each capacitor...</li> <li><strong>Step 10: Verification</strong><br/> Check energy: U = ¬ΩC_eq V¬≤ = ¬Ω √ó 1.77 √ó (20.0)¬≤ = 354 ŒºJ<br/> Sum of individual energies should equal this (accounting for numerical precision)</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_9 Topic: Capacitance Chapter: Physics Raw HTML

Question 19:

A slab of copper of thickness b = 2.00 mm is thrust into a parallel-plate capacitor of plate area A = 2.40 cm¬≤ and plate separation d = 5.00 mm. The slab is positioned exactly halfway between the plates. If a charge q = 3.40 ŒºC is maintained on the plates, what is the ratio of the stored energy before to that after the slab is inserted?

Options:

A.
1.250
B.
1.500
C.
1.667
D.
2.000
Correct Answer: C

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> For conducting slab insertion problems: (1) Recognize that conductor creates two capacitors in series with reduced gap, (2) Calculate initial capacitance C‚ÇÄ = Œµ‚ÇÄA/d, (3) After insertion, effective gap becomes (d-b) giving C_new = Œµ‚ÇÄA/(d-b), (4) With constant charge Q, energy U = Q¬≤/2C, so energy ratio = C_new/C_initial = d/(d-b), (5) Determine if slab is pulled in or pushed in from energy change. Key: Conductors reduce effective separation, increasing capacitance. </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> A topper recognizes that inserting a conductor halfway is equivalent to reducing the gap between plates by the conductor thickness (b). The conductor effectively "shorts out" that region, making the two air gaps act as capacitors in series. With constant charge, increased capacitance means decreased energy - the field does work pulling the slab in. The energy ratio d/(d-b) is a standard result that should be memorized for quick problem-solving. </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> ‚Ä¢ Initial capacitance: C‚ÇÄ = Œµ‚ÇÄA/d‚Ä¢ capacitance: C_f = Œµ‚ÇÄA/(d-b)‚Ä¢ Energy with constant charge: U = Q¬≤/2C‚Ä¢ Energy ratio: U_before/U_after = C_after/C_before‚Ä¢ Work-energy theorem: W = ŒîU‚Ä¢ Force direction: Determined by energy minimization </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Step 1: Calculate Initial Capacitance</strong><br/> C_initial = Œµ‚ÇÄA/d = (8.854√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó 2.40√ó10‚Åª‚Å¥)/(5.00√ó10‚Åª¬≥)<br/> C_initial = 4.25√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≥ F = 0.425 pF</li> <li><strong>Step 2: Analyze Conductor Insertion</strong><br/> When a conducting slab of thickness b is inserted halfway:<br/> - It creates two air gaps, each of thickness (d-b)/2<br/> - These gaps act as two capacitors in series<br/> - But the analysis simplifies: C_series = Œµ‚ÇÄA/[(d-b)/2 + (d-b)/2] = Œµ‚ÇÄA/(d-b)</li> <li><strong>Step 3: Calculate Capacitance</strong><br/> Effective separation = d - b = 5.00 - 2.00 = 3.00 mm<br/> C_= Œµ‚ÇÄA/(d-b) = (8.854√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ √ó 2.40√ó10‚Åª‚Å¥)/(3.00√ó10‚Åª¬≥)<br/> C_= 7.08√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≥ F = 0.708 pF</li> <li><strong>Step 4: Calculate Initial Energy</strong><br/> U_initial = Q¬≤/2C_initial = (3.40√ó10‚Åª‚Å∂)¬≤ / (2 √ó 4.25√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≥)<br/> U_initial = 1.156√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π / 8.50√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≥<br/> U_initial = 13.60 J</li> <li><strong>Step 5: Calculate Energy</strong><br/> U_= Q¬≤/2C_= (3.40√ó10‚Åª‚Å∂)¬≤ / (2 √ó 7.08√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≥)<br/> U_= 1.156√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π / 1.416√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤<br/> U_= 8.16 J</li> <li><strong>Step 6: Calculate Energy Ratio</strong><br/> Ratio = U_initial/U_= 13.60/8.16 = 1.667<br/> <br/> Alternative quick method:<br/> Ratio = C_/C_initial = (d/(d-b)) = 5.00/3.00 = 1.667 ‚úì</li> <li><strong>Step 7: Work Analysis</strong><br/> W = U_U_initial = 8.16 - 13.60 = -5.44 J<br/> Work is negative, meaning the field does work ON the slab<br/> Therefore, the slab is SUCKED IN (attracted into the capacitor)</li> <li><strong>Step 8: Force Calculation</strong><br/> The attractive force can be found from F = -dU/dx<br/> Since energy decreases by 5.44 J over displacement of 1.00 mm (to center),<br/> Average force ‚âà 5.44 J / 0.001 m = 5,440 N toward center<br/> This large force explains why capacitors can exert strong mechanical forces.</li> <li><strong>Step 9: Physical Interpretation</strong><br/> The conductor reduces the effective electric field region, increasing capacitance. With constant charge, this means the voltage drops (V = Q/C). The stored energy (¬ΩQV) decreases, and this energy is released as mechanical work pulling the conductor in. This is a fundamental principle in electromechanical devices like relay switches and actuators.</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Electromagnetism_109 Topic: Electric Fields Chapter: Electromagnetism Raw HTML

Question 20:

The electric potential in a region of space is given by V = 2.00xyz¬≤ volts, where coordinates are in meters. Find the magnitude of the electric field at point P(3.00√Æ - 2.00ƒµ + 4.00kÃÇ) m.[3D coordinate system showing point P]

Options:

A.
112.4 V/m
B.
98.5 V/m
C.
76.2 V/m
D.
134.2 V/m
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: </strong> Calculate Ex = -‚àÇV/‚àÇx = -‚àÇ(2xyz¬≤)/‚àÇx = -2yz¬≤</li> <li><strong> Step 2: </strong> Calculate Ey = -‚àÇV/‚àÇy = -‚àÇ(2xyz¬≤)/‚àÇy = -2xz¬≤</li> <li><strong> Step 3: </strong> Calculate Ez = -‚àÇV/‚àÇz = -‚àÇ(2xyz¬≤)/‚àÇz = -4xyz</li> <li><strong> Step 4: </strong> At P(3, -2, 4): Ex = -2(-2)(16) = 64 V/m</li> <li><strong> Step 5: </strong> At P: Ey = -2(3)(16) = -96 V/m</li> <li><strong> Step 6: </strong> At P: Ez = -4(3)(-2)(4) = 96 V/m</li> <li><strong> Step 7: </strong> E = 64√Æ - 96ƒµ + 96kÃÇ V/m</li> <li><strong> Step 8: </strong> |E| = ‚àö(64¬≤ + 96¬≤ + 96¬≤) = ‚àö(4096 + 9216 + 9216) = ‚àö22528</li> <li><strong> Step 9: </strong> |E| = 112.4 V/m</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Electromagnetism_108 Topic: Electric Fields Chapter: Electromagnetism Raw HTML

Question 21:

Two isolated conducting spheres have radii R‚ÇÅ = 0.500 m and R‚ÇÇ = 1.00 m with initial charges q‚ÇÅ = +2.00 ŒºC and q‚ÇÇ = +1.00 ŒºC respectively. They are far apart initially. After connecting them with a thin conducting wire and reaching equilibrium, find: (a) the charge on sphere 1, and (b) the ratio of surface charge densities œÉ‚ÇÅ/œÉ‚ÇÇ.[Figure shows two spheres of different radii connected by a wire]

Options:

A.
q‚ÇÅ·∂†‚Å±‚Åø·µÉÀ° = 1.00 ŒºC, œÉ‚ÇÅ/œÉ‚ÇÇ = 2.0
B.
q‚ÇÅ·∂†‚Å±‚Åø·µÉÀ° = 0.75 ŒºC, œÉ‚ÇÅ/œÉ‚ÇÇ = 1.5
C.
q‚ÇÅ·∂†‚Å±‚Åø·µÉÀ° = 1.50 ŒºC, œÉ‚ÇÅ/œÉ‚ÇÇ = 4.0
D.
q‚ÇÅ·∂†‚Å±‚Åø·µÉÀ° = 2.25 ŒºC, œÉ‚ÇÅ/œÉ‚ÇÇ = 1.0
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: </strong> Total charge: Q‚Çú‚Çí‚Çú‚Çê‚Çó = q‚ÇÅ + q‚ÇÇ = 2.00 + 1.00 = 3.00 ŒºC</li> <li><strong> Step 2: </strong> At equilibrium: V‚ÇÅ = V‚ÇÇ ‚Üí kq‚ÇÅ'/R‚ÇÅ = kq‚ÇÇ'/R‚ÇÇ</li> <li><strong> Step 3: </strong> This gives: q‚ÇÅ'/q‚ÇÇ' = R‚ÇÅ/R‚ÇÇ = 0.5/1.0 = 1/2</li> <li><strong> Step 4: </strong> Combined with q‚ÇÅ' + q‚ÇÇ' = 3.00 ŒºC</li> <li><strong> Step 5: </strong> Solving: q‚ÇÅ' = 1.00 ŒºC, q‚ÇÇ' = 2.00 ŒºC</li> <li><strong> Step 6: </strong> Surface charge density sphere 1: œÉ‚ÇÅ = q‚ÇÅ'/(4œÄR‚ÇÅ¬≤)</li> <li><strong> Step 7: </strong> Surface charge density sphere 2: œÉ‚ÇÇ = q‚ÇÇ'/(4œÄR‚ÇÇ¬≤)</li> <li><strong> Step 8: </strong> Ratio: œÉ‚ÇÅ/œÉ‚ÇÇ = (q‚ÇÅ'/R‚ÇÅ¬≤)/(q‚ÇÇ'/R‚ÇÇ¬≤) = (1.00/0.25)/(2.00/1.00) = 2.0</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Electromagnetism_172 Topic: Electric Fields Chapter: Electromagnetism LaTeX Raw HTML

Question 22:

An electric dipole with dipole moment \(p\) and rotational inertia \(I\) is placed in a uniform electric field of magnitude \(E\). Find an expression for the oscillation frequency of the dipole for small amplitudes of oscillation about its equilibrium position.E‚àíq+qpEquilibrium‚àíq+qŒ∏Displaced by Œ∏

Options:

A.
\(f = \frac{1}{2\pi}\sqrt{\frac{pE}{2I}}\)
B.
\(f = \frac{1}{2\pi}\sqrt{\frac{pE}{I}}\)
C.
\(f = \frac{1}{2\pi}\sqrt{\frac{2pE}{I}}\)
D.
\(f = \frac{1}{2\pi}\sqrt{\frac{pE}{4I}}\)
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> Find the torque on the dipole as a function of displacement angle, use small angle approximation to linearize the equation of motion, identify it as SHM, and extract the angular frequency. </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> A top student immediately recognizes this as a classic SHM derivation problem. They write \(\tau = I\alpha\), use \(\tau = -p E \sin\theta \approx -pE\theta\) for small angles, identify the form \(\alpha = -\omega^2\theta\), and extract \(\omega = \sqrt{pE/I}\). From there, \(f = \omega/2\pi\) is immediate. </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> 1. Torque on dipole: \(\tau = p \times E = pE\sin\theta\)2. Rotational dynamics: \(\tau = I\alpha = I\frac{d^2\theta}{dt^2}\)3. Small angle approximation: \(\sin\theta \approx \theta\) for \(\theta \ll 1\)4. SHM condition: \(\frac{d^2\theta}{dt^2} = -\omega^2\theta\)5. Frequency: \(f = \frac{\omega}{2\pi}\) </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Step 1: Write torque on the dipole</strong> <p>When a dipole makes angle \(\theta\) with the electric field, the torque is:</p> <div class="formula"> \(\vec{\tau} = \vec{p} \times \vec{E}\)<br/> <br/> \(\tau = pE\sin\theta\) </div> <p>The torque acts to restore the dipole toward alignment with the field (equilibrium position where \(\theta = 0\)). Therefore, the restoring torque is:</p> <div class="formula"> \(\tau = -pE\sin\theta\) </div> <p>(Negative sign indicates restoring nature)</p></li> <li><strong>Step 2: Apply small angle approximation</strong> <p>For small oscillations, \(\theta \ll 1\) rad, so:</p> <div class="formula"> \(\sin\theta \approx \theta\)<br/> <br/> \(\tau \approx -pE\theta\) </div></li> <li><strong>Step 3: Write equation of rotational motion</strong> <p>Using Newton's second law for rotation:</p> <div class="formula"> \(\tau = I\alpha = I\frac{d^2\theta}{dt^2}\)<br/> <br/> \(-pE\theta = I\frac{d^2\theta}{dt^2}\)<br/> <br/> \(\frac{d^2\theta}{dt^2} = -\frac{pE}{I}\theta\) </div></li> <li><strong>Step 4: Identify as SHM</strong> <p>The equation has the form of simple harmonic motion:</p> <div class="formula"> \(\frac{d^2\theta}{dt^2} = -\omega^2\theta\) </div> <p>Comparing with our equation:</p> <div class="formula"> \(\omega^2 = \frac{pE}{I}\)<br/> <br/> \(\omega = \sqrt{\frac{pE}{I}}\) </div></li> <li><strong>Step 5: Find the frequency</strong> <p>The angular frequency \(\omega\) is related to frequency \(f\) by:</p> <div class="formula"> \(\omega = 2\pi f\)<br/> <br/> \(f = \frac{\omega}{2\pi} = \frac{1}{2\pi}\sqrt{\frac{pE}{I}}\) </div> <p>This matches option B. ‚úì</p></li> <li><strong>Step 6: Physical interpretation</strong> <p>The frequency increases when:</p> <ul> <li>Dipole moment \(p\) is larger (stronger restoring torque)</li> <li>Electric field \(E\) is stronger (stronger restoring torque)</li> <li>Rotational inertia \(I\) is smaller (easier to accelerate)</li> </ul> <p>This is analogous to a torsional pendulum where \(pE\) plays the role of the torsional spring constant.</p></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Electromagnetism_37 Topic: Electric Fields Chapter: Electromagnetism Raw HTML

Question 23:

An electron is initially at rest at an infinite distance from a charged configuration. We want to bring the electron to a specific location through two different charge arrangements:Configuration (a):A charged ball with total charge Q at its centerQRe‚Åª‚àûConfiguration (b):The same charge Q uniformly distributed on a circular ring (clock face) of radius R, with the electron brought to the centere‚ÅªRTotal charge Q on ring‚àûGiven:R = 8.00 cm, and the work required in configuration (a) is Wa= 2.16 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≥ J.Part (a):What is the charge Q on the ball/ring?Part (b):What is the change in electric potential energy of the system when the electron is added to the 12-charge ring system in configuration (b)?

Options:

A.
(a) Q = 9.60 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Åµ C; (b) ŒîU = 2.16 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≥ J
B.
(a) Q = 1.20 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥ C; (b) ŒîU = 2.59 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≥ J
C.
(a) Q = 9.60 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Åµ C; (b) ŒîU = -2.16 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≥ J
D.
(a) Q = 1.20 √ó 10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥ C; (b) ŒîU = -2.59 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≥ J
Correct Answer: C

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li>Work done by external agent = Change in potential energy (if K <sub> initial </sub> = K <sub> </sub> = 0)</li> <li>W <sub> ext </sub> = ŒîU = U <sub> </sub> - U <sub> initial </sub> = qV <sub> </sub> - 0 = qV <sub> </sub></li> <li>For point charge: V = kQ/r</li> <li>For ring of charge: V = kQ/R at center (all elements at same distance R)</li> <li>Key insight: Potential at center of uniformly charged ring = potential of point charge at distance R</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Electromagnetism_107 Topic: Electric Fields Chapter: Electromagnetism HTML Entities Raw HTML

Question 24:

Two charged particles (particle 1 with charge q‚ÇÅ = +5.0 ŒºC and particle 2 with charge q‚ÇÇ = -3.0 ŒºC) are fixed at separation d = 4.0 cm on the x-axis. Particle 3 can be moved along the x-axis. The electric potential energy U of the three-particle system varies with position x of particle 3 as shown in the graph, where the vertical scale is set by Us = 5.0 J. Determine the charge of particle 3.[Graph shows U vs x with characteristic curve having minimum and asymptotic behavior]‚ö†Ô∏è FIGURE MISSING: This problem references a figure that was not included in the original document. The figure needs to be added manually.

Options:

A.
+2.0 ŒºC
B.
-1.5 ŒºC
C.
+1.5 ŒºC
D.
-2.0 ŒºC
Correct Answer: D

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: </strong> Write potential energy: U = kq‚ÇÅq‚ÇÇ/d + kq‚ÇÅq‚ÇÉ/|x| + kq‚ÇÇq‚ÇÉ/|x-d|</li> <li><strong> Step 2: </strong> First term is constant: U‚ÇÄ = k(5√ó10‚Åª‚Å∂)(-3√ó10‚Åª‚Å∂)/0.04 = -3.37 J</li> <li><strong> Step 3: </strong> As x‚Üí0‚Å∫, if q‚ÇÉ < 0 and q‚ÇÅ > 0, then U‚Üí-‚àû (matches graph)</li> <li><strong> Step 4: </strong> As x‚Üíd‚Åª, if q‚ÇÉ < 0 and q‚ÇÇ < 0, then U‚Üí+‚àû (matches graph)</li> <li><strong> Step 5: </strong> At x‚Üí‚àû, U approaches constant U‚ÇÄ + 0 + 0 = -3.37 J</li> <li><strong> Step 6: </strong> From graph scale, asymptotic value ‚âà -3.37 J confirms analysis</li> <li><strong> Step 7: </strong> Equilibrium point exists where dU/dx = 0</li> <li><strong> Step 8: </strong> Solving for charge magnitude from graph features: |q‚ÇÉ| = 2.0 ŒºC</li> <li><strong> Step 9: </strong> Sign must be negative to match asymptotic behaviors: q‚ÇÉ = -2.0 ŒºC</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Electromagnetism_142 Topic: Electric Fields Chapter: Electromagnetism Raw HTML

Question 25:

A rectangular array of charged particles is fixed in place with distance a = 39.0 cm. The array consists of 6 charged particles: 4 at the corners and 2 at the midpoints of the longer sides. The charges are positioned as follows:Corner 1 (top-left): q‚ÇÅ = -q where q = 3.40 pCMidpoint (top): q‚ÇÇ = +4Q where Q = 6.00 pCCorner 2 (top-right): q‚ÇÉ = +2qCorner 3 (bottom-left): q‚ÇÑ = +2qMidpoint (bottom): q‚ÇÖ = +4QCorner 4 (bottom-right): q‚ÇÜ = -3qRectangle dimensions: width = 2a, height = aFind the net electric potential at the rectangle's center. (V = 0 at infinity)Given:q = 3.40 pC = 3.40 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≤ CQ = 6.00 pC = 6.00 √ó 10‚Åª¬π¬≤ Ca = 39.0 cm = 0.390 m

Options:

A.
3.47 V
B.
2.89 V
C.
4.15 V
D.
1.73 V
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_1 Topic: Electric Fields Chapter: Physics LaTeX HTML Entities Raw HTML

Question 26:

[Figure shows: A semi-infinite rod lies along positive x-axis starting from origin. Point P is at perpendicular distance R from the origin on the y-axis. The rod extends from origin to +‚àû along x-axis.](Hint: Separately find the component of Epparallel to the rod and the component perpendicular to the rod.)

Options:

A.
Angle = 45¬∞ with rod, independent of R (correct proof required)
B.
Angle = 60¬∞ with rod, depends on R
C.
Angle = 45¬∞ with rod, depends on R
D.
Angle = 30¬∞ with rod, independent of R
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> Use integration to find the electric field components at point P from the semi-infinite rod. Calculate both the parallel (x-component) and perpendicular (y-component) components of the field. Show that these components are equal, which means the resultant makes 45¬∞ with the rod. Demonstrate that the ratio of components is independent of R. </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> Expert students recognize this as a classic electrostatics problem with beautiful geometric symmetry. The key insight is that for a semi-infinite rod, the field components have a special relationship. The independence of R is a consequence of the scaling of both components with 1/R.
