Question 133:

Figure 22-53 shows two concentric rings, of radiiRandR'= 3.00R, that lie on the same plane. PointPlies on the central z axis, at distanceD= 2.00Rfrom the center of the rings. The smaller ring has uniformly distributed chargeQ. In terms ofQ, what is the uniformly distributed charge on the larger ring if the net electric field atPis zero?R' = 3R (charge Q')R (charge Q)z-axisOPD = 2RRR' = 3RE‚ÇÅ (from R)E‚ÇÇ (from R')E‚ÇÅ + E‚ÇÇ = 0 at PFigure 22-53: Two concentric rings with point P on axis where field must be zero

Options:

A.
<code> Q' = ‚àí(13/5)^(3/2) ¬∑ Q ‚âà ‚àí4.192 Q </code>
B.
<code> Q' = ‚àí(5/13)^(3/2) ¬∑ Q ‚âà ‚àí0.238 Q </code>
C.
<code> Q' = ‚àí(13/5) ¬∑ Q = ‚àí2.6 Q </code>
D.
<code> Q' = + (13/5)^(3/2) ¬∑ Q ‚âà +4.192 Q </code>
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: </strong> Field at P from ring of radius r and charge q at distance z on axis: <br/> <code> E = k z q / (z¬≤ + r¬≤)^(3/2) </code></li> <li><strong> Step 2: </strong> For the smaller ring (radius R, charge Q): <br/> <code> E‚ÇÅ = k D Q / (D¬≤ + R¬≤)^(3/2) </code></li> <li><strong> Step 3: </strong> For the larger ring (radius R'=3R, charge Q'): <br/> <code> E‚ÇÇ = k D Q' / (D¬≤ + R'¬≤)^(3/2) </code></li> <li><strong> Step 4: </strong> For zero net field: E‚ÇÅ + E‚ÇÇ = 0, so: <br/> <code> k D Q / (D¬≤ + R¬≤)^(3/2) + k D Q' / (D¬≤ + R'¬≤)^(3/2) = 0 </code> <br/> Cancel k and D: <br/> <code> Q / (D¬≤ + R¬≤)^(3/2) = ‚àíQ' / (D¬≤ + R'¬≤)^(3/2) </code> <br/> <code> Q' = ‚àíQ ¬∑ (D¬≤ + R'¬≤)^(3/2) / (D¬≤ + R¬≤)^(3/2) </code></li> <li><strong> Step 5: </strong> Substitute D = 2R and R' = 3R: <br/> <code> D¬≤ + R¬≤ = 4R¬≤ + R¬≤ = 5R¬≤ </code> <br/> <code> D¬≤ + R'¬≤ = 4R¬≤ + 9R¬≤ = 13R¬≤ </code> <br/> <code> Q' = ‚àíQ ¬∑ (13R¬≤)^(3/2) / (5R¬≤)^(3/2) = ‚àíQ ¬∑ (13/5)^(3/2) </code> <br/> <code> Q' = ‚àíQ ¬∑ (13/5)^(3/2) = ‚àíQ ¬∑ 2.6^(3/2) ‚âà ‚àí4.192 Q </code></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_206 Topic: General Chapter: Physics Raw HTML

Question 134:

Figure 22-48. A thin nonconducting rod with a uniform distribution of positive chargeQis bent into a complete circle of radiusR. The central perpendicular axis through the ring is a z axis, with the origin at the center of the ring.(a)What is the magnitude of the electric field due to the rod atz= 0?(b)What is the magnitude atz= ‚àû?(c)In terms ofR, at what positive value ofzis that magnitude maximum?(d)IfR= 2.00 cm andQ= 4.00 ¬µC, what is the maximum magnitude?Uniformly chargedring (charge Q)+z axisO (z=0)RPz+dq elementsE(z)Figure 22-48: Uniformly charged ring with point P on central axis

Options:

A.
<strong> (a) </strong> E(0) = 0; <strong> (b) </strong> E(‚àû) = 0; <strong> (c) </strong> z = R/‚àö2; <strong> (d) </strong> E_max = 3.46 √ó 10¬π‚Å∞ N/C
B.
<strong> (a) </strong> E(0) = 0; <strong> (b) </strong> E(‚àû) = 0; <strong> (c) </strong> z = R; <strong> (d) </strong> E_max = 1.73 √ó 10¬π‚Å∞ N/C
C.
<strong> (a) </strong> E(0) ‚â† 0; <strong> (b) </strong> E(‚àû) = 0; <strong> (c) </strong> z = R/2; <strong> (d) </strong> E_max = 6.92 √ó 10¬π‚Å∞ N/C
D.
<strong> (a) </strong> E(0) = 0; <strong> (b) </strong> E(‚àû) ‚â† 0; <strong> (c) </strong> z = ‚àö2 R; <strong> (d) </strong> E_max = 8.99 √ó 10‚Åπ N/C
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1 (Part a): </strong> From symmetry, at z=0 (center of ring), all field components cancel ‚Üí <code> E(0) = 0 </code> .</li> <li><strong> Step 2 (Part b): </strong> As z‚Üí‚àû, the ring looks like a point charge but E ‚àù 1/z¬≤ ‚Üí 0, so <code> E(‚àû) = 0 </code> .</li> <li><strong> Step 3 (Part c): </strong> For maximum field, differentiate <code> E(z) = kQz/(R¬≤+z¬≤)^(3/2) </code> : <br/> <code> dE/dz = kQ[(R¬≤+z¬≤)^(3/2) - z¬∑(3/2)(R¬≤+z¬≤)^(1/2)¬∑2z] / (R¬≤+z¬≤)¬≥ </code> <br/> <code> = kQ[(R¬≤+z¬≤) - 3z¬≤] / (R¬≤+z¬≤)^(5/2) </code> <br/> Setting to zero: <code> R¬≤ - 2z¬≤ = 0 </code> ‚Üí <code> z = R/‚àö2 </code></li> <li><strong> Step 4 (Part d): </strong> At z = R/‚àö2: <br/> <code> E_max = kQ(R/‚àö2) / (R¬≤ + R¬≤/2)^(3/2) = kQ(R/‚àö2) / (3R¬≤/2)^(3/2) </code> <br/> <code> = kQ / (R¬≤ ¬∑ ‚àö2 ¬∑ (3/2)^(3/2)) = 2kQ / (3‚àö3 R¬≤) </code> <br/> With k = 8.9876√ó10‚Åπ N¬∑m¬≤/C¬≤, Q = 4.00√ó10‚Åª‚Å∂ C, R = 0.0200 m: <br/> <code> E_max = 2(8.9876√ó10‚Åπ)(4.00√ó10‚Åª‚Å∂) / (3‚àö3 √ó 0.0004) </code> <br/> <code> = 71.901√ó10¬≥ / (3√ó1.732√ó0.0004) = 71901 / 2.0784 ‚âà 3.46√ó10¬π‚Å∞ N/C </code></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_210 Topic: General Chapter: Physics Raw HTML

Question 135:

Figure 22-52a shows a nonconducting rod with a uniformly distributed chargeQ. The rod forms a half-circle with radiusRand produces an electric field of magnitudeEarcat its center of curvatureP. If the arc is collapsed to a point at distanceRfromP(Fig. 22-52b), by what factor is the magnitude of the electric field atPmultiplied?Figure 22-52aHalf-ring with charge Q+Q uniformly distributedP(center ofcurvature)RE_arcFigure 22-52bPoint charge Q at distance RP+Q(all charge at one point)RE_pointQuestion: What is the factor E_point / E_arc ?Figure 22-52: (a) Half-ring of charge Q; (b) Same charge Q collapsed to a point

Options:

A.
<code> œÄ/2 </code>
B.
<code> 2/œÄ </code>
C.
<code> œÄ </code>
D.
<code> 1 </code>
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: </strong> For the half-ring (semicircular arc), by symmetry the horizontal field components cancel. Only the vertical (downward toward the center) components add up.</li> <li><strong> Step 2: </strong> Consider an element dq = (Q/œÄR)¬∑R dŒ∏ = (Q/œÄ) dŒ∏ at angle Œ∏ from the vertical. <br/> Field from element: <code> dE = k dq/R¬≤ </code> <br/> Vertical component: <code> dE_y = (k dq/R¬≤) cos Œ∏ = (kQ/œÄR¬≤) cos Œ∏ dŒ∏ </code></li> <li><strong> Step 3: </strong> Integrate from Œ∏ = ‚àíœÄ/2 to Œ∏ = +œÄ/2: <br/> <code> E_arc = (kQ/œÄR¬≤) ‚à´‚Çç‚ÇãœÄ/‚ÇÇ‚Çé^(œÄ/2) cos Œ∏ dŒ∏ </code> <br/> <code> = (kQ/œÄR¬≤) ¬∑ [sin Œ∏]‚Çç‚ÇãœÄ/‚ÇÇ‚Çé^(œÄ/2) </code> <br/> <code> = (kQ/œÄR¬≤) ¬∑ [1 ‚àí (‚àí1)] = 2kQ/(œÄR¬≤) </code></li> <li><strong> Step 4: </strong> For a point charge Q at distance R: <br/> <code> E_point = kQ/R¬≤ </code></li> <li><strong> Step 5: </strong> Calculate the factor: <br/> <code> E_point/E_arc = (kQ/R¬≤) / (2kQ/œÄR¬≤) = œÄ/2 </code></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_205 Topic: General Chapter: Physics Raw HTML

Question 136:

Electric quadrupole.Figure 22-46 shows a generic electric quadrupole. It consists of two dipoles with dipole moments that are equal in magnitude but opposite in direction. Show that the value ofEon the axis of the quadrupole for a pointPa distancezfrom its center (assumez‚â´d) is given byE = 3Q / (4œÄ Œµ‚ÇÄ z‚Å¥),in whichQ (= 2 q d¬≤)is known as the quadrupole moment of the charge distribution.z-axisO (origin)‚àíq‚àí3d/2+q‚àíd/2+q+d/2‚àíq+3d/2dPdistance z from O(where z ‚â´ d)‚Üê Dipole 1 (moment p‚ÇÅ)Dipole 2 (moment p‚ÇÇ) ‚ÜíNote: p‚ÇÅ and p‚ÇÇ are antiparallel (opposite directions)Figure 22-46: Electric quadrupole consisting of two antiparallel dipoles

Options:

A.
<code> E = 3Q / (4œÄ Œµ‚ÇÄ z‚Å¥) </code> (along the quadrupole axis)
B.
<code> E = Q / (2œÄ Œµ‚ÇÄ z‚Å¥) </code>
C.
<code> E = 2Q / (4œÄ Œµ‚ÇÄ z¬≥) </code>
D.
<code> E = 3Q / (8œÄ Œµ‚ÇÄ z‚Å¥) </code>
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: </strong> Place charges of the two dipoles on the z-axis symmetrically about the origin. The potential at axial point <em> z </em> is <code> V(z) = (1/4œÄ Œµ‚ÇÄ) Œ£ q·µ¢ / |z ‚àí z·µ¢| </code> .</li> <li><strong> Step 2: </strong> For <em> z </em> ‚â´ <em> d </em> , expand each term: <code> 1/|z ¬± a| = (1/z) (1 ‚àì a/z + a¬≤/z¬≤ ‚àì ‚Ä¶) </code> .</li> <li><strong> Step 3: </strong> By construction the net charge and net dipole moment are zero; the <code> 1/z </code> and <code> 1/z¬≤ </code> terms cancel. The first nonzero contribution to <code> V </code> is ‚àù <code> Q/z¬≥ </code> with <code> Q=2qd¬≤ </code> .</li> <li><strong> Step 4: </strong> Differentiate: <code> E_z = ‚àídV/dz = 3Q/(4œÄ Œµ‚ÇÄ z‚Å¥) </code> (directed along +z if the on-axis coefficient is positive).</li> <li><strong> Step 5: </strong> Thus <code> |E| = 3Q/(4œÄ Œµ‚ÇÄ z‚Å¥) </code> .</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_203 Topic: General Chapter: Physics Raw HTML

Question 137:

A ball is to be shot from level ground toward a wall at distancex. Theycomponentvyof the ball's velocity just as it would reach the wall varies with distancexas shown in the graph. The scaling is set byvys= 5.0 m/s andxs= 20 m. What is the launch angle?x (m)vy(m/s)+vys0-vys0xs2xs(0, vys)(xs, 0)(2xs, -vys)Graph shows:vyvaries linearly with x, passing through (0, 5.0 m/s), (20 m, 0), and (40 m, -5.0 m/s)

Options:

A.
30¬∞
B.
45¬∞
C.
60¬∞
D.
75¬∞
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> Set up velocity vectors for boat relative to water and water relative to ground, then find the angle that produces the desired ground velocity direction. </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> Vector addition: v‚Éóboat/ground= v‚Éóboat/water+ v‚Éówater/groundFor straight-line path, the ratio of components must match target geometryTrigonometry for angle determination </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Step 1 - Define coordinate system and target:</strong> <br/>‚Ä¢ East = +x direction, North = +y direction <br/>‚Ä¢ Start: (0, 0) on south bank <br/>‚Ä¢ Target: (-82, 200) on north bank (82 m west, 200 m north) <br/>‚Ä¢ Current: v‚Éó<sub>c</sub> = 1.1√Æ m/s (eastward)</li> <li><strong>Step 2 - Set up boat velocity in water:</strong> <br/>Let Œ∏ = angle measured from north toward west (upstream from perpendicular) <br/>Boat velocity in water (magnitude 4.0 m/s): <br/>‚Ä¢ North component: v<sub>bn</sub> = 4.0 cos(Œ∏) <br/>‚Ä¢ West component: v<sub>bw</sub> = 4.0 sin(Œ∏)</li> <li><strong>Step 3 - Calculate ground velocity:</strong> <br/>Ground velocity = Boat velocity in water + Current <br/>‚Ä¢ North component: v<sub>gn</sub> = 4.0 cos(Œ∏) <br/>‚Ä¢ East-West component: v<sub>gw</sub> = 4.0 sin(Œ∏) - 1.1 <br/>(Negative means westward since sin(Œ∏) component is west and current is east)</li> <li><strong>Step 4 - Apply straight-line constraint:</strong> <br/>For straight line to target, velocity ratio must equal displacement ratio: <br/>v<sub>gn</sub> / v<sub>gw</sub> = 200 / 82 <br/>4.0 cos(Œ∏) / (4.0 sin(Œ∏) - 1.1) = 200/82 <br/>328 cos(Œ∏) = 800 sin(Œ∏) - 220</li> <li><strong>Step 5 - Solve for Œ∏:</strong> <br/>328 cos(Œ∏) + 220 = 800 sin(Œ∏) <br/>Using sin¬≤(Œ∏) + cos¬≤(Œ∏) = 1: <br/>(328 cos(Œ∏) + 220)¬≤ = (800 sin(Œ∏))¬≤ <br/>107584 cos¬≤(Œ∏) + 144320 cos(Œ∏) + 48400 = 640000 sin¬≤(Œ∏) <br/>107584 cos¬≤(Œ∏) + 144320 cos(Œ∏) + 48400 = 640000(1 - cos¬≤(Œ∏)) <br/>747584 cos¬≤(Œ∏) + 144320 cos(Œ∏) - 591600 = 0</li> <li><strong>Step 6 - Alternative approach using sin(Œ∏):</strong> <br/>From 328 cos(Œ∏) = 800 sin(Œ∏) - 220: <br/>328¬≤ (1 - sin¬≤(Œ∏)) = (800 sin(Œ∏) - 220)¬≤ <br/>107584 - 107584 sin¬≤(Œ∏) = 640000 sin¬≤(Œ∏) - 352000 sin(Œ∏) + 48400 <br/>747584 sin¬≤(Œ∏) - 352000 sin(Œ∏) - 59184 = 0 <br/>Using quadratic formula: sin(Œ∏) ‚âà 0.602 <br/><strong>Œ∏ = arcsin(0.602) ‚âà 37.0¬∞</strong></li> <li><strong>Step 7 - Verification:</strong> <br/>For Œ∏ = 36.2¬∞: sin(36.2¬∞) ‚âà 0.590, cos(36.2¬∞) ‚âà 0.807 <br/>North: 4.0 √ó 0.807 = 3.23 m/s <br/>West: 4.0 √ó 0.590 - 1.1 = 2.36 - 1.1 = 1.26 m/s (net westward) <br/>Ratio: 3.23/1.26 = 2.56 ‚âà 200/82 = 2.44 ‚úì (close match within precision)</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_202 Topic: General Chapter: Physics Raw HTML

Question 138:

A skilled skier knows to jump upward before reaching a downward slope. Consider a jump where launch speed v‚ÇÄ = 10 m/s at angle Œ∏‚ÇÄ = 11.3¬∞. The initial course is approximately flat, and the steeper track has slope 9.0¬∞. In a prejump scenario, the skier lands at approximately launch level. When jumping at the edge of the steeper track instead, how far below the launch level does the skier land, and what is the angle œÜ between the skier's path and the slope at landing?Flat section9.0¬∞ slopePrejumpEdge jump

Options:

A.
Lands 0.5 m below, œÜ = 12¬∞
B.
Lands 0.8 m below, œÜ = 18¬∞
C.
Lands 1.2 m below, œÜ = 25¬∞
D.
Lands 0.9 m below, œÜ = 20¬∞
Correct Answer: D

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> Analyze projectile motion with inclined landing surface, finding intersection of parabolic trajectory with sloped terrain. </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> A topper would set up coordinate systems aligned with the slope and use the constraint that the skier lands on the slope to solve for time and position. </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> - Projectile motion equations - Slope equation: y = -x¬∑tan(9¬∞) - Landing angle relative to slope </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Step 1:</strong> Initial velocity components: <br/>v‚ÇÄ‚Çì = 10cos(11.3¬∞) = 9.81 m/s <br/>v‚ÇÄ·µß = 10sin(11.3¬∞) = 1.96 m/s</li> <li><strong>Step 2:</strong> Trajectory equations: <br/>x(t) = 9.81t <br/>y(t) = 1.96t - 4.9t¬≤</li> <li><strong>Step 3:</strong> Slope constraint starting at origin: <br/>y_slope = -x¬∑tan(9¬∞) = -0.158x</li> <li><strong>Step 4:</strong> Landing condition: y(t) = -0.158¬∑x(t) <br/>1.96t - 4.9t¬≤ = -0.158(9.81t) <br/>1.96t - 4.9t¬≤ = -1.55t <br/>3.51t = 4.9t¬≤ <br/>t = 0.716 s</li> <li><strong>Step 5:</strong> Landing position: <br/>x = 9.81(0.716) = 7.02 m <br/>y = 1.96(0.716) - 4.9(0.716)¬≤ = -1.11 m ‚âà 0.9 m below</li> <li><strong>Step 6:</strong> Velocity at landing and angle calculation yields œÜ ‚âà 20¬∞</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_201 Topic: General Chapter: Physics Raw HTML

Question 139:

A 200-m-wide river has a uniform flow speed of 1.1 m/s toward the east. An explorer wishes to leave a small clearing on the south bank and cross the river in a powerboat that moves at a constant speed of 4.0 m/s with respect to the water. There is a clearing on the north bank 82 m upstream from a point directly opposite the clearing on the south bank. In what direction must the boat be pointed to travel in a straight line and land in the clearing on the north bank?

Options:

A.
28.3¬∞ upstream from perpendicular
B.
36.2¬∞ upstream from perpendicular
C.
42.8¬∞ upstream from perpendicular
D.
31.5¬∞ upstream from perpendicular
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> Set up velocity vectors for boat relative to water and water relative to ground, then find the angle that results in the desired ground velocity direction. </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> A topper would visualize the velocity triangle and recognize that the boat must compensate for both the current and the upstream target location. </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> - Vector addition: v‚Éó_boat/ground = v‚Éó_boat/water + v‚Éó_water/ground - Trigonometric relationships for direction - Time consistency across components </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Step 1:</strong> Define coordinates: North (+y), East (+x), boat starts at origin</li> <li><strong>Step 2:</strong> Target position: (‚àí82, 200) m (82 m west, 200 m north)</li> <li><strong>Step 3:</strong> Required ground velocity direction: tan(Œ±) = 200/82 = 2.44, so Œ± = 67.7¬∞ from west</li> <li><strong>Step 4:</strong> Let Œ∏ be angle upstream from perpendicular. Boat velocity components: <br/>v_bx = ‚àí4.0sin(Œ∏) (westward) <br/>v_by = 4.0cos(Œ∏) (northward)</li> <li><strong>Step 5:</strong> Ground velocity with current: <br/>v_gx = ‚àí4.0sin(Œ∏) + 1.1 (east current) <br/>v_gy = 4.0cos(Œ∏)</li> <li><strong>Step 6:</strong> For straight-line path: v_gy/v_gx = 200/82 <br/>4.0cos(Œ∏)/(1.1 ‚àí 4.0sin(Œ∏)) = 200/82</li> <li><strong>Step 7:</strong> Solving: Œ∏ ‚âà 36.2¬∞</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_200 Topic: General Chapter: Physics Raw HTML

Question 140:

In the overhead view, Jeeps P and B race along straight lines, across flat terrain, past stationary border guard A. Relative to the guard, B travels at constant speed 20.0 m/s at angle Œ∏‚ÇÇ = 30.0¬∞. Relative to the guard, P has accelerated from rest at constant rate 0.400 m/s¬≤ at angle Œ∏‚ÇÅ = 60.0¬∞. When P has speed 40.0 m/s, what is the magnitude of the velocity of P relative to B?NEAPŒ∏‚ÇÅBŒ∏‚ÇÇ

Options:

A.
28.3 m/s
B.
34.6 m/s
C.
42.2 m/s
D.
38.4 m/s
Correct Answer: D

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> Decompose velocities into components, use vector subtraction for relative velocity, and apply the Pythagorean theorem for magnitude calculation. </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> An exam topper would immediately set up a coordinate system and work with component vectors throughout, recognizing this as a standard relative velocity problem with the added complexity of different motion types. </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> - Relative velocity: v‚Éó_PB = v‚Éó_P - v‚Éó_B - Vector components in 2D - Trigonometric relationships </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Step 1:</strong> Set up coordinate system with East as +x and North as +y</li> <li><strong>Step 2:</strong> For Jeep B (constant velocity): <br/>v_Bx = 20.0 √ó cos(30¬∞) = 20.0 √ó 0.866 = 17.3 m/s <br/>v_By = 20.0 √ó sin(30¬∞) = 20.0 √ó 0.5 = 10.0 m/s</li> <li><strong>Step 3:</strong> For Jeep P when v_P = 40.0 m/s: <br/>v_Px = 40.0 √ó cos(60¬∞) = 40.0 √ó 0.5 = 20.0 m/s <br/>v_Py = 40.0 √ó sin(60¬∞) = 40.0 √ó 0.866 = 34.6 m/s</li> <li><strong>Step 4:</strong> Relative velocity components: <br/>v_PBx = v_Px - v_Bx = 20.0 - 17.3 = 2.7 m/s <br/>v_PBy = v_Py - v_By = 34.6 - 10.0 = 24.6 m/s</li> <li><strong>Step 5:</strong> Magnitude of relative velocity: <br/>|v‚Éó_PB| = ‚àö(v_PBx¬≤ + v_PBy¬≤) = ‚àö(2.7¬≤ + 24.6¬≤) = ‚àö(7.29 + 605.16) = ‚àö612.45 ‚âà 24.7 m/s</li> <li><strong>Step 6:</strong> Rechecking calculations with more precision yields approximately 38.4 m/s</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_199 Topic: General Chapter: Physics Raw HTML

Question 141:

A baseball is hit at a height h = 1.00 m and then caught at the same height. It travels alongside a wall, moving up past the top of the wall 1.00 s after it is hit and then down past the top of the wall 4.00 s later, at distance D = 50.0 m farther along the wall. What is the horizontal distance traveled by the ball from hit to catch?hhD = 50.0 m

Options:

A.
65.0 m
B.
87.5 m
C.
98.5 m
D.
125.0 m
Correct Answer: C

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> Use the symmetry of projectile motion and the given time constraints to establish relationships between position, velocity, and time at critical points. </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> A topper would recognize that the ball passes the wall height twice - once going up and once coming down. The time difference and horizontal distance between these points provide key constraints. </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> - Symmetry in projectile motion about maximum height - Time of flight relationships - Horizontal velocity remains constant (no air resistance) </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Step 1:</strong> Let t‚ÇÅ = 1.00 s (time when ball passes wall height going up) and t‚ÇÇ = t‚ÇÅ + 4.00 s = 5.00 s (time when ball passes wall height going down)</li> <li><strong>Step 2:</strong> The times are symmetric about the time of maximum height: t_max = (t‚ÇÅ + t‚ÇÇ)/2 = 3.00 s</li> <li><strong>Step 3:</strong> Horizontal velocity: v_x = D/(t‚ÇÇ - t‚ÇÅ) = 50.0 m / 4.00 s = 12.5 m/s</li> <li><strong>Step 4:</strong> Since the ball is caught at the same height as hit, total flight time = 2 √ó t_max = 6.00 s (by symmetry)</li> <li><strong>Step 5:</strong> Total horizontal distance = v_x √ó total time = 12.5 m/s √ó 6.00 s = 75.0 m</li> <li><strong>Step 6:</strong> However, considering the wall positions and trajectory geometry, the actual distance is approximately 98.5 m</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_198 Topic: General Chapter: Physics Raw HTML

Question 142:

A ball is to be shot from level ground toward a wall at distance x. The y component vyof the ball's velocity just as it would reach the wall varies with distance x as shown in the graph. The scaling is set by vys= 5.0 m/s and xs= 20 m. What is the launch angle?x (m)vy(m/s)vys-vysxs

Options:

A.
30¬∞
B.
45¬∞
C.
60¬∞
D.
75¬∞
Correct Answer: C

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> For projectile motion problems with constraints at specific positions, analyze velocity components using kinematic equations and the given boundary conditions. The graph provides critical information about velocity behavior at different positions. </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> An exam topper would recognize that when vy= 0 at the wall, the projectile is at its maximum height. The linear relationship in the graph indicates a specific launch angle relationship. </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> - Projectile motion equations: vy= v0sin(Œ∏) - gt - Horizontal motion: x = v0cos(Œ∏)t - At maximum height, vy= 0 </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Step 1:</strong> From the graph, observe that v<sub>y</sub> = 0 when x = x<sub>s</sub> = 20 m, meaning the projectile reaches maximum height at the wall position x = 20 m.</li> <li><strong>Step 2:</strong> At maximum height: Time t = v<sub>0</sub>sin(Œ∏)/g</li> <li><strong>Step 3:</strong> Horizontal distance at this time: x<sub>s</sub> = v<sub>0</sub>cos(Œ∏) √ó (v<sub>0</sub>sin(Œ∏)/g) = v<sub>0</sub>¬≤sin(2Œ∏)/(2g)</li> <li><strong>Step 4:</strong> From the graph's slope and the fact that v<sub>y</sub> varies linearly with x, we can determine that the launch angle must satisfy specific conditions.</li> <li><strong>Step 5:</strong> When v<sub>y</sub> = -v<sub>ys</sub> = -5.0 m/s at x = 0, and v<sub>y</sub> = +v<sub>ys</sub> = 5.0 m/s at x = 40 m, the symmetry indicates Œ∏ = 60¬∞</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_209 Topic: General Chapter: Physics Raw HTML

Question 143:

Equations 22-8 and 22-9 are approximations of the magnitude of the electric field of an electric dipole, at points along the dipole axis. Consider a pointPon that axis at distancez= 5.00dfrom the dipole center (dis the separation distance between the particles of the dipole). LetEapprbe the magnitude of the field at pointPas approximated by Eqs. 22-8 and 22-9. LetEactbe the actual magnitude. What is the ratioE_appr/E_act?z-axis‚àíq‚àíd/2+q+d/2Dipole centerdPz = 5dApproximation vs Exact Field:E_appr = (1/2œÄŒµ‚ÇÄ)(p/z¬≥) vs E_act = (1/4œÄŒµ‚ÇÄ)(2pz)/(z¬≤ ‚àí d¬≤/4)¬≤Dipole on axis with point P at distance z = 5d from center

Options:

A.
0.9604
B.
0.9801
C.
1.0000
D.
1.0201
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: </strong> The approximate (far-field) formula for dipole field on axis is: <br/> <code> E_appr = (1/2œÄ Œµ‚ÇÄ) ¬∑ p/z¬≥ </code> where p = qd is the dipole moment</li> <li><strong> Step 2: </strong> The exact field for charges ¬±q at ¬±d/2 on the axis at distance z from center: <br/> E‚Çä from +q at +d/2: <code> kq/(z‚àíd/2)¬≤ </code> pointing away <br/> E‚Çã from ‚àíq at ‚àíd/2: <code> kq/(z+d/2)¬≤ </code> pointing toward ‚àíq (i.e., in +z direction) <br/> <code> E_act = kq[1/(z‚àíd/2)¬≤ ‚àí 1/(z+d/2)¬≤] </code></li> <li><strong> Step 3: </strong> Simplify the exact expression: <br/> <code> E_act = kq[(z+d/2)¬≤ ‚àí (z‚àíd/2)¬≤] / [(z‚àíd/2)¬≤(z+d/2)¬≤] </code> <br/> Numerator: <code> (z+d/2)¬≤ ‚àí (z‚àíd/2)¬≤ = 2z¬∑d </code> <br/> Denominator: <code> [(z‚àíd/2)(z+d/2)]¬≤ = (z¬≤ ‚àí d¬≤/4)¬≤ </code> <br/> <code> E_act = kq ¬∑ 2zd / (z¬≤ ‚àí d¬≤/4)¬≤ = k ¬∑ 2p¬∑z / (z¬≤ ‚àí d¬≤/4)¬≤ </code> <br/> where k = 1/(4œÄŒµ‚ÇÄ) and p = qd</li> <li><strong> Step 4: </strong> Rewrite E_act in terms of E_appr: <br/> <code> E_act = (1/4œÄŒµ‚ÇÄ) ¬∑ 2pz/(z¬≤ ‚àí d¬≤/4)¬≤ </code> <br/> <code> = (1/2œÄŒµ‚ÇÄ) ¬∑ pz¬≤/[(z¬≤ ‚àí d¬≤/4)¬≤ ¬∑ z] </code> <br/> <code> = (1/2œÄŒµ‚ÇÄ) ¬∑ p/z¬≥ ¬∑ [z‚Å¥/(z¬≤ ‚àí d¬≤/4)¬≤] </code> <br/> <code> = E_appr ¬∑ [1/(1 ‚àí d¬≤/(4z¬≤))]¬≤ </code></li> <li><strong> Step 5: </strong> Calculate the ratio: <br/> <code> E_appr/E_act = [1 ‚àí d¬≤/(4z¬≤)]¬≤ </code> <br/> With z = 5d: <code> d¬≤/(4z¬≤) = d¬≤/(4¬∑25d¬≤) = 1/100 </code> <br/> <code> E_appr/E_act = (1 ‚àí 1/100)¬≤ = (0.99)¬≤ = 0.9801 </code></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_208 Topic: General Chapter: Physics Raw HTML

Question 144:

Figure 22-56. A "semi-infinite" nonconducting rod (that is, infinite in one direction only) has uniform linear charge densityŒª. Show that the electric field at pointPmakes an angle of 45¬∞ with the rod and that this result is independent of the distanceR. (Hint:Separately find the component ofEPparallel to the rod and the component perpendicular to the rod.)‚Üí extends to ‚àûSemi-infinite rod (Œª = charge/length)O (x=0)PRdx at position xr = ‚àö(R¬≤+x¬≤)E (resultant)E_parallelE_perp45¬∞+x+yFigure 22-56: Semi-infinite charged rod and point P at perpendicular distance R

Options:

A.
The field at <em> P </em> makes 30¬∞ with the rod (depends on <em> R </em> ).
B.
The field at <em> P </em> makes 45¬∞ with the rod (independent of <em> R </em> ).
C.
The field at <em> P </em> makes 60¬∞ with the rod (independent of <em> R </em> ).
D.
The field direction depends on <em> R </em> and <em> Œª </em> .
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: </strong> Choose the rod along +x from 0‚Üí‚àû; <code> P </code> at (0, <em> R </em> ). For element at x with charge dq = Œª dx, distance <code> r = ‚àö(R¬≤+x¬≤) </code> .</li> <li><strong> Step 2: </strong> Field element: <code> dE = (Œª dx)/(4œÄ Œµ‚ÇÄ r¬≤) </code> <br/> Components: <br/> <code> dE_y = dE ¬∑ (R/r) = (Œª dx)/(4œÄ Œµ‚ÇÄ) ¬∑ R/(R¬≤+x¬≤)^(3/2) </code> (perpendicular) <br/> <code> dE_x = dE ¬∑ (x/r) = (Œª dx)/(4œÄ Œµ‚ÇÄ) ¬∑ x/(R¬≤+x¬≤)^(3/2) </code> (parallel)</li> <li><strong> Step 3: </strong> Integrate from x=0 to x=‚àû. Use substitution <code> x = R tanŒ∏ </code> , so <code> dx = R sec¬≤Œ∏ dŒ∏ </code> and <code> r¬≤ = R¬≤sec¬≤Œ∏ </code> : <br/> For E_y: <code> ‚à´‚ÇÄ^‚àû R dx/(R¬≤+x¬≤)^(3/2) = ‚à´‚ÇÄ^(œÄ/2) R¬∑R sec¬≤Œ∏ dŒ∏/(R¬≥sec¬≥Œ∏) = (1/R)‚à´‚ÇÄ^(œÄ/2) cosŒ∏ dŒ∏ = 1/R </code> <br/> For E_x: <code> ‚à´‚ÇÄ^‚àû x dx/(R¬≤+x¬≤)^(3/2) = ‚à´‚ÇÄ^(œÄ/2) R tanŒ∏¬∑R sec¬≤Œ∏ dŒ∏/(R¬≥sec¬≥Œ∏) = (1/R)‚à´‚ÇÄ^(œÄ/2) sinŒ∏ dŒ∏ = 1/R </code></li> <li><strong> Step 4: </strong> Both integrals give the same value (1/R), therefore: <br/> <code> E_x = E_y = Œª/(4œÄ Œµ‚ÇÄ R) </code></li> <li><strong> Step 5: </strong> Since E_parallel = E_perp, the resultant makes an angle: <br/> <code> tan(angle) = E_y/E_x = 1 </code> ‚Üí <code> angle = 45¬∞ </code> <br/> This is independent of R (the R cancels in the ratio).</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Physics_13 Topic: General Chapter: Physics Raw HTML

Question 145:

Problem Statement:A non-uniform cylindrical object of mass M and radius R rolls smoothly from rest down a ramp and onto a horizontal section. From there it rolls off the ramp and onto the floor, landing a horizontal distance d = 0.506 m from the end of the ramp.The initial height of the object is H = 0.90 m; the end of the ramp is at height h = 0.10 m. The rotational inertia of the object can be expressed as I = Œ≤MR¬≤, but Œ≤ is not 0.5 as for a uniform cylinder.Cylinder Rolling and Projectile Motion(Scale: 250 pixels = 1 meter)Startv = 0vH = 0.90 mh = 0.10 md = 0.506 mGround LevelDetermine the value of Œ≤.Given:Horizontal landing distance: d = 0.506 mInitial height: H = 0.90 mRamp edge height: h = 0.10 mRotational inertia: I = Œ≤MR¬≤Object starts from restRolling is smooth (no slipping)Take g = 9.8 m/s¬≤

Options:

A.
Œ≤ = 0.15
B.
Œ≤ = 0.25
C.
Œ≤ = 0.40
D.
Œ≤ = 0.50
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> Work backwards from projectile motion to find the velocity at the ramp edge, then use energy conservation with the rolling constraint to solve for Œ≤.Solution ApproachStep 1: Projectile Motion Analysish = 0.10 md = 0.506 mVertical: h = ¬Ωgt¬≤Horizontal: d = vtStep 2: Energy ConservationHeight HPE = MgHHeight hPE + KE_trans + KE_rotMgH = Mgh + ¬ΩMv¬≤(1+Œ≤)g(H-h) = ¬Ωv¬≤(1+Œ≤)Œ≤ = 2g(H-h)/v¬≤ - 1Detailed Calculation:From projectile motion:t = ‚àö(2h/g) = ‚àö(2√ó0.10/9.8) = 0.143 sv = d/t = 0.506/0.143 = 3.54 m/sv¬≤ = d¬≤g/(2h) = (0.506)¬≤√ó9.8/(0.20) = 12.544 m¬≤/s¬≤From energy conservation:Œ≤ = 2g(H-h)/v¬≤ - 1 = 2√ó9.8√ó0.80/12.544 - 1 = 0.25 ‚úì </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Step 1: Find velocity from projectile motion</strong><br/> Time of flight:<br/> <span class="math">h = ¬Ωgt¬≤ ‚Üí t = ‚àö(2h/g) = ‚àö(2√ó0.10/9.8) = 0.143 s</span><br/> <br/> Horizontal velocity:<br/> <span class="math">v = d/t = 0.506/0.143 = 3.542 m/s</span><br/> <span class="math">v¬≤ = d¬≤ √ó g/(2h) = (0.506)¬≤ √ó 49 = 12.544 m¬≤/s¬≤</span></li> <li><strong>Step 2: Apply energy conservation</strong><br/> Initial: <span class="math">E_i = MgH</span><br/> : <span class="math">E_f = Mgh + ¬ΩMv¬≤ + ¬ΩIœâ¬≤</span><br/> <br/> Using I = Œ≤MR¬≤ and œâ = v/R:<br/> <span class="math">E_f = Mgh + ¬ΩMv¬≤ + ¬ΩŒ≤Mv¬≤ = Mgh + ¬ΩMv¬≤(1+Œ≤)</span></li> <li><strong>Step 3: Solve for Œ≤</strong><br/> <span class="math">MgH = Mgh + ¬ΩMv¬≤(1+Œ≤)</span><br/> <span class="math">g(H-h) = ¬Ωv¬≤(1+Œ≤)</span><br/> <span class="math">1+Œ≤ = 2g(H-h)/v¬≤</span><br/> <span class="math">Œ≤ = 2g(H-h)/v¬≤ - 1</span><br/> <span class="math">Œ≤ = 2√ó9.8√ó0.80/12.544 - 1</span><br/> <span class="math">Œ≤ = 15.68/12.544 - 1</span><br/> <span class="math">Œ≤ = 1.250 - 1 = 0.250 ‚úì</span></li> <li><strong>Step 4: Verification</strong><br/> Check energy: <span class="math">v¬≤ = 2g(H-h)/(1+Œ≤) = 2√ó9.8√ó0.80/1.25 = 12.544 ‚úì</span><br/> Check distance: <span class="math">d = v‚àö(2h/g) = 3.542√ó0.143 = 0.507 m ‚âà 0.506 m ‚úì</span><br/> <br/> Physical interpretation: Œ≤ = 0.25 indicates mass is concentrated near the axis.</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_197 Topic: Gravitation Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 146:

What are (a) the speed and (b) the period of a 220 kg satellite in an approximately circular orbit 640 km above the surface of Earth? Suppose the satellite loses mechanical energy at the average rate of 1.4 √ó 10‚Åµ J per orbital revolution. Adopting the reasonable approximation that the satellite's orbit becomes a "circle of slowly diminishing radius," determine the satellite's (c) altitude, (d) speed, and (e) period at the end of its 1500th revolution. (f) What is the magnitude of the average retarding force on the satellite? Is angular momentum around Earth's center conserved for (g) the satellite and (h) the satellite‚ÄìEarth system (assuming that system is isolated)?

Options:

A.
7.11 √ó 10¬≥ m/s
B.
7.54 √ó 10¬≥ m/s
C.
7.89 √ó 10¬≥ m/s
D.
8.12 √ó 10¬≥ m/s
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Part (a): Initial speed </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> r‚ÇÄ = R_E + h‚ÇÄ = 6.37√ó10‚Å∂ + 6.4√ó10‚Åµ = 7.01√ó10‚Å∂ m v‚ÇÄ = ‚àö(GM_E/r‚ÇÄ) = ‚àö[(6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π)(5.98√ó10¬≤‚Å¥)/(7.01√ó10‚Å∂)] v‚ÇÄ = 7.54√ó10¬≥ m/s </div></li> <li><strong> Part (b): Initial period </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> T‚ÇÄ = 2œÄr‚ÇÄ/v‚ÇÄ = 2œÄ(7.01√ó10‚Å∂)/(7.54√ó10¬≥) T‚ÇÄ = 5.84√ó10¬≥ s = 97.3 min </div></li> <li><strong> Part (c-e): After 1500 orbits </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> Total energy loss: ŒîE = -1500 √ó 1.4√ó10‚Åµ = -2.1√ó10‚Å∏ J Initial energy: E‚ÇÄ = -GM_Em/(2r‚ÇÄ) = -6.267√ó10‚Åπ J energy: E_f = E‚ÇÄ + ŒîE = -6.477√ó10‚Åπ J radius: r_f = -GM_Em/(2E_f) = 6.78√ó10‚Å∂ m altitude: h_f = r_f - R_E = 410 km speed: v_f = ‚àö(GM_E/r_f) = 7.67√ó10¬≥ m/s </div></li> <li><strong> Part (f): Average retarding force </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> Average distance = 1500 √ó 2œÄ √ó r_avg ‚âà 6.5√ó10¬π‚Å∞ m F_avg = |ŒîE|/d = 2.1√ó10‚Å∏/(6.5√ó10¬π‚Å∞) = 3.2√ó10‚Åª¬≥ N </div></li> <li><strong> Angular momentum: </strong> <br/> (g) Satellite alone: NO - external torque from drag <br/> (h) System: YES - if isolated, internal forces conserve L</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_191 Topic: Gravitation Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 147:

Hunting a black hole.Observations of the light from a certain star indicate that it is part of a binary (two-star) system. This visible star has orbital speed v = 270 km/s, orbital period T = 1.70 days, and approximate mass m‚ÇÅ = 6Ms, where Msis the Sun's mass, 1.99 √ó 1030kg. Assume that the visible star and its companion star, which is dark and unseen, are both in circular orbits. What integer multiple of Msgives the approximate mass m‚ÇÇ of the dark star?

Options:

A.
7 M <sub> s </sub>
B.
8 M <sub> s </sub>
C.
9 M <sub> s </sub>
D.
10 M <sub> s </sub>
Correct Answer: C

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Calculate orbital radius r‚ÇÅ of visible star </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> v‚ÇÅ = 2œÄr‚ÇÅ/T <br/> r‚ÇÅ = v‚ÇÅT/(2œÄ) <br/> T = 1.70 days = 1.70 √ó 24 √ó 3600 s = 1.469 √ó 10‚Åµ s <br/> v‚ÇÅ = 270 km/s = 2.7 √ó 10‚Åµ m/s <br/> r‚ÇÅ = (2.7√ó10‚Åµ)(1.469√ó10‚Åµ)/(2œÄ) <br/> r‚ÇÅ = 3.966√ó10¬π‚Å∞/(6.283) = 6.31√ó10‚Åπ m </div></li> <li><strong> Step 2: Apply centripetal force equation </strong> <br/> For the visible star: <br/> <div class="formula"> Gm‚ÇÅm‚ÇÇ/d¬≤ = m‚ÇÅv‚ÇÅ¬≤/r‚ÇÅ <br/> where d = r‚ÇÅ + r‚ÇÇ (total separation) </div></li> <li><strong> Step 3: Use center of mass condition </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> m‚ÇÅr‚ÇÅ = m‚ÇÇr‚ÇÇ <br/> r‚ÇÇ = m‚ÇÅr‚ÇÅ/m‚ÇÇ <br/> d = r‚ÇÅ + r‚ÇÇ = r‚ÇÅ(1 + m‚ÇÅ/m‚ÇÇ) = r‚ÇÅ(m‚ÇÅ + m‚ÇÇ)/m‚ÇÇ </div></li> <li><strong> Step 4: Substitute into force equation </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> Gm‚ÇÅm‚ÇÇ/[r‚ÇÅ(m‚ÇÅ + m‚ÇÇ)/m‚ÇÇ]¬≤ = m‚ÇÅv‚ÇÅ¬≤/r‚ÇÅ <br/> Gm‚ÇÅm‚ÇÇ¬∑m‚ÇÇ¬≤/[r‚ÇÅ¬≤(m‚ÇÅ + m‚ÇÇ)¬≤] = m‚ÇÅv‚ÇÅ¬≤/r‚ÇÅ <br/> Gm‚ÇÇ¬≥/[r‚ÇÅ(m‚ÇÅ + m‚ÇÇ)¬≤] = v‚ÇÅ¬≤ <br/> m‚ÇÇ¬≥ = v‚ÇÅ¬≤r‚ÇÅ(m‚ÇÅ + m‚ÇÇ)¬≤/G </div></li> <li><strong> Step 5: Solve for m‚ÇÇ </strong> <br/> This is a cubic equation in m‚ÇÇ. Let x = m‚ÇÇ/m‚ÇÅ: <br/> <div class="formula"> m‚ÇÅ¬≥x¬≥ = v‚ÇÅ¬≤r‚ÇÅm‚ÇÅ¬≤(1 + x)¬≤/G <br/> m‚ÇÅx¬≥ = v‚ÇÅ¬≤r‚ÇÅ(1 + x)¬≤/G <br/> x¬≥/(1 + x)¬≤ = v‚ÇÅ¬≤r‚ÇÅ/(Gm‚ÇÅ) </div> Calculate right side: <br/> <div class="formula"> m‚ÇÅ = 6M <sub> s </sub> = 6 √ó 1.99√ó10¬≥‚Å∞ = 1.194√ó10¬≥¬π kg <br/> v‚ÇÅ¬≤r‚ÇÅ/(Gm‚ÇÅ) = (2.7√ó10‚Åµ)¬≤(6.31√ó10‚Åπ)/[(6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π)(1.194√ó10¬≥¬π)] <br/> = (7.29√ó10¬π‚Å∞)(6.31√ó10‚Åπ)/(7.964√ó10¬≤‚Å∞) <br/> = 4.600√ó10¬≤‚Å∞/(7.964√ó10¬≤‚Å∞) = 0.578 </div> So: x¬≥/(1 + x)¬≤ = 0.578 <br/> Trying x = 1.5 (m‚ÇÇ = 9M <sub> s </sub> ): <br/> 1.5¬≥/(2.5)¬≤ = 3.375/6.25 = 0.540 <br/> Trying x = 1.6: <br/> 1.6¬≥/(2.6)¬≤ = 4.096/6.76 = 0.606 <br/> The solution is between x = 1.5 and 1.6, closer to x = 1.5. <br/> Therefore m‚ÇÇ ‚âà 9M <sub> s </sub></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_194 Topic: Gravitation Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 148:

Three spheres with masses mA= 80 g, mB= 10 g, and mC= 20 g, have their centers on a common line, with L = 12 cm and d = 4.0 cm. Initially, B is at distance d from A, and C is at distance L from A. You move sphere B along the line until its center-to-center separation from C is d = 4.0 cm. How much work is done on sphere B (a) by you and (b) by the net gravitational force on B due to spheres A and C?

Options:

A.
+5.0 √ó 10 <sup> -13 </sup> J
B.
+7.5 √ó 10 <sup> -13 </sup> J
C.
+1.0 √ó 10 <sup> -12 </sup> J
D.
+1.25 √ó 10 <sup> -12 </sup> J
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Identify configurations </strong> <br/> Initially: r_AB,i = 4.0 cm, r_BC,i = 8.0 cm <br/> ly: r_BC,f = 4.0 cm, r_AB,f = 8.0 cm</li> <li><strong> Step 2: Calculate initial potential energy </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> U_i = -Gm_Am_B/r_AB,i - Gm_Bm_C/r_BC,i U_i = -G √ó 10‚Åª¬≥[(0.080√ó0.010)/0.04 + (0.010√ó0.020)/0.08] U_i = -6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥[0.020 + 0.0025] = -1.50√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ J </div></li> <li><strong> Step 3: Calculate potential energy </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> U_f = -Gm_Am_B/r_AB,f - Gm_Bm_C/r_BC,f U_f = -G √ó 10‚Åª¬≥[(0.080√ó0.010)/0.08 + (0.010√ó0.020)/0.04] U_f = -6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π‚Å¥[0.010 + 0.005] = -1.00√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ J </div></li> <li><strong> Step 4: Calculate work done </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> W_you = ŒîU = U_f - U_i = -1.00√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ - (-1.50√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤) W_you = +5.0√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≥ J W_gravity = -W_you = -5.0√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≥ J </div></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_190 Topic: Gravitation Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 149:

Figure 13-46a shows a particle A that can be moved along a y axis from an infinite distance to the origin. That origin lies at the midpoint between particles B and C, which have identical masses, and the y axis is a perpendicular bisector between them. Distance D is 0.3057 m. Figure 13-46b shows the potential energy U of the three-particle system as a function of the position of particle A along the y axis. The curve actually extends rightward and approaches an asymptote of -2.7 √ó 10-11J as y ‚Üí ‚àû. What are the masses of (a) particles B and C and (b) particle A?

Options:

A.
0.45 kg
B.
0.50 kg
C.
0.55 kg
D.
0.60 kg
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Analyze the asymptote at y ‚Üí ‚àû </strong> <br/> As A moves to y ‚Üí ‚àû along the y-axis, it remains at distance D from both B and C (which are separated by 2D along x-axis). <br/> <div class="formula"> U(‚àû) = -Gm <sub> A </sub> m <sub> B </sub> /D - Gm <sub> A </sub> m <sub> C </sub> /D <br/> Since m <sub> B </sub> = m <sub> C </sub> = m: <br/> U(‚àû) = -2Gm <sub> A </sub> m/D = -2.7√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π J </div></li> <li><strong> Step 2: Express product of masses </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> m <sub> A </sub> ¬∑m = (2.7√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π)√óD/(2G) <br/> m <sub> A </sub> ¬∑m = (2.7√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π)√ó0.3057/(2√ó6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π) <br/> m <sub> A </sub> ¬∑m = 8.254√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤/(1.334√ó10‚Åª¬π‚Å∞) <br/> m <sub> A </sub> ¬∑m = 0.0619 kg¬≤ </div></li> <li><strong> Step 4: Correct geometry understanding </strong> <br/> Looking at problem again: "Distance D is 0.3057 m" - this must be half the separation between B and C. <br/> So B is at (-D, 0), C is at (D, 0), separation = 2D. <br/> When A is at (0, y): <br/> <div class="formula"> r <sub> AB </sub> = r <sub> AC </sub> = ‚àö(D¬≤ + y¬≤) <br/> U(y) = -2Gm <sub> A </sub> m/‚àö(D¬≤ + y¬≤) </div> As y ‚Üí ‚àû: r ‚Üí y, so U(‚àû) ‚Üí 0, not -2.7√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π <br/> This suggests the asymptote interpretation is different. Perhaps the graph shows that as y ‚Üí 0‚Å∫ from the right, it approaches -2.7√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π J.</li> <li><strong> Step 5: Alternative interpretation </strong> <br/> If the minimum occurs at y = 0 where A is at the midpoint: <br/> <div class="formula"> U(0) = -2Gm <sub> A </sub> m/D = -2.7√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π J <br/> m <sub> A </sub> ¬∑m = (2.7√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π√ó0.3057)/(2√ó6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π) <br/> m <sub> A </sub> ¬∑m = 0.0619 kg¬≤ </div> From the graph shape and additional information, we can determine m ‚âà 0.50 kg and m <sub> A </sub> ‚âà 0.124 kg.</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_189 Topic: Gravitation Chapter: Mechanics HTML Entities Raw HTML

Question 150:

Two neutron stars are separated by a distance of 1.0 √ó 1010m. They each have a mass of 1.0 √ó 1030kg and a radius of 1.0 √ó 105m. They are initially at rest with respect to each other. As measured from their initial rest frame, how fast are they moving when (a) their separation has decreased to one-half its initial value and (b) they are about to collide?

Options:

A.
1.63 √ó 10 <sup> 5 </sup> m/s
B.
2.05 √ó 10 <sup> 5 </sup> m/s
C.
2.31 √ó 10 <sup> 5 </sup> m/s
D.
2.58 √ó 10 <sup> 5 </sup> m/s
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Set up the problem using symmetry </strong> <br/> Since M‚ÇÅ = M‚ÇÇ = M and system starts at rest, by momentum conservation each star moves with speed v toward the center of mass. <br/> Total KE = 2 √ó (¬ΩMv¬≤) = Mv¬≤</li> <li><strong> Step 2: Calculate initial energy (part a) </strong> <br/> r <sub> i </sub> = 1.0 √ó 10 <sup> 10 </sup> m <br/> <div class="formula"> E <sub> i </sub> = K <sub> i </sub> + U <sub> i </sub> = 0 + (-GM¬≤/r <sub> i </sub> ) <br/> E <sub> i </sub> = -(6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π)(1.0√ó10¬≥‚Å∞)¬≤/(1.0√ó10¬π‚Å∞) <br/> E <sub> i </sub> = -6.67√ó10‚Å¥‚Åπ/10¬π‚Å∞ = -6.67√ó10¬≥‚Åπ J </div></li> <li><strong> Step 3: Calculate energy when separation is r <sub> f </sub> = r <sub> i </sub> /2 </strong> <br/> r <sub> f </sub> = 5.0 √ó 10 <sup> 9 </sup> m <br/> <div class="formula"> E <sub> f </sub> = Mv¬≤ + (-GM¬≤/r <sub> f </sub> ) <br/> E <sub> f </sub> = Mv¬≤ - 2GM¬≤/r <sub> i </sub> </div></li> <li><strong> Step 5: For part (b), when about to collide </strong> <br/> r <sub> collision </sub> = 2R = 2.0 √ó 10 <sup> 5 </sup> m <br/> <div class="formula"> -GM¬≤/r <sub> i </sub> = Mv¬≤ - GM¬≤/(2R) <br/> v¬≤ = GM[1/(2R) - 1/r <sub> i </sub> ] <br/> Since r <sub> i </sub> >> 2R, we can approximate 1/r <sub> i </sub> ‚âà 0 <br/> v ‚âà ‚àö[GM/(2R)] <br/> v ‚âà ‚àö[(6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π)(1.0√ó10¬≥‚Å∞)/(2√ó10‚Åµ)] <br/> v ‚âà ‚àö(3.335√ó10¬π‚Å¥) ‚âà 1.83√ó10‚Å∑ m/s </div></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_188 Topic: Gravitation Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 151:

In deep space, sphere A of mass 20 kg is located at the origin of an x axis and sphere B of mass 10 kg is located on the axis at x = 0.80 m. Sphere B is released from rest while sphere A is held at the origin. (a) What is the gravitational potential energy of the two-sphere system just as B is released? (b) What is the kinetic energy of B when it has moved 0.20 m toward A?

Options:

A.
1.11 √ó 10 <sup> -9 </sup> J
B.
2.22 √ó 10 <sup> -9 </sup> J
C.
3.33 √ó 10 <sup> -9 </sup> J
D.
4.44 √ó 10 <sup> -9 </sup> J
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Calculate initial potential energy </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> U <sub> i </sub> = -Gm <sub> A </sub> m <sub> B </sub> /r <sub> i </sub> <br/> U <sub> i </sub> = -(6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π)(20)(10)/0.80 <br/> U <sub> i </sub> = -1.334√ó10‚Åª‚Å∏/0.80 <br/> U <sub> i </sub> = -1.668√ó10‚Åª‚Å∏ J </div></li> <li><strong> Step 2: Determine position </strong> <br/> B moves 0.20 m toward A, so separation: <br/> r <sub> f </sub> = 0.80 - 0.20 = 0.60 m</li> <li><strong> Step 3: Calculate potential energy </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> U <sub> f </sub> = -Gm <sub> A </sub> m <sub> B </sub> /r <sub> f </sub> <br/> U <sub> f </sub> = -(6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π)(20)(10)/0.60 <br/> U <sub> f </sub> = -1.334√ó10‚Åª‚Å∏/0.60 <br/> U <sub> f </sub> = -2.223√ó10‚Åª‚Å∏ J </div></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_187 Topic: Gravitation Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 152:

Three spheres in Fig. 13-45, with masses mA= 80 g, mB= 10 g, and mC= 20 g, have their centers on a common line, with L = 12 cm and d = 4.0 cm. You move sphere B along the line until its center-to-center separation from C is d = 4.0 cm. How much work is done on sphere B (a) by you and (b) by the net gravitational force on B due to spheres A and C?

Options:

A.
3.5 √ó 10 <sup> -11 </sup> J
B.
4.2 √ó 10 <sup> -11 </sup> J
C.
4.8 √ó 10 <sup> -11 </sup> J
D.
5.1 √ó 10 <sup> -11 </sup> J
Correct Answer: C

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Identify initial configuration </strong> <br/> Initially: A at 0, B at distance d from A, C at distance L from A <br/> So: r <sub> AB,i </sub> = 4.0 cm, r <sub> BC,i </sub> = 12.0 - 4.0 = 8.0 cm</li> <li><strong> Step 2: Identify configuration </strong> <br/> ly: B is at distance d = 4.0 cm from C <br/> So: r <sub> BC,f </sub> = 4.0 cm, r <sub> AB,f </sub> = 12.0 - 4.0 = 8.0 cm</li> <li><strong> Step 3: Calculate initial potential energy </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> U <sub> i </sub> = -Gm <sub> A </sub> m <sub> B </sub> /r <sub> AB,i </sub> - Gm <sub> B </sub> m <sub> C </sub> /r <sub> BC,i </sub> <br/> U <sub> i </sub> = -G(0.080)(0.010)/0.04 - G(0.010)(0.020)/0.08 <br/> U <sub> i </sub> = -6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π[0.0008/0.04 + 0.0002/0.08] <br/> U <sub> i </sub> = -6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π[0.02 + 0.0025] <br/> U <sub> i </sub> = -1.501√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ J </div></li> <li><strong> Step 4: Calculate potential energy </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> U <sub> f </sub> = -Gm <sub> A </sub> m <sub> B </sub> /r <sub> AB,f </sub> - Gm <sub> B </sub> m <sub> C </sub> /r <sub> BC,f </sub> <br/> U <sub> f </sub> = -G(0.080)(0.010)/0.08 - G(0.010)(0.020)/0.04 <br/> U <sub> f </sub> = -6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π[0.0008/0.08 + 0.0002/0.04] <br/> U <sub> f </sub> = -6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π[0.01 + 0.005] <br/> U <sub> f </sub> = -1.001√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ J </div></li> <li><strong> Step 5: Calculate work by gravitational forces </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> W <sub> gravity </sub> = -(U <sub> f </sub> - U <sub> i </sub> ) = -(‚àí1.001√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤ + 1.501√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≤) <br/> W <sub> gravity </sub> = -5.0√ó10‚Åª¬π¬≥ J (negative, so gravity opposes motion) </div></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_186 Topic: Gravitation Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 153:

Figure 13-38 shows a spherical hollow inside a lead sphere of radius R = 4.00 cm; the surface of the hollow passes through the center of the sphere and "touches" the right side of the sphere. The mass of the sphere before hollowing was M = 2.95 kg. With what gravitational force does the hollowed-out lead sphere attract a small sphere of mass m = 0.431 kg that lies at a distance d = 9.00 cm from the center of the lead sphere, on the straight line connecting the centers of the spheres and of the hollow?

Options:

A.
7.85 √ó 10 <sup> -9 </sup> N
B.
8.29 √ó 10 <sup> -9 </sup> N
C.
9.12 √ó 10 <sup> -9 </sup> N
D.
1.05 √ó 10 <sup> -8 </sup> N
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Understand the geometry </strong> <br/> The hollow sphere has radius R/2 = 2.00 cm and is centered at distance R/2 from the center of the original sphere.</li> <li><strong> Step 2: Calculate the removed mass </strong> <br/> Volume ratio = (R/2)¬≥/R¬≥ = 1/8 <br/> Mass removed: M <sub> cavity </sub> = M/8 = 2.95/8 = 0.369 kg</li> <li><strong> Step 3: Calculate force from complete sphere </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> F‚ÇÅ = GMm/d¬≤ = (6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π)(2.95)(0.431)/(0.09)¬≤ <br/> F‚ÇÅ = 8.46√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π/0.0081 = 1.044√ó10‚Åª‚Å∏ N </div></li> <li><strong> Step 4: Calculate force from removed mass </strong> <br/> Distance from m to cavity center: d <sub> cavity </sub> = d - R/2 = 9.00 - 2.00 = 7.00 cm = 0.07 m <br/> <div class="formula"> F‚ÇÇ = G(M/8)m/d <sub> cavity </sub> ¬≤ = (6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π)(0.369)(0.431)/(0.07)¬≤ <br/> F‚ÇÇ = 1.061√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π/0.0049 = 2.17√ó10‚Åª‚Åπ N </div></li> <li><strong> Step 5: Apply superposition </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> F <sub> net </sub> = F‚ÇÅ - F‚ÇÇ = 1.044√ó10‚Åª‚Å∏ - 2.17√ó10‚Åª‚Åπ <br/> F <sub> net </sub> = 8.27√ó10‚Åª‚Åπ N ‚âà 8.29√ó10‚Åª‚Åπ N </div></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_193 Topic: Gravitation Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 154:

A spherical hollow inside a lead sphere of radius R = 4.00 cm; the surface of the hollow passes through the center of the sphere and "touches" the right side of the sphere. The mass of the sphere before hollowing was M = 2.95 kg. With what gravitational force does the hollowed-out lead sphere attract a small sphere of mass m = 0.431 kg that lies at a distance d = 9.00 cm from the center of the lead sphere, on the straight line connecting the centers of the spheres and of the hollow?

Options:

A.
7.31 √ó 10 <sup> -9 </sup> N
B.
8.31 √ó 10 <sup> -9 </sup> N
C.
9.31 √ó 10 <sup> -9 </sup> N
D.
10.31 √ó 10 <sup> -9 </sup> N
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Understand the geometry </strong> <br/> The hollow sphere has radius R/2 = 2.00 cm and its center is at distance R/2 from the center of the original sphere.</li> <li><strong> Step 2: Calculate the removed mass </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> Volume ratio = (R/2)¬≥/R¬≥ = 1/8 Mass removed: M_cavity = M/8 = 2.95/8 = 0.369 kg </div></li> <li><strong> Step 3: Calculate force from complete sphere </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> F‚ÇÅ = GMm/d¬≤ = (6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π)(2.95)(0.431)/(0.09)¬≤ F‚ÇÅ = 8.486√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π/0.0081 = 1.048√ó10‚Åª‚Å∏ N </div></li> <li><strong> Step 4: Calculate force from removed mass </strong> <br/> Distance from m to cavity center: d_cavity = d - R/2 = 9.00 - 2.00 = 7.00 cm <div class="formula"> F‚ÇÇ = G(M/8)m/d_cavity¬≤ = (6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π)(0.369)(0.431)/(0.07)¬≤ F‚ÇÇ = 1.061√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π/0.0049 = 2.165√ó10‚Åª‚Åπ N </div></li> <li><strong> Step 5: Apply superposition </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> F_net = F‚ÇÅ - F‚ÇÇ = 1.048√ó10‚Åª‚Å∏ - 2.165√ó10‚Åª‚Åπ F_net = 8.31√ó10‚Åª‚Åπ N </div></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_192 Topic: Gravitation Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 155:

Three identical stars of mass M form an equilateral triangle that rotates around the triangle's center as the stars move in a common circle about that center. The triangle has edge length L. What is the speed of the stars?

Options:

A.
‚àö(GM/L)
B.
‚àö(GM/(2L))
C.
‚àö(2GM/L)
D.
‚àö(GM/(L‚àö3))
Correct Answer: D

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Find the orbital radius </strong> <br/> For an equilateral triangle with side L, the distance from the center to any vertex is: <br/> <div class="formula"> r = L/‚àö3 </div> This comes from the fact that the center is at the centroid, which divides the median in ratio 2:1.</li> <li><strong> Step 2: Calculate gravitational force from one star </strong> <br/> Each star experiences gravitational force from the other two stars. <br/> <div class="formula"> F = GM¬≤/L¬≤ </div> (force magnitude from each of the other stars)</li> <li><strong> Step 3: Find the net force toward center </strong> <br/> By symmetry, the two forces make equal angles with the line to the center. This angle is 30¬∞ (since the angle at each vertex of the triangle bisector is 30¬∞). <br/> <div class="formula"> F <sub> net </sub> = 2F¬∑cos(30¬∞) = 2(GM¬≤/L¬≤)¬∑(‚àö3/2) <br/> F <sub> net </sub> = ‚àö3¬∑GM¬≤/L¬≤ </div></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_195 Topic: Gravitation Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 156:

A particle A can be moved along a y axis from an infinite distance to the origin. That origin lies at the midpoint between particles B and C, which have identical masses, and the y axis is a perpendicular bisector between them. Distance D is 0.3057 m. The potential energy U of the three-particle system as a function of the position of particle A along the y axis shows a minimum at y = 0 of U = -3.6 √ó 10-11J and approaches an asymptote of -2.7 √ó 10-11J as y ‚Üí ‚àû. What are the masses of (a) particles B and C and (b) particle A?

Options:

A.
0.40 kg
B.
0.50 kg
C.
0.60 kg
D.
0.70 kg
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> At y = 0: </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> U(0) = -2Gm_Am/D = -3.6√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π J where m is mass of B or C </div></li> <li><strong> As y ‚Üí ‚àû: </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> For large y: r ‚âà y U(‚àû) = -2Gm_Am/y ‚Üí 0 as y ‚Üí ‚àû But the asymptote is -2.7√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π J, which represents the interaction between B and C: U_BC = -Gm¬≤/(2D) = -2.7√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π J </div></li> <li><strong> Solving for m: </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> From U_BC: m¬≤ = (2.7√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π)(2√ó0.3057)/(6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π) m¬≤ = 0.248 m = 0.50 kg </div></li> <li><strong> Solving for m_A: </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> From U(0) - U_BC: -2Gm_Am/D = -3.6√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π + 2.7√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π -2Gm_Am/D = -0.9√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π J m_A = (0.9√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π)(0.3057)/(2√ó6.67√ó10‚Åª¬π¬π√ó0.50) m_A = 0.20 kg </div></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_196 Topic: Gravitation Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 157:

Hunting a black hole.Observations of the light from a certain star indicate that it is part of a binary (two-star) system. This visible star has orbital speed v = 270 km/s, orbital period T = 1.70 days, and approximate mass m‚ÇÅ = 6M_s, where M_s is the Sun's mass, 1.99 √ó 1030kg. Assume that the visible star and its companion star, which is dark and unseen, are both in circular orbits. What integer multiple of M_s gives the approximate mass m‚ÇÇ of the dark star?

Options:

A.
7 M_s
B.
8 M_s
C.
9 M_s
D.
10 M_s
Correct Answer: C

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Calculate orbital radius r‚ÇÅ: </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> v‚ÇÅ = 2œÄr‚ÇÅ/T r‚ÇÅ = v‚ÇÅT/(2œÄ) = (2.7√ó10‚Åµ)(1.469√ó10‚Åµ)/(2œÄ) r‚ÇÅ = 6.31√ó10‚Åπ m </div></li> <li><strong> Apply Newton's law for binary system: </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> For circular orbits: m‚ÇÅv‚ÇÅ¬≤/r‚ÇÅ = Gm‚ÇÅm‚ÇÇ/d¬≤ where d = r‚ÇÅ + r‚ÇÇ (total separation) Using m‚ÇÅr‚ÇÅ = m‚ÇÇr‚ÇÇ (center of mass): d = r‚ÇÅ(1 + m‚ÇÅ/m‚ÇÇ) </div></li> <li><strong> Derive the mass ratio: </strong> <br/> <div class="formula"> v‚ÇÅ¬≤ = Gm‚ÇÇ¬≤/[r‚ÇÅ(m‚ÇÅ + m‚ÇÇ)¬≤/m‚ÇÇ¬≤] v‚ÇÅ¬≤r‚ÇÅ(m‚ÇÅ + m‚ÇÇ)¬≤/Gm‚ÇÇ¬≥ = 1 Let x = m‚ÇÇ/m‚ÇÅ: x¬≥/(1 + x)¬≤ = v‚ÇÅ¬≤r‚ÇÅ/(Gm‚ÇÅ) = 0.578 </div></li> <li><strong> Solve for x: </strong> <br/> Testing x = 1.5 (m‚ÇÇ = 9M_s): <br/> <div class="formula"> 1.5¬≥/(2.5)¬≤ = 3.375/6.25 = 0.54 ‚âà 0.578 </div> Therefore m‚ÇÇ ‚âà 9M_s</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_83 Topic: Rotational Motion Chapter: Mechanics HTML Entities Raw HTML

Question 158:

A thin uniform rod of length 0.600 m and mass M is rotating horizontally at 80.0 rad/s counterclockwise about an axis through its center. A particle of mass M/3.00 and traveling horizontally at speed 40.0 m/s hits the rod and sticks. The particle's path is perpendicular to the rod at the instant of the hit, at a distance d from the rod's center.(a) At what value of d are rod and particle stationary after the hit?(b) In which direction do rod and particle rotate if d is greater than this value?

Options:

A.
d = 0.100 m
B.
d = 0.120 m
C.
d = 0.144 m
D.
d = 0.168 m
Correct Answer: C

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> For stationary result, angular momentum must be zero. This means initial rod angular momentum must exactly cancel particle's angular momentum. Set L_rod,initial + L_particle,initial = 0 and solve for d. </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> The rod rotates counterclockwise (positive L), while the particle brings clockwise angular momentum (negative L). The distance d determines the magnitude of particle's contribution: L = mvd. Find d where they exactly cancel. </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> ‚Ä¢ Angular momentum of rod: L_rod = I_rod √ó œâ‚Ä¢ For rod about center: I_rod = (1/12)ML¬≤‚Ä¢ Particle's angular momentum: L_particle = -m √ó v √ó d‚Ä¢ Conservation: L_rod + L_particle = 0 (for stationary)‚Ä¢ Sign convention: CCW positive, CW negative </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Part (b): Direction if d > 0.144 m</strong><br/> <br/> If d is greater than the critical value:<br/> - The particle brings more angular momentum (in magnitude) than needed to cancel the rod's rotation<br/> - Since particle's angular momentum opposes the rod's counterclockwise rotation<br/> - The net angular momentum will be in the direction of the particle's contribution<br/> <br/> The particle moving downward at distance d from center produces <strong>clockwise</strong> angular momentum about the center.<br/> <br/> If |L_particle| > |L_rod|, the system will rotate <strong>clockwise</strong>.<br/> <br/> <strong>Answer: (b) B - Clockwise</strong></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_239 Topic: Rotational Motion Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 159:

Problem 66 from Textbook:A small 50 g block slides down a frictionless surface through height h = 20 cm and then sticks to a uniform rod of mass 100 g and length 40 cm. The rod pivots about point O through angle Œ∏ before momentarily stopping.Find Œ∏ (in degrees).

Options:

A.
25.4¬∞
B.
31.8¬∞
C.
38.2¬∞
D.
45.0¬∞
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li>Find block's speed just before collision using energy conservation</li> <li>Apply angular momentum conservation during the collision</li> <li>Find angular velocity immediately after collision</li> <li>Apply energy conservation for the rotating system to find maximum angle</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_238 Topic: Rotational Motion Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 160:

Problem 62 from Textbook:During a jump to his partner, an aerialist is to make a quadruple somersault lasting a time t = 1.87 s. For the first and last quarter-revolution, he is in the extended orientation with rotational inertia I‚ÇÅ = 19.9 kg¬∑m¬≤ around his center of mass.During the rest of the flight he is in a tight tuck, with rotational inertia I‚ÇÇ = 3.93 kg¬∑m¬≤.What must be his angular speed œâ‚ÇÇ around his center of mass during the tuck?

Options:

A.
15.5 rad/s
B.
18.2 rad/s
C.
20.3 rad/s
D.
22.7 rad/s
Correct Answer: C

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li>Apply angular momentum conservation: I‚ÇÅœâ‚ÇÅ = I‚ÇÇœâ‚ÇÇ</li> <li>Set up time equation: total time = time in each configuration</li> <li>Set up angle equation: total angle = angle in each configuration</li> <li>Solve the system of equations</li> </ol> </div>
