Question 161:

Problem 53 from Textbook:A uniform thin rod of length 0.500 m and mass 4.00 kg can rotate in a horizontal plane about a vertical axis through its center. The rod is at rest when a 3.00 g bullet traveling in the rotation plane is fired into one end of the rod.In the view from above, the bullet's path makes angle Œ∏ = 60.0¬∞ with the rod. If the bullet lodges in the rod and the angular velocity of the rod is 10 rad/s immediately after the collision, what is the bullet's speed just before impact?

Options:

A.
850 m/s
B.
1050 m/s
C.
1286 m/s
D.
1520 m/s
Correct Answer: C

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li>Identify the axis of rotation</li> <li>Calculate moment of inertia before and after collision</li> <li>Express angular momentum before collision (point mass)</li> <li>Express angular momentum after collision (rotating system)</li> <li>Apply conservation of angular momentum</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_27 Topic: Rotational Motion Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 162:

Problem Statement:A small 50 g block slides down a frictionless surface through height h = 20 cm and then sticks to a uniform rod of mass 100 g and length 40 cm. The rod pivots about point O through angle Œ∏ before momentarily stopping.Block Sliding and Colliding with Pivoting RodStage 1: Initialm = 50 gh = 20 cmStage 2: Before CollisionvM = 100 g, L = 40 cmPivot OStage 3: After CollisionŒ∏System swings up and stopsFind the angle Œ∏ through which the rod rotatesUse energy conservation, then angular momentum, then energy againFind the angle Œ∏.Given:Block mass: m = 50 g = 0.050 kgInitial height: h = 20 cm = 0.20 mRod mass: M = 100 g = 0.100 kgRod length: L = 40 cm = 0.40 mFrictionless surfaceTake g = 9.8 m/s¬≤

Options:

A.
Œ∏ = 18.5¬∞
B.
Œ∏ = 24.3¬∞
C.
Œ∏ = 31.8¬∞
D.
Œ∏ = 38.7¬∞
Correct Answer: C

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> Three-stage problem: (1) Energy conservation for sliding, (2) Angular momentum conservation for collision, (3) Energy conservation for rotation.Three-Stage SolutionStage 1: SlidingEnergy conservation:mgh = ¬Ωmv¬≤v = ‚àö(2gh)v = 1.980 m/sStage 2: CollisionAngular momentum:mvL = (I_rod + I_block)œâI_total = ‚ÖìML¬≤ + mL¬≤œâ = 2.970 rad/sStage 3: RotationEnergy conservation:¬ΩIœâ¬≤ = (M+m)g√óŒîhŒîh = y_cm(1-cos Œ∏)Œ∏ = 31.8¬∞Detailed Calculations:Step 1:v = ‚àö(2√ó9.8√ó0.20) = 1.980 m/sStep 2:I_rod = ‚ÖìML¬≤ = ‚Öì(0.100)(0.40)¬≤ = 0.00533 kg¬∑m¬≤L_before = mvL = 0.050√ó1.980√ó0.40 = 0.0396 kg¬∑m¬≤/sI_total = 0.00533 + 0.050√ó(0.40)¬≤ = 0.01333 kg¬∑m¬≤œâ = 0.0396/0.01333 = 2.970 rad/sStep 3:KE = ¬Ω(0.01333)(2.970)¬≤ = 0.0588 Jy_cm = [M(L/2) + mL]/(M+m) = [0.100√ó0.20 + 0.050√ó0.40]/0.150= 0.040/0.150 = 0.2667 mEnergy: 0.0588 = 0.150√ó9.8√ó0.2667√ó(1-cos Œ∏)1-cos Œ∏ = 0.1499 ‚Üí cos Œ∏ = 0.8501Œ∏ = arccos(0.8501) = 31.79¬∞ ‚âà 31.8¬∞ ‚úì </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_26 Topic: Rotational Motion Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 163:

Problem Statement:Two 2.00 kg balls are attached to the ends of a thin rod of length 50.0 cm and negligible mass. The rod is free to rotate in a vertical plane without friction about a horizontal axis through its center.With the rod initially horizontal, a 50.0 g wad of wet putty drops onto one of the balls, hitting it with a speed of 3.00 m/s and then sticking to it.Putty Collision with Rotating Rod SystemBefore Collision:PivotM = 2.00 kgM = 2.00 kgL = 50.0 cmv = 3.00 m/sm = 50 gAfter Collision:œâSystem rotates upwardDetermine:(a) Angular speed œâ immediately after collision(b) Ratio of KE_after / KE_before(c) Angle Œ∏ through which system rotates before stoppingDetermine:What is the angular speed immediately after the putty hits?What is the ratio of KEafter/ KEbefore?Through what angle will the system rotate before momentarily stopping?Given:Ball mass: M = 2.00 kg (each)Rod length: L = 50.0 cm = 0.500 mPutty mass: m = 50.0 g = 0.050 kgPutty velocity: v = 3.00 m/s (downward)Rod initially horizontalTake g = 9.8 m/s¬≤

Options:

A.
(a) œâ = 0.148 rad/s<br/> (b) Ratio = 0.0123<br/> (c) Œ∏ = 5.42¬∞
B.
(a) œâ = 0.296 rad/s<br/> (b) Ratio = 0.0246<br/> (c) Œ∏ = 10.8¬∞
C.
(a) œâ = 0.185 rad/s<br/> (b) Ratio = 0.0308<br/> (c) Œ∏ = 13.5¬∞
D.
(a) œâ = 0.222 rad/s<br/> (b) Ratio = 0.0431<br/> (c) Œ∏ = 16.2¬∞
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> Three-stage problem: (1) Angular momentum conservation for collision, (2) Energy ratio calculation, (3) Energy conservation for rotation.Solution AnalysisPart (a): CollisionInitial: L = mvr = 0.050√ó3.00√ó0.250: I_total = 2M(L/2)¬≤ + m(L/2)¬≤0.0375 = 0.2531√óœâœâ = 0.148 rad/s ‚úìPart (b): Energy RatioKE_before = ¬Ωmv¬≤ = ¬Ω(0.050)(3.00)¬≤= 0.225 JKE_after = ¬ΩIœâ¬≤ = ¬Ω(0.2531)(0.148)¬≤= 0.00278 JRatio = 0.0123 ‚úìPart (c): Rotational MotionMM+my_cmCenter of mass position:y_cm = m(L/2)/(2M+m) = 0.050√ó0.250/4.05= 0.00309 m from pivotEnergy conservation (rotation):KE = (2M+m)g √ó y_cm √ó (1-cos Œ∏)0.00278 = 4.05√ó9.8√ó0.00309√ó(1-cos Œ∏)1-cos Œ∏ = 0.0227 ‚Üí cos Œ∏ = 0.9773Œ∏ = 5.42¬∞ ‚úì </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Part (a): œâ after collision</strong><br/> <span class="math">I_initial = 2M(L/2)¬≤ = 0.250 kg¬∑m¬≤</span><br/> <span class="math">L_putty = mvr = 0.050√ó3.00√ó0.250 = 0.0375 kg¬∑m¬≤/s</span><br/> <span class="math">I_= (2M+m)(L/2)¬≤ = 0.2531 kg¬∑m¬≤</span><br/> <span class="math">œâ = 0.0375/0.2531 = 0.148 rad/s ‚úì</span></li> <li><strong>Part (b): Energy ratio</strong><br/> <span class="math">KE_before = ¬Ω(0.050)(3.00)¬≤ = 0.225 J</span><br/> <span class="math">KE_after = ¬Ω(0.2531)(0.148)¬≤ = 0.00278 J</span><br/> <span class="math">Ratio = 0.00278/0.225 = 0.0123 ‚úì</span></li> <li><strong>Part (c): Rotation angle</strong><br/> <span class="math">y_cm = 0.050√ó0.250/4.05 = 0.00309 m</span><br/> <span class="math">0.00278 = 4.05√ó9.8√ó0.00309√ó(1-cos Œ∏)</span><br/> <span class="math">Œ∏ = arccos(0.9773) = 5.42¬∞ ‚úì</span></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_24 Topic: Rotational Motion Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 164:

Problem Statement:A bowler throws a bowling ball of radius R = 11 cm along a lane. The ball (initially) slides on the lane with initial speed vcom,0= 8.5 m/s and initial angular speed œâ0= 0.The coefficient of kinetic friction between the ball and the lane is 0.21. The kinetic frictional force acting on the ball causes a linear deceleration of the ball while producing a torque that causes an angular acceleration of the ball.When speed vcomhas decreased enough and angular speed œâ has increased enough, the ball stops sliding and then rolls smoothly.Bowling Ball: Sliding to Rolling TransitionInitial State (Sliding):v‚ÇÄ = 8.5 m/sœâ‚ÇÄ = 0f = Œº‚ÇñMgFinal State (Rolling):œâv = 6.07 m/sv = œâRSliding Phaset = 1.18 s, d = 8.60 mDetermine:What is vcom(in terms of œâ) when smooth rolling begins?What is the ball's linear acceleration during sliding?What is the ball's angular acceleration during sliding?How long does the ball slide?How far does the ball slide?What is the linear speed when smooth rolling begins?Given:Ball radius: R = 11 cm = 0.11 mInitial linear velocity: v0= 8.5 m/sInitial angular velocity: œâ0= 0Coefficient of kinetic friction: Œºk= 0.21For a solid sphere: I = (2/5)MR¬≤Take g = 9.8 m/s¬≤

Options:

A.
<strong>Part (a):</strong> v<sub>com</sub> = œâR<br/> <strong>Part (b):</strong> |a| = 2.06 m/s¬≤<br/> <strong>Part (c):</strong> Œ± = 46.8 rad/s¬≤<br/> <strong>Part (d):</strong> t = 1.18 s<br/> <strong>Part (e):</strong> s = 8.60 m<br/> <strong>Part (f):</strong> v = 6.07 m/s
B.
<strong>Part (a):</strong> v<sub>com</sub> = 2œâR<br/> <strong>Part (b):</strong> |a| = 2.06 m/s¬≤<br/> <strong>Part (c):</strong> Œ± = 93.5 rad/s¬≤<br/> <strong>Part (d):</strong> t = 2.36 s<br/> <strong>Part (e):</strong> s = 17.2 m<br/> <strong>Part (f):</strong> v = 3.04 m/s
C.
<strong>Part (a):</strong> v<sub>com</sub> = œâR/2<br/> <strong>Part (b):</strong> |a| = 1.03 m/s¬≤<br/> <strong>Part (c):</strong> Œ± = 23.4 rad/s¬≤<br/> <strong>Part (d):</strong> t = 2.36 s<br/> <strong>Part (e):</strong> s = 17.2 m<br/> <strong>Part (f):</strong> v = 12.1 m/s
D.
<strong>Part (a):</strong> v<sub>com</sub> = œâR<br/> <strong>Part (b):</strong> |a| = 4.12 m/s¬≤<br/> <strong>Part (c):</strong> Œ± = 23.4 rad/s¬≤<br/> <strong>Part (d):</strong> t = 0.59 s<br/> <strong>Part (e):</strong> s = 4.30 m<br/> <strong>Part (f):</strong> v = 6.07 m/s
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> During sliding, friction causes linear deceleration and angular acceleration. Apply Newton's laws separately for translation and rotation. The transition to rolling occurs when v = œâR. </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Part (a): Rolling condition</strong><br/> Smooth rolling occurs when:<br/> <span class="math">v<sub>com</sub> = œâR ‚úì</span></li> <li><strong>Part (b): Linear acceleration</strong><br/> Friction opposes motion:<br/> <span class="math">-f<sub>k</sub> = Ma</span><br/> <span class="math">a = -Œº<sub>k</sub>g = -0.21 √ó 9.8 = -2.058 m/s¬≤</span><br/> <span class="math">|a| = 2.06 m/s¬≤ ‚úì</span></li> <li><strong>Part (c): Angular acceleration</strong><br/> Torque equation:<br/> <span class="math">œÑ = fR = IŒ±</span><br/> <span class="math">Œº<sub>k</sub>MgR = (2/5)MR¬≤Œ±</span><br/> <span class="math">Œ± = 5Œº<sub>k</sub>g/(2R)</span><br/> <span class="math">Œ± = 5(0.21)(9.8)/(2 √ó 0.11)</span><br/> <span class="math">Œ± = 10.29/0.22 = 46.77 rad/s¬≤</span><br/> <span class="math">Œ± = 46.8 rad/s¬≤ ‚úì</span></li> <li><strong>Part (d): Sliding time</strong><br/> Linear: <span class="math">v = v<sub>0</sub> + at = 8.5 - 2.058t</span><br/> Angular: <span class="math">œâ = œâ<sub>0</sub> + Œ±t = 0 + 46.77t</span><br/> <br/> When v = œâR:<br/> <span class="math">8.5 - 2.058t = 46.77t √ó 0.11</span><br/> <span class="math">8.5 - 2.058t = 5.145t</span><br/> <span class="math">8.5 = 7.203t</span><br/> <span class="math">t = 1.180 s ‚âà 1.18 s ‚úì</span></li> <li><strong>Part (e): Sliding distance</strong><br/> <span class="math">s = v<sub>0</sub>t + ¬Ωat¬≤</span><br/> <span class="math">s = 8.5(1.180) + ¬Ω(-2.058)(1.180)¬≤</span><br/> <span class="math">s = 10.03 - 1.432</span><br/> <span class="math">s = 8.60 m ‚úì</span></li> <li><strong>Part (f): Final speed</strong><br/> <span class="math">v = v<sub>0</sub> + at = 8.5 + (-2.058)(1.180)</span><br/> <span class="math">v = 8.5 - 2.428 = 6.072 m/s</span><br/> <span class="math">v ‚âà 6.07 m/s ‚úì</span></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_23 Topic: Rotational Motion Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 165:

Problem Statement:A non-uniform ball of massMand radiusRrolls smoothly from rest down a ramp and onto a circular loop of radius 0.48 m. The initial height of the ball ish= 0.36 m. At the loop bottom, the magnitude of the normal force on the ball is 2.00Mg.The ball consists of an outer spherical shell (of a certain uniform density) that is glued to a central sphere (of a different uniform density). The rotational inertia of the ball can be expressed in the general formI= Œ≤MR¬≤, but Œ≤ is not 0.4 as it is for a ball of uniform density.Determine the value of Œ≤.M, Rh = 0.36 mR_loop = 0.48 mN = 2MgMgBall Rolling on Loop-the-LoopInitial: v = 0, at height hAt bottom: N = 2MgGiven:Loop radius: Rloop= 0.48 mInitial height: h = 0.36 mNormal force at bottom: N = 2.00MgRotational inertia: I = Œ≤MR¬≤Ball starts from restRolling is smooth (no slipping)

Options:

A.
Œ≤ = 0.25
B.
Œ≤ = 0.40
C.
Œ≤ = 0.50
D.
Œ≤ = 0.60
Correct Answer: C

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> Use energy conservation to find velocity at the bottom of the loop, then apply Newton's second law for circular motion at that point. The normal force constraint provides the equation to solve for Œ≤. </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong>Step 1: Find velocity at bottom using force analysis</strong><br/> At the bottom, net upward force provides centripetal acceleration:<br/> <span class="math">N - Mg = Mv¬≤/R_loop</span><br/> Given N = 2.00Mg:<br/> <span class="math">2.00Mg - Mg = Mv¬≤/R_loop</span><br/> <span class="math">Mg = Mv¬≤/R_loop</span><br/> <span class="math">v¬≤ = g √ó R_loop = 9.8 √ó 0.48 = 4.704 m¬≤/s¬≤</span></li> <li><strong>Step 2: Apply energy conservation</strong><br/> Initial energy: <span class="math">E_i = Mgh</span><br/> Final energy: <span class="math">E_f = ¬ΩMv¬≤ + ¬ΩIœâ¬≤</span><br/> <br/> For rolling without slipping: <span class="math">œâ = v/R_ball</span><br/> With I = Œ≤MR¬≤_ball:<br/> <span class="math">E_f = ¬ΩMv¬≤ + ¬Ω(Œ≤MR¬≤_ball)(v/R_ball)¬≤</span><br/> <span class="math">E_f = ¬ΩMv¬≤ + ¬ΩŒ≤Mv¬≤</span><br/> <span class="math">E_f = ¬ΩMv¬≤(1 + Œ≤)</span></li> <li><strong>Step 3: Set up conservation equation</strong><br/> <span class="math">Mgh = ¬ΩMv¬≤(1 + Œ≤)</span><br/> <span class="math">2gh = v¬≤(1 + Œ≤)</span><br/> <span class="math">v¬≤ = 2gh/(1 + Œ≤)</span></li> <li><strong>Step 4: Solve for Œ≤</strong><br/> From Step 1: <span class="math">v¬≤ = g √ó R_loop = 4.704</span><br/> From Step 3: <span class="math">v¬≤ = 2gh/(1 + Œ≤)</span><br/> <br/> Equating:<br/> <span class="math">g √ó R_loop = 2gh/(1 + Œ≤)</span><br/> <span class="math">R_loop(1 + Œ≤) = 2h</span><br/> <span class="math">1 + Œ≤ = 2h/R_loop</span><br/> <span class="math">Œ≤ = 2h/R_loop - 1</span><br/> <span class="math">Œ≤ = 2(0.36)/0.48 - 1</span><br/> <span class="math">Œ≤ = 0.72/0.48 - 1</span><br/> <span class="math">Œ≤ = 1.5 - 1</span><br/> <span class="math">Œ≤ = 0.50 ‚úì</span></li> <li><strong>Step 5: Verification</strong><br/> Check: <span class="math">v¬≤ = 2gh/(1+Œ≤) = 2(9.8)(0.36)/1.5 = 7.056/1.5 = 4.704 ‚úì</span><br/> This matches the value from circular motion analysis.</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_22 Topic: Rotational Motion Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 166:

In the figure below, a non-uniform cylindrical object of mass M and radius R rolls smoothly from rest down a ramp and onto a horizontal section. From there it rolls off the ramp and onto the floor, landing a horizontal distance d = 0.506 m from the end of the ramp.Figure: Non-uniform cylindrical object rolling down from height H, leaving ramp at height h, landing at distance dThe initial height of the object is H = 0.90 m; the end of the ramp is at height h = 0.10 m. The object consists of an outer cylindrical shell (of a certain uniform density) that is glued to a central cylinder (of a different uniform density).The rotational inertia of the object can be expressed in the general formI = Œ≤MR¬≤, but Œ≤ is not 0.5 as it is for a cylinder of uniform density.Determine the value of Œ≤.‚ö†Ô∏è FIGURE MISSING: This problem references a figure that was not included in the original document. The figure needs to be added manually.

Options:

A.
Œ≤ = 0.20
B.
Œ≤ = 0.25
C.
Œ≤ = 0.30
D.
Œ≤ = 0.40
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Analyze Projectile Motion Phase </strong> <p> After leaving the ramp at height h = 0.10 m, the object undergoes projectile motion. The vertical motion determines the time of flight: </p> <div class="formula"> Vertical motion: h = (1/2)gt¬≤ <br/> t = ‚àö(2h/g) = ‚àö(2 √ó 0.10 / 9.8) = ‚àö0.0204 = 0.1429 s </div></li> <li><strong> Step 2: Find Horizontal Velocity at Ramp Edge </strong> <p> The horizontal distance traveled during projectile motion: </p> <div class="formula"> d = v_horizontal √ó t <br/> v = d/t = 0.506 / 0.1429 = 3.542 m/s </div> <p> This is the speed of the object's center of mass as it leaves the ramp (assuming negligible air resistance). </p></li> <li><strong> Step 3: Apply Energy Conservation from Start to Ramp Edge </strong> <p> Initial state: At rest at height H </p> <div class="formula"> E_initial = MgH (purely potential) </div> <p> state: Rolling at ramp edge at height h with speed v </p> <div class="formula"> E_= Mgh + KE_translational + KE_rotational <br/> E_= Mgh + (1/2)Mv¬≤ + (1/2)Iœâ¬≤ </div> <p> For rolling: v = œâR, so œâ = v/R </p> <p> With I = Œ≤MR¬≤: </p> <div class="formula"> E_= Mgh + (1/2)Mv¬≤ + (1/2)(Œ≤MR¬≤)(v/R)¬≤ <br/> E_= Mgh + (1/2)Mv¬≤ + (1/2)Œ≤Mv¬≤ <br/> E_= Mgh + (1/2)Mv¬≤(1 + Œ≤) </div></li> <li><strong> Step 4: Apply Conservation of Energy </strong> <div class="formula"> MgH = Mgh + (1/2)Mv¬≤(1 + Œ≤) <br/> <br/> Dividing by M: <br/> gH = gh + (1/2)v¬≤(1 + Œ≤) <br/> <br/> g(H - h) = (1/2)v¬≤(1 + Œ≤) <br/> <br/> (1 + Œ≤) = 2g(H - h)/v¬≤ </div></li> <li><strong> Step 5: Calculate Œ≤ </strong> <p> Substituting the known values: </p> <div class="formula"> H - h = 0.90 - 0.10 = 0.80 m <br/> v¬≤ = (3.542)¬≤ = 12.546 m¬≤/s¬≤ <br/> <br/> (1 + Œ≤) = (2 √ó 9.8 √ó 0.80) / 12.546 <br/> (1 + Œ≤) = 15.68 / 12.546 = 1.2498 <br/> <br/> Œ≤ = 1.2498 - 1 = 0.2498 ‚âà 0.25 </div></li> <li><strong> Step 6: Physical Interpretation </strong> <p> Œ≤ = 0.25 = 1/4 means: </p> <div class="formula"> I = (1/4)MR¬≤ </div> <p> This is exactly half the value for a uniform cylinder (Œ≤ = 0.5). This suggests: </p> <ul> <li> The mass distribution is more concentrated toward the center axis </li> <li> Possible configuration: dense inner cylinder with lighter outer shell </li> <li> Comparison with standard objects: </li> </ul> <table style="margin: 10px 0; border-collapse: collapse; width: 100%;"> <tr style="background-color: #ecf0f1;"> <th style="border: 1px solid #bdc3c7; padding: 8px;"> Object </th> <th style="border: 1px solid #bdc3c7; padding: 8px;"> Œ≤ value </th> </tr> <tr> <td style="border: 1px solid #bdc3c7; padding: 8px;"> Thin rod (perpendicular) </td> <td style="border: 1px solid #bdc3c7; padding: 8px;"> 1/12 ‚âà 0.083 </td> </tr> <tr> <td style="border: 1px solid #bdc3c7; padding: 8px;"> Solid disk (axis through center) </td> <td style="border: 1px solid #bdc3c7; padding: 8px;"> 1/4 = 0.25 ‚Üê <strong> Our result! </strong> </td> </tr> <tr> <td style="border: 1px solid #bdc3c7; padding: 8px;"> Solid sphere </td> <td style="border: 1px solid #bdc3c7; padding: 8px;"> 2/5 = 0.40 </td> </tr> <tr> <td style="border: 1px solid #bdc3c7; padding: 8px;"> Uniform cylinder </td> <td style="border: 1px solid #bdc3c7; padding: 8px;"> 1/2 = 0.50 </td> </tr> <tr> <td style="border: 1px solid #bdc3c7; padding: 8px;"> Thin cylindrical shell </td> <td style="border: 1px solid #bdc3c7; padding: 8px;"> 1.0 </td> </tr> </table> <p> Interestingly, Œ≤ = 0.25 is exactly the value for a solid disk rotating about its central axis, which makes physical sense for a cylinder-like object with mass concentrated near the center. </p></li> <li><strong> Step 7: Verification </strong> <p> Let's verify our answer by checking if the projectile motion works out: </p> <div class="formula"> With Œ≤ = 0.25: <br/> v¬≤ = 2g(H-h)/(1+Œ≤) = 2√ó9.8√ó0.80/1.25 = 12.544 m¬≤/s¬≤ <br/> v = 3.542 m/s ‚úì <br/> <br/> t = ‚àö(2h/g) = 0.1429 s ‚úì <br/> d = vt = 3.542 √ó 0.1429 = 0.506 m ‚úì </div> <p> Perfect match! </p></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_21 Topic: Rotational Motion Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 167:

A bowler throws a bowling ball of radius R = 11 cm along a lane. The ball (shown in figure below) slides on the lane with initial speed vcom,0= 8.5 m/s and initial angular speed œâ‚ÇÄ = 0. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the ball and the lane is Œºk= 0.21.Figure: Bowling ball initially sliding (œâ=0) then transitioning to smooth rolling (v=œâR)The kinetic frictional force fkacting on the ball causes a linear acceleration of the ball while producing a torque that causes an angular acceleration of the ball. When speed vcomhas decreased enough and angular speed œâ has increased enough, the ball stops sliding and then rolls smoothly.Find the following quantities:(a)What is vcomin terms of œâ when smooth rolling begins?(b)What is the ball's linear acceleration during the sliding phase?(c)What is the ball's angular acceleration during the sliding phase?(d)How long does the ball slide?(e)How far does the ball slide?(f)What is the linear speed of the ball when smooth rolling begins?‚ö†Ô∏è FIGURE MISSING: This problem references a figure that was not included in the original document. The figure needs to be added manually.

Options:

A.
(a) v = œâR; (b) a = -2.06 m/s¬≤; (c) Œ± = 46.8 rad/s¬≤; (d) t = 1.18 s; (e) s = 8.60 m; (f) v = 6.07 m/s
B.
(a) v = œâR; (b) a = -1.50 m/s¬≤; (c) Œ± = 35.0 rad/s¬≤; (d) t = 1.50 s; (e) s = 9.50 m; (f) v = 5.50 m/s
C.
(a) v = œâR; (b) a = -2.50 m/s¬≤; (c) Œ± = 50.0 rad/s¬≤; (d) t = 1.00 s; (e) s = 7.50 m; (f) v = 6.50 m/s
D.
(a) v = œâR; (b) a = -1.96 m/s¬≤; (c) Œ± = 44.0 rad/s¬≤; (d) t = 1.25 s; (e) s = 8.00 m; (f) v = 6.25 m/s
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Part (a) - Rolling Condition </strong> <p> Smooth rolling occurs when the velocity of the contact point is zero, which requires: </p> <div class="formula"> v <sub> com </sub> = œâR </div> <p> This is the fundamental condition for rolling without slipping. </p></li> <li><strong> Step 2: Part (b) - Linear Acceleration </strong> <p> The friction force acts backward (opposing motion): </p> <div class="formula"> f_k = Œº_k Mg (backward) <br/> <br/> Œ£F = Ma <br/> -f_k = Ma <br/> -Œº_k Mg = Ma <br/> a = -Œº_k g = -0.21 √ó 9.8 = -2.058 m/s¬≤ </div> <p> <strong> Answer: a ‚âà -2.06 m/s¬≤ </strong> </p></li> <li><strong> Step 3: Part (c) - Angular Acceleration </strong> <p> The friction creates a torque about the center of mass: </p> <div class="formula"> œÑ = f_k √ó R (causes clockwise rotation viewed from side) <br/> <br/> Œ£œÑ = IŒ± <br/> f_k R = IŒ± <br/> <br/> For a solid sphere: I = (2/5)MR¬≤ <br/> Œº_k Mg R = (2/5)MR¬≤ Œ± <br/> Œ± = (5Œº_k g)/(2R) = (5 √ó 0.21 √ó 9.8)/(2 √ó 0.11) <br/> Œ± = 10.29/0.22 = 46.77 rad/s¬≤ </div> <p> <strong> Answer: Œ± ‚âà 46.8 rad/s¬≤ </strong> </p></li> <li><strong> Step 4: Part (d) - Time to Reach Smooth Rolling </strong> <p> Using kinematics for linear and angular motion: </p> <div class="formula"> v_com(t) = v_com,0 + at = 8.5 - 2.058t <br/> œâ(t) = œâ_0 + Œ±t = 0 + 46.77t = 46.77t </div> <p> At smooth rolling: v_com = œâR </p> <div class="formula"> 8.5 - 2.058t = 46.77t √ó 0.11 <br/> 8.5 - 2.058t = 5.145t <br/> 8.5 = 2.058t + 5.145t = 7.203t <br/> t = 8.5/7.203 = 1.180 s </div> <p> <strong> Answer: t ‚âà 1.18 s </strong> </p> <p> <em> Alternative elegant derivation: </em> </p> <div class="formula"> From v = v‚ÇÄ + at and œâ = Œ±t: <br/> v = v‚ÇÄ - Œºgt and œâ = (5Œºg)/(2R) √ó t <br/> At rolling: v = œâR <br/> v‚ÇÄ - Œºgt = (5Œºg)/(2R) √ó t √ó R <br/> v‚ÇÄ - Œºgt = (5Œºgt)/2 <br/> v‚ÇÄ = Œºgt + (5Œºgt)/2 = Œºgt(1 + 5/2) = (7Œºgt)/2 <br/> t = 2v‚ÇÄ/(7Œºg) </div></li> <li><strong> Step 5: Part (e) - Sliding Distance </strong> <p> Using kinematic equation for distance: </p> <div class="formula"> s = v‚ÇÄt + (1/2)at¬≤ <br/> s = 8.5 √ó 1.180 + (1/2) √ó (-2.058) √ó (1.180)¬≤ <br/> s = 10.03 - 1.433 <br/> s = 8.597 m ‚âà 8.60 m </div> <p> <strong> Answer: s ‚âà 8.60 m </strong> </p></li> <li><strong> Step 6: Part (f) - Speed When Rolling Begins </strong> <p> Using the linear velocity equation: </p> <div class="formula"> v = v‚ÇÄ + at = 8.5 + (-2.058) √ó 1.180 <br/> v = 8.5 - 2.428 = 6.072 m/s </div> <p> Or using the elegant relation: </p> <div class="formula"> v = œâR = (Œ±t)R = (5Œºgt/2R) √ó R = (5Œºgt)/2 <br/> v = (5 √ó 0.21 √ó 9.8 √ó 1.180)/2 = 6.072 m/s </div> <p> Or using energy (for verification): </p> <div class="formula"> v_/v_initial = 5/7 (for sphere sliding to rolling) <br/> v = (5/7) √ó 8.5 = 6.071 m/s </div> <p> <strong> Answer: v ‚âà 6.07 m/s </strong> </p></li> <li><strong> Step 7: Physical Interpretation </strong> <p> The ball loses about 29% of its speed during the transition: </p> <div class="formula"> Speed loss = (8.5 - 6.07)/8.5 = 28.6% </div> <p> This energy goes into: </p> <ul> <li> Rotational kinetic energy (ball starts spinning) </li> <li> Heat due to friction (sliding dissipation) </li> </ul> <p> After reaching v = œâR, the ball rolls smoothly with no more sliding friction (only static friction maintains rolling). </p></li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_32 Topic: Rotational Motion Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 168:

Problem Statement:Two 2.00 kg balls are attached to the ends of a thin rod of length 50.0 cm and negligible mass. The rod is free to rotate in a vertical plane without friction about a horizontal axis through its center.With the rod initially horizontal, a 50.0 g wad of wet putty drops onto one of the balls, hitting it with a speed of 3.00 m/s and then sticking to it.Determine:What is the angular speed of the system just after the putty wad hits?What is the ratio of the kinetic energy of the system after the collision to that of the putty wad just before?Through what angle will the system rotate before it momentarily stops?Given:Ball mass:M= 2.00 kg (each)Rod length:L= 50.0 cm = 0.500 mPutty mass:m= 50.0 g = 0.050 kgPutty velocity:v= 3.00 m/s (downward)Rod initially horizontalTakeg= 9.8 m/s¬≤

Options:

A.
(a) 0.148 rad/s, (b) 0.0123, (c) 5.42¬∞
B.
(a) 0.296 rad/s, (b) 0.0246, (c) 10.8¬∞
C.
(a) 0.185 rad/s, (b) 0.0308, (c) 13.5¬∞
D.
(a) 0.222 rad/s, (b) 0.0431, (c) 16.2¬∞
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Calculate moment of inertia before collision </strong> <br/> Two balls at ends of rod (each at distance <em> L </em> /2 from axis): <br/> <span class="math"> I <sub> initial </sub> = 2M(L/2)¬≤ = 2 √ó 2.00 √ó (0.250)¬≤ </span> <br/> <span class="math"> I <sub> initial </sub> = 2 √ó 2.00 √ó 0.0625 = 0.250 kg¬∑m¬≤ </span></li> <li><strong> Step 2: Calculate angular momentum of putty before collision (part a) </strong> <br/> Putty hits one ball at distance <em> r </em> = <em> L </em> /2 = 0.250 m from axis: <br/> <span class="math"> L <sub> putty </sub> = mvr = 0.050 √ó 3.00 √ó 0.250 </span> <br/> <span class="math"> L <sub> putty </sub> = 0.0375 kg¬∑m¬≤/s </span></li> <li><strong> Step 3: Calculate moment of inertia after collision </strong> <br/> After putty sticks, system has two balls plus putty: <br/> <span class="math"> I <sub> </sub> = 2M(L/2)¬≤ + m(L/2)¬≤ </span> <br/> <span class="math"> I <sub> </sub> = (2M + m)(L/2)¬≤ </span> <br/> <span class="math"> I <sub> </sub> = (2 √ó 2.00 + 0.050)(0.250)¬≤ </span> <br/> <span class="math"> I <sub> </sub> = 4.050 √ó 0.0625 = 0.2531 kg¬∑m¬≤ </span></li> <li><strong> Step 4: Apply angular momentum conservation to find œâ </strong> <br/> <span class="math"> L <sub> before </sub> = L <sub> after </sub> </span> <br/> <span class="math"> 0.0375 = I <sub> </sub> √ó œâ </span> <br/> <span class="math"> œâ = 0.0375/0.2531 </span> <br/> <span class="math"> œâ = 0.1482 rad/s </span> <br/> <strong> Answer (a): œâ = 0.148 rad/s </strong></li> <li><strong> Step 5: Calculate kinetic energies (part b) </strong> <br/> KE of putty before collision: <br/> <span class="math"> KE <sub> before </sub> = ¬Ωmv¬≤ = ¬Ω √ó 0.050 √ó (3.00)¬≤ = 0.225 J </span> <br/> <br/> KE of system after collision: <br/> <span class="math"> KE <sub> after </sub> = ¬ΩI <sub> </sub> œâ¬≤ = ¬Ω √ó 0.2531 √ó (0.1482)¬≤ </span> <br/> <span class="math"> KE <sub> after </sub> = ¬Ω √ó 0.2531 √ó 0.02196 = 0.00278 J </span> <br/> <br/> Ratio: <br/> <span class="math"> Ratio = KE <sub> after </sub> /KE <sub> before </sub> = 0.00278/0.225 = 0.01234 </span> <br/> <strong> Answer (b): Ratio = 0.0123 </strong></li> <li><strong> Step 6: Apply energy conservation for rotation (part c) </strong> <br/> After collision, the system rotates and rises until it momentarily stops. <br/> <br/> Initial state (horizontal): <span class="math"> E <sub> i </sub> = KE <sub> after </sub> = 0.00278 J </span> <br/> <br/> state (at angle Œ∏): <span class="math"> E <sub> f </sub> = PE = Œî(potential energy) </span> <br/> <br/> Center of mass calculation (taking axis as origin): <br/> Ball 1 (with putty): mass = M + m = 2.05 kg at +L/2 <br/> Ball 2: mass = M = 2.00 kg at -L/2 <br/> <br/> <span class="math"> y <sub> cm </sub> = [(M+m)(L/2) - M(L/2)]/(2M+m) </span> <br/> <span class="math"> y <sub> cm </sub> = [m(L/2)]/(2M+m) </span> <br/> <span class="math"> y <sub> cm </sub> = (0.050 √ó 0.250)/4.05 = 0.00309 m </span></li> <li><strong> Step 7: Calculate angle Œ∏ </strong> <br/> When system rotates through angle Œ∏, the center of mass rises by: <br/> <span class="math"> Œîh = y <sub> cm </sub> (1 - cos Œ∏) </span> <br/> <br/> Energy conservation: <br/> <span class="math"> KE <sub> after </sub> = (2M + m)g √ó Œîh </span> <br/> <span class="math"> 0.00278 = 4.05 √ó 9.8 √ó 0.00309 √ó (1 - cos Œ∏) </span> <br/> <span class="math"> 0.00278 = 0.1226(1 - cos Œ∏) </span> <br/> <span class="math"> 1 - cos Œ∏ = 0.0227 </span> <br/> <span class="math"> cos Œ∏ = 0.9773 </span> <br/> <span class="math"> Œ∏ = arccos(0.9773) = 0.0946 rad = 5.42¬∞ </span> <br/> <strong> Answer (c): Œ∏ = 5.42¬∞ </strong></li> <li><strong> Step 8: Verification </strong> <br/> Check energy loss in collision: <br/> Energy lost = 0.225 - 0.00278 = 0.222 J (98.8% lost) ‚úì <br/> This large energy loss is expected in an inelastic collision. <br/> <br/> The small angle makes sense because most of the putty's kinetic energy was lost in the inelastic collision.</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_30 Topic: Rotational Motion Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 169:

Problem Statement:A uniform thin rod of length 0.500 m and mass 4.00 kg can rotate in a horizontal plane about a vertical axis through its center. The rod is at rest when a 3.00 g bullet traveling in the rotation plane is fired into one end of the rod.In the view from above, the bullet's path makes an angle Œ∏ = 60.0¬∞ with the rod. If the bullet lodges in the rod and the angular velocity of the rod is 10 rad/s immediately after the collision, what is the bullet's speed just before impact?Given:Rod length:L= 0.500 mRod mass:M= 4.00 kgBullet mass:m= 3.00 g = 0.003 kgAngle: Œ∏ = 60.0¬∞angular velocity:œâ= 10 rad/sRod initially at rest

Options:

A.
v = 857 m/s
B.
v = 1072 m/s
C.
v = 1286 m/s
D.
v = 1500 m/s
Correct Answer: C

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Calculate rod's moment of inertia about center </strong> <br/> For a uniform rod rotating about its center: <br/> <span class="math"> I <sub> rod </sub> = (1/12)ML¬≤ = (1/12)(4.00)(0.500)¬≤ = (1/12)(4.00)(0.25) </span> <br/> <span class="math"> I <sub> rod </sub> = 0.0833 kg¬∑m¬≤ </span></li> <li><strong> Step 2: Analyze bullet's angular momentum before collision </strong> <br/> The bullet hits at distance <em> r </em> = <em> L </em> /2 = 0.250 m from the axis. <br/> The bullet's path makes angle Œ∏ = 60¬∞ with the rod. <br/> <br/> Angular momentum of bullet about axis: <br/> <span class="math"> L <sub> bullet </sub> = mvr sin(Œ∏) </span> <br/> <span class="math"> L <sub> bullet </sub> = m √ó v √ó (L/2) √ó sin(60¬∞) </span> <br/> <span class="math"> L <sub> bullet </sub> = 0.003 √ó v √ó 0.250 √ó (‚àö3/2) </span> <br/> <span class="math"> L <sub> bullet </sub> = 0.003 √ó v √ó 0.250 √ó 0.866 </span> <br/> <span class="math"> L <sub> bullet </sub> = 6.495 √ó 10 <sup> -4 </sup> v kg¬∑m¬≤/s </span></li> <li><strong> Step 3: Calculate total moment of inertia after collision </strong> <br/> After the bullet lodges in the rod, it rotates at distance <em> L </em> /2 from the axis: <br/> <span class="math"> I <sub> bullet </sub> = m(L/2)¬≤ = 0.003 √ó (0.250)¬≤ = 0.003 √ó 0.0625 </span> <br/> <span class="math"> I <sub> bullet </sub> = 1.875 √ó 10 <sup> -4 </sup> kg¬∑m¬≤ </span> <br/> <br/> Total moment of inertia: <br/> <span class="math"> I <sub> total </sub> = I <sub> rod </sub> + I <sub> bullet </sub> </span> <br/> <span class="math"> I <sub> total </sub> = 0.0833 + 0.0001875 = 0.08349 kg¬∑m¬≤ </span></li> <li><strong> Step 4: Apply conservation of angular momentum </strong> <br/> Initial angular momentum = angular momentum <br/> <span class="math"> L <sub> before </sub> = L <sub> after </sub> </span> <br/> <span class="math"> 6.495 √ó 10 <sup> -4 </sup> v = I <sub> total </sub> √ó œâ </span> <br/> <span class="math"> 6.495 √ó 10 <sup> -4 </sup> v = 0.08349 √ó 10 </span> <br/> <span class="math"> 6.495 √ó 10 <sup> -4 </sup> v = 0.8349 </span></li> <li><strong> Step 5: Solve for bullet velocity </strong> <br/> <span class="math"> v = 0.8349 / (6.495 √ó 10 <sup> -4 </sup> ) </span> <br/> <span class="math"> v = 1285.7 m/s </span> <br/> <span class="math"> v ‚âà 1286 m/s </span></li> <li><strong> Step 6: Verification and physical reasonableness </strong> <br/> The bullet velocity is very high (~1.3 km/s), which is reasonable for high-speed projectiles. <br/> Check energy: The collision is inelastic (bullet lodges), so kinetic energy is not conserved, only angular momentum. This is physically correct. <br/> <br/> Verification of angular momentum: <br/> Before: <span class="math"> L = 6.495 √ó 10 <sup> -4 </sup> √ó 1286 = 0.835 kg¬∑m¬≤/s </span> <br/> After: <span class="math"> L = 0.08349 √ó 10 = 0.835 kg¬∑m¬≤/s </span> ‚úì</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_29 Topic: Rotational Motion Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 170:

Problem Statement:A non-uniform cylindrical object of massMand radiusRrolls smoothly from rest down a ramp and onto a horizontal section. From there it rolls off the ramp and onto the floor, landing a horizontal distanced= 0.506 m from the end of the ramp.The initial height of the object isH= 0.90 m; the end of the ramp is at heighth= 0.10 m. The object consists of an outer cylindrical shell (of a certain uniform density) that is glued to a central cylinder (of a different uniform density).The rotational inertia of the object can be expressed in the general formI= Œ≤MR¬≤, but Œ≤ is not 0.5 as it is for a cylinder of uniform density.Determine the value of Œ≤.Given:Horizontal landing distance:d= 0.506 mInitial height:H= 0.90 mRamp edge height:h= 0.10 mRotational inertia:I= Œ≤MR¬≤Object starts from restRolling is smooth (no slipping)Takeg= 9.8 m/s¬≤

Options:

A.
Œ≤ = 0.15
B.
Œ≤ = 0.25
C.
Œ≤ = 0.40
D.
Œ≤ = 0.50
Correct Answer: B

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Analyze projectile motion from ramp edge to floor </strong> <br/> The cylinder leaves the ramp horizontally at height <em> h </em> = 0.10 m. <br/> Vertical motion: <span class="math"> h = ¬Ωgt¬≤ </span> <br/> Time of flight: <span class="math"> t = ‚àö(2h/g) = ‚àö(2 √ó 0.10/9.8) = ‚àö(0.0204) = 0.143 s </span> <br/> <br/> Horizontal motion: <span class="math"> d = vt </span> <br/> Velocity at edge: <span class="math"> v = d/t = 0.506/0.143 = 3.539 m/s </span></li> <li><strong> Step 2: Alternative calculation for velocity (more precise) </strong> <br/> <span class="math"> v = d/‚àö(2h/g) = d‚àö(g/2h) </span> <br/> <span class="math"> v = 0.506 √ó ‚àö(9.8/(2 √ó 0.10)) </span> <br/> <span class="math"> v = 0.506 √ó ‚àö49 = 0.506 √ó 7 = 3.542 m/s </span> <br/> <span class="math"> v¬≤ = (0.506)¬≤ √ó 49 = 0.256 √ó 49 = 12.544 m¬≤/s¬≤ </span></li> <li><strong> Step 3: Apply energy conservation from start to ramp edge </strong> <br/> Initial energy (at height H): <span class="math"> E <sub> i </sub> = MgH </span> <br/> <br/> energy (at ramp edge, height h): <br/> <span class="math"> E <sub> f </sub> = Mgh + ¬ΩMv¬≤ + ¬ΩIœâ¬≤ </span> <br/> <br/> Using <em> I </em> = Œ≤ <em> MR </em> ¬≤ and <em> œâ </em> = <em> v </em> / <em> R </em> : <br/> <span class="math"> E <sub> f </sub> = Mgh + ¬ΩMv¬≤ + ¬Ω(Œ≤MR¬≤)(v/R)¬≤ </span> <br/> <span class="math"> E <sub> f </sub> = Mgh + ¬ΩMv¬≤ + ¬ΩŒ≤Mv¬≤ </span> <br/> <span class="math"> E <sub> f </sub> = Mgh + ¬ΩMv¬≤(1 + Œ≤) </span></li> <li><strong> Step 4: Set up energy conservation equation </strong> <br/> <span class="math"> MgH = Mgh + ¬ΩMv¬≤(1 + Œ≤) </span> <br/> Dividing by M and rearranging: <br/> <span class="math"> g(H - h) = ¬Ωv¬≤(1 + Œ≤) </span> <br/> <span class="math"> 2g(H - h) = v¬≤(1 + Œ≤) </span> <br/> <span class="math"> 1 + Œ≤ = 2g(H - h)/v¬≤ </span></li> <li><strong> Step 5: Solve for Œ≤ </strong> <br/> <span class="math"> Œ≤ = 2g(H - h)/v¬≤ - 1 </span> <br/> <span class="math"> Œ≤ = 2 √ó 9.8 √ó (0.90 - 0.10)/12.544 - 1 </span> <br/> <span class="math"> Œ≤ = 2 √ó 9.8 √ó 0.80/12.544 - 1 </span> <br/> <span class="math"> Œ≤ = 15.68/12.544 - 1 </span> <br/> <span class="math"> Œ≤ = 1.250 - 1 </span> <br/> <span class="math"> Œ≤ = 0.250 </span></li> <li><strong> Step 6: Physical interpretation and verification </strong> <br/> Œ≤ = 0.25 is less than 0.5 (uniform cylinder), indicating the mass is concentrated more toward the axis than a uniform cylinder. This could represent a solid inner cylinder with a thin outer shell. <br/> <br/> Verification: With Œ≤ = 0.25: <br/> <span class="math"> v¬≤ = 2g(H-h)/(1+Œ≤) = 2 √ó 9.8 √ó 0.80/1.25 = 12.544 m¬≤/s¬≤ </span> ‚úì <br/> <span class="math"> d = v‚àö(2h/g) = ‚àö12.544 √ó ‚àö(0.02041) = 3.542 √ó 0.143 = 0.506 m </span> ‚úì</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_28 Topic: Rotational Motion Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 171:

Problem Statement:A bowler throws a bowling ball of radiusR= 11 cm along a lane. The ball (initially) slides on the lane with initial speedvcom,0= 8.5 m/s and initial angular speedœâ0= 0.The coefficient of kinetic friction between the ball and the lane is 0.21. The kinetic frictional force acting on the ball causes a linear deceleration of the ball while producing a torque that causes an angular acceleration of the ball.When speedvcomhas decreased enough and angular speedœâhas increased enough, the ball stops sliding and then rolls smoothly.Determine:What isvcom(in terms ofœâ) when smooth rolling begins?What is the ball's linear acceleration during sliding?What is the ball's angular acceleration during sliding?How long does the ball slide?How far does the ball slide?What is the linear speed when smooth rolling begins?Given:Ball radius:R= 11 cm = 0.11 mInitial linear velocity:v0= 8.5 m/sInitial angular velocity:œâ0= 0Coefficient of kinetic friction: Œºk= 0.21For a solid sphere:I= (2/5)MR¬≤Takeg= 9.8 m/s¬≤

Options:

A.
(a) <em> v </em> <sub> com </sub> = <em> œâR </em> , (b) 2.06 m/s¬≤, (c) 46.8 rad/s¬≤, (d) 1.18 s, (e) 8.60 m, (f) 6.07 m/s
B.
(a) <em> v </em> <sub> com </sub> = 2 <em> œâR </em> , (b) 2.06 m/s¬≤, (c) 93.5 rad/s¬≤, (d) 2.36 s, (e) 17.2 m, (f) 3.04 m/s
C.
(a) <em> v </em> <sub> com </sub> = <em> œâR </em> /2, (b) 1.03 m/s¬≤, (c) 23.4 rad/s¬≤, (d) 2.36 s, (e) 17.2 m, (f) 12.1 m/s
D.
(a) <em> v </em> <sub> com </sub> = <em> œâR </em> , (b) 4.12 m/s¬≤, (c) 23.4 rad/s¬≤, (d) 0.59 s, (e) 4.30 m, (f) 6.07 m/s
Correct Answer: A

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> <li><strong> Step 1: Answer part (a) - Condition for smooth rolling </strong> <br/> Smooth rolling (no slipping) occurs when the rolling constraint is satisfied: <br/> <span class="math"> v <sub> com </sub> = œâR </span> <br/> <strong> Answer (a): v <sub> com </sub> = œâR </strong></li> <li><strong> Step 2: Calculate linear acceleration (part b) </strong> <br/> During sliding, friction opposes the motion: <br/> Friction force: <span class="math"> f <sub> k </sub> = Œº <sub> k </sub> Mg </span> <br/> By Newton's 2nd law: <br/> <span class="math"> -f <sub> k </sub> = Ma </span> <br/> <span class="math"> a = -Œº <sub> k </sub> g = -0.21 √ó 9.8 = -2.058 m/s¬≤ </span> <br/> <strong> Answer (b): |a| = 2.06 m/s¬≤ (deceleration) </strong></li> <li><strong> Step 3: Calculate angular acceleration (part c) </strong> <br/> Friction creates torque about the center of mass: <br/> <span class="math"> œÑ = f <sub> k </sub> R = Œº <sub> k </sub> MgR </span> <br/> By rotational Newton's 2nd law: <br/> <span class="math"> IŒ± = œÑ </span> <br/> <span class="math"> (2/5)MR¬≤Œ± = Œº <sub> k </sub> MgR </span> <br/> <span class="math"> Œ± = (5Œº <sub> k </sub> g)/(2R) = (5 √ó 0.21 √ó 9.8)/(2 √ó 0.11) </span> <br/> <span class="math"> Œ± = 10.29/0.22 = 46.77 rad/s¬≤ </span> <br/> <strong> Answer (c): Œ± = 46.8 rad/s¬≤ </strong></li> <li><strong> Step 4: Determine sliding time (part d) </strong> <br/> Linear velocity: <span class="math"> v = v <sub> 0 </sub> + at = 8.5 - 2.058t </span> <br/> Angular velocity: <span class="math"> œâ = œâ <sub> 0 </sub> + Œ±t = 0 + 46.77t </span> <br/> Rolling begins when <span class="math"> v = œâR </span> : <br/> <span class="math"> 8.5 - 2.058t = 46.77t √ó 0.11 </span> <br/> <span class="math"> 8.5 - 2.058t = 5.145t </span> <br/> <span class="math"> 8.5 = 7.203t </span> <br/> <span class="math"> t = 1.180 s </span> <br/> <strong> Answer (d): t = 1.18 s </strong></li> <li><strong> Step 5: Calculate sliding distance (part e) </strong> <br/> Using kinematics: <br/> <span class="math"> s = v <sub> 0 </sub> t + ¬Ωat¬≤ </span> <br/> <span class="math"> s = 8.5(1.180) + ¬Ω(-2.058)(1.180)¬≤ </span> <br/> <span class="math"> s = 10.03 - 1.432 </span> <br/> <span class="math"> s = 8.60 m </span> <br/> <strong> Answer (e): s = 8.60 m </strong></li> <li><strong> Step 6: Find linear speed (part f) </strong> <br/> At t = 1.180 s: <br/> <span class="math"> v = v <sub> 0 </sub> + at = 8.5 + (-2.058)(1.180) </span> <br/> <span class="math"> v = 8.5 - 2.428 = 6.072 m/s </span> <br/> Alternatively, using the ratio: <span class="math"> v <sub> </sub> = (5/7)v <sub> 0 </sub> = (5/7)(8.5) = 6.071 m/s </span> <br/> <strong> Answer (f): v = 6.07 m/s </strong></li> <li><strong> Step 7: Verification </strong> <br/> Check rolling condition: <span class="math"> œâ = v/R = 6.071/0.11 = 55.19 rad/s </span> <br/> From angular acceleration: <span class="math"> œâ = Œ±t = 46.77 √ó 1.180 = 55.19 rad/s </span> ‚úì <br/> Energy check: The ball loses kinetic energy to friction work, which is expected and correct.</li> </ol> </div>
ID: Mechanics_78 Topic: Rotational Motion Chapter: Mechanics Raw HTML

Question 172:

A non-uniform ball of mass M and radius R rolls smoothly from rest down a ramp and onto a circular loop of radius 0.48 m. The initial height of the ball is h = 0.36 m. At the loop bottom, the magnitude of the normal force on the ball is 2.00Mg. The ball consists of an outer spherical shell (of a certain uniform density) that is glued to a central sphere (of a different uniform density). The rotational inertia of the ball can be expressed in the general form I = Œ≤MR¬≤, but Œ≤ is not 0.4 as it is for a ball of uniform density. Determine Œ≤.

Options:

A.
Œ≤ = 0.25
B.
Œ≤ = 0.30
C.
Œ≤ = 0.35
D.
Œ≤ = 0.40
Correct Answer: B

Question 173:

An aerialist is to make a quadruple somersault lasting a time t = 1.87 s. For the first and last quarter-revolution, he is in the extended orientation with rotational inertia I‚ÇÅ = 19.9 kg‚ãÖm¬≤ around his center of mass. During the rest of the flight he is in a tight tuck, with rotational inertia I‚ÇÇ = 3.93 kg‚ãÖm¬≤. What must be his angular speed œâ‚ÇÇ around his center of mass during the tuck?

Options:

A.
œâ‚ÇÇ = 6.28 rad/s
B.
œâ‚ÇÇ = 8.54 rad/s
C.
œâ‚ÇÇ = 10.32 rad/s
D.
œâ‚ÇÇ = 12.95 rad/s
Correct Answer: D

üí° Solution (with unrendered expressions):

<div class="solution"> <strong>Solution:</strong> <div class="strategy"> <strong>Strategy:</strong> </div> <div class="expert-insight"> <strong>Expert Insight:</strong> </div> <div class="key-facts"> <strong>Key Facts Used:</strong> </div> <ol class="steps"> </ol> </div>
